—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That although elector-initiated referendums are conducted successfully in such countries as Switzerland and the U.S.A., no such facility exists for Australian citizens.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Initiate the necessary action for a referendum to be held to amend the Constitution to provide for such an initiative on the following conditions:

If a specified percentage of voters (such as 2%) sign a petition asking that a referendum be held on a certain question the Federal Government would be obliged to hold that referendum and the result would become law.
And your petitioners further humbly pray that the referendum be timed to coincide with the referendum to be held to extend the term of office of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years.
And we humbly pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatization and de-regulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatization, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 66 citizens), Powell (from 213 citizens) and Zakharov (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mordechai Vanunu: Release from Prison
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:
Our deepest concern at the plight of Mordechai Vanunu, who revealed details of the nuclear weapons arsenal of Israel;
Our belief that Vanunu's actions were a service to humanity-including to the people of Israel-and were in fulfilment of his duty under international law;

Our belief that the unlawful abduction of Vanunu from Rome, his imprisonment since then, his prison conditions, and his conviction on charges of espionage and treason are denials of his fundamental human rights.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Resolve to ask the Australian Government to appeal to the Government of Israel to release Mordechai Vanunu immediately and without conditions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Nuclear Free Zone

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALLENTINE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 2,133 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, praying that the Australian Capital Territory, including Jervis Bay, be declared a nuclear free zone:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned concerned citizens and residents of the A.C.T. reject the proposed military and industrial developments at Jervis Bay.

We support the conclusions of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation Reports of 1975 and 1986 which found that Jervis Bay should be preserved for recreation and scientific research purposes.
We also oppose plans for the establishment of a Nuclear Reactor at Jervis Bay and for visits by Nuclear-Powered and Nuclear-Armed warships to the region.
We call on the Federal Government to implement legislation to declare the A.C.T. (including Jervis Bay) a Nuclear Free Zone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MAGUIRE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petitioning letter, from four citizens, which is not in conformity with Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, praying that adequate funds be provided for nursing homes in Victoria to maintain a high standard of care:

SPEECH.PARA: The Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament.
In reference to proposed legislation on the funding of Nursing Homes-

We, the undersigned, have relatives either awaiting admission to or who are already in Nursing Homes, and we are justifiably concerned at what effect a severe cut in funding would have. These elderly people are the former young parents who reared families during the depression years, and have earned some care and consideration in the final years of their lives.

Indeed, if the funding cuts are to be as severe as the media has indicated, in addition to a sharp decline in nursing care, many of these folk would be unable to remain in care at all, and as most of them have sold their homes in order to meet expenses, they would have nowhere to go. This situation has engendered enormous fear in the elderly, an extra worry they do not need.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a I give notice that, immediately after Question Time this day, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 to 13 standing in my name for this day of sitting for disallowance of certain delegated legislation. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been corresponding with various Ministers about delegated legislation which appeared to be at variance with the Committee's principles. Ministers have now given the Committee satisfactory explanations for certain provisions and undertaken to amend other provisions to ensure that the Committee's standards are complied with. I thank all of the Ministers for their cooperation. In two of the 13 instruments examined, Ministers have given satisfactory explanations of certain provisions about which the Committee was initially concerned. In the remaining 11 matters Ministers have agreed to bring forward amendments including the following measures to protect personal liberties: various Administrative Appeals Tribunal review rights are to be granted when certain discretions are exercised; a reference to an absolute discretion is to be replaced by a right to seek reconsideration of a decision; certain officials and inspectors are to use proper photographic identity cards; written instruments are to be used when Ministers take certain important administrative decisions; a reasonable time is to be allowed for public submissions about certain proposed plans of management; various matters are to be reported to the Parliament which might not otherwise have been made public; and certain strict liability offences are to be re-examined in the light of the Committee's principles.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee hopes that all of these important ministerial undertakings can be implemented within six months as recommended in the Committee's eightieth and eighty-third reports. If, for whatever reason, it proves impossible to finalise matters within six months, the Committee hopes that Ministers will take the opportunity to advise the Senate of the reasons for any delay.

Mr President, I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short description of the Committee's scrutiny of the matters that are now resolved. This will be available immediately for any honourable senators who wishes to read it.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Regulations (Amendment)

The Regulations exempted from a certain levy foreign fishing boats imported into Australia by resident Australian citizens or companies. The Regulations made the question of determining the ownership of a boat a matter for the unreviewable discretionary decision of the Departmental Secretary or an officer authorised by the Secretary. Such an unreviewable discretion appeared to the Committee to be inappropriate since citizenship and ownership would be ascertainable matters of fact and law. Since as a matter of law Australian owned boats are exempt from levy the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Kerin, M.P., agreed to amend the Regulations to make it clear that the Secretary has no discretion in this matter and that his or her responsibility is limited to ascertaining whether, as a matter of fact, a boat is Australian owned.
Canberra Institute of the Arts Ordinance 1988
(A.C.T. Ordinance No. 1 of 1988)

The Committee was interested to ensure: (i) that certain statutory decisions to be taken under the Ordinance would be made in writing for the protection of all concerned; (ii) that certain Fees Determinations would legally be subject to parliamentary control through procedures for tabling and disallowance; and (iii) that some possibly confusing drafting errors were examined. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., (i) assured the Committee that the Determinations in question were legally subject to parliamentary procedures; and (ii) agreed to amend the Ordinance to remove typographic errors and require that, to be lawful, certain discretionary decisions must be taken in writing.
Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment) (S.R. 1987 No. 303)

These Regulations repealed earlier Regulations which established and regulated the importation scheme for the landing of meat and blood products in Australia. The repealed Regulations have been replaced by Proclamations which are not subject to parliamentary scrutiny. The Proclamations are drafted in a style little different from regulations and contain provisions concerning unreviewable discretionary powers. Had these provisions appeared in Regulations the Committee would have discussed them with the relevant Minister and sought certain amendments. Because proper parliamentary controls were not available, the Committee wrote to the Minister for Resources, Senator the Honourable Peter Cook, M.P., about the issue. Although the Proclamations as such are not subject to the Committee's scrutiny the Minister has nevertheless undertaken to amend them to provide for AAT review of the discretionary powers they contain. A new Agricultural Quarantine Bill is in the course of preparation for introduction in the Budget sittings which will provide that the matters currently dealt with by the Proclamation, including necessary review rights, will instead be prescribed by regulations subject to parliamentary oversight.
Telecommunications (General) By-laws Amendment No. 50

Under the By-laws the Commission may determine that a group of buildings is not a building complex and therefore, the owner or tenant of the complex (the relevant subscriber) is not eligible to receive an authorization to operate a shared tenant private branch exchange. The Committee was concerned about a number of aspects of the By-laws. No criteria existed to guide the exercise of that discretionary power. A negative determination could cause commercial or other damage to a relevant subscriber. Such a determination could be arrived at erroneously, unfairly or arbitrarily. There was no right under the By-laws to apply either to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or to the Commission for review of such a determination. Long standing Australian principles of fair administration in the public domain suggested to the Committee that in these By-laws there should be some legal criteria for decision making and some legal right of appeal on the merits.

Having considered these points the Australian Telecommunications Commission has agreed that (i) the By-laws should be amended, as soon as possible, to provide relevant subscribers with a right to apply for internal reconsideration of a determination that a group of buildings is not a building complex for the purposes of the By-laws; (ii) the By-laws should provide the usual range of procedural safeguards and requirements for this right of reconsideration, for example, a relevant subscriber who is affected by such a determination should be informed in writing of the decision and of the right of reconsideration within a reasonable time; (iii) the reconsideration should be conducted expeditiously by the Managing Director and one or more Commissioners appointed by the Commission for this purpose; (iv) within the next 12 months set criteria should be developed, and expressly included in the By-laws, as the criteria in accordance with which determinations will be made whether a group of buildings is a building complex; and (v) in 12 months time the Commission will advise the Committee on how the internal reconsideration procedure is operating.
Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations (S.R. 1987 No. 322)

These Regulations prescribed certain Standards for the preservation and portability of benefits in superannuation funds and approved deposit funds. Under the Regulations a fund member's benefits will be preserved until the member leaves the fund or benefits become payable on the member retiring, dying, emigrating or in ``such other circumstances (if any) as the [Insurance and Superannuation] Commissioner approves''. The Committee sought advice from the Treasurer, the Honourable Paul Keating, M.P., as to whether the exercise of these discretionary decisions of the Commissioner should be subject to review. The Treasurer advised that-(i) the regulations continued a pre-existing arrangement under which the Commissioner of Taxation approved early release of benefits; (ii) in other than very special circumstances release of benefits that had enjoyed taxation concessions would reduce the incentive to invest income for genuine retirement purposes and cause inequity for other fund contributors and tax payers; (iii) the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will carefully consider applications made for early release of funds outside the circumstances prescribed and decisions will be subject to judicial review in the Federal Court; (iv) the unreviewable discretions identified by the Committee related to the Commissioner's power in special and clearly warranted cases only, to make exceptions or grant exemptions to an otherwise universal administrative scheme. After reflecting on these points the Committee agreed to accept the Treasurer's explanations for the absence of explicit merits review mechanisms. In the particular circumstances of this case the Committee considered-(i) the special taxation and policy complexities of the Standards in question; (ii) the national financial and economic significance of the general scheme in which exemptions of necessity and by definition would be exceptional; and (iii) the practice of not subjecting to independent review administrative exemptions from the application of a general scheme that is intended, in all but exceptional circumstances, to apply uniformly and in its entirety to a general class of persons-this is not a general principle for the Committee but merely a guideline to assist its categorisation and evaluation of certain discretions. Bearing in mind all of these factors the Committee accepted the Treasurers' explanations.
Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Regulations (Amendment) (S.R. 1987 No. 330)

These Regulations provided that, although generally proceedings before a Redeployment and Retirement Appeal Committee were public, the Committee could by order prohibit or restrict the publication of evidence if satisfied that this was desirable because of its confidential nature (for example, in cases involving certain kinds of medical evidence). The Committee pointed out to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, the Hon. Ralph Willis, M.P., that there was no legislative power or penalty to enforce such an order, and while generally all proceedings should be open, where an exception was needed it should be enforceable. The Minister agreed to amend the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984 to allow for the imposition of a reasonable sanction for breach of a confidentiality order issued by the Committee.
Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 70 of 1987)

The Committee was concerned that section 55 might have conferred on the Schools Authority (a corporation sole) immunity from civil action for negligent or other acts committed in the performance of the Authority's functions. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., advised the Committee that the section did not confer immunity on the Authority as such which could still be sued for wrong-doing. However, the past and present holders of the office of Authority (i.e. essentially the Chief Education Officer) would be protected from action in the same way as an employee would be protected. The Committee accepted this. The Minister also undertook to amend the Ordinance to ensure that powers either affecting individuals or committing the Commonwealth to obligations would be exercisable only in writing. The Minister has also drawn to the attention of his legislative drafters the importance of requiring such powers in future legislation to be exercised in writing. In the interim he will require writing as an administrative practice in relation to relevant powers. Finally, the Minister also undertook to amend the Ordinance to make it clear that employees of the restructured Schools Authority would continue to be employed on the same terms and conditions they were subject to immediately before the commencement of the Ordinance.
A.C.T. Institute of Technical and Further Education Ordinance 1987 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 71 of 1987)

The Committee was concerned about a number of technical aspects of the Ordinance namely: (i) that the law should require certain important decisions to be taken in writing-the Minister, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., undertook to amend the Ordinance to reflect this principle; (ii) that the Minister's power to withhold from Parliament all information about the commercial activities of the Institute where disclosure would adversely affect the Institute, should be reduced to enable publication at least of the fact that information is being withheld for good reasons-the Minister undertook to seek an amendment to the Audit Regulations to require that the Institute's Annual Report would record and until the situation altered, go on recording, the fact that the Minister wished to withhold certain information about the commercial transactions of the Institute, the Report itself being subject to tabling and debate in Parliament. (iii) that the Ordinance include the usual ministerial powers of removal of the Director of the Institute in specified circumstances only-the Minister agreed that the office of Director should be protected in this way; (iv) that the Ordinance itself place a limit on the penalties that might be imposed for infringement of administrative arrangements and directions made and given by the Director-the Minister undertook to do this and provide for AAT review of any administrative decision that could result in the imposition of such a penalty.
Liquor (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1987 (A.C.T. ordinance No. 72 of 1987)

The Committee obtained the assurance of the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., that section 17a of the Ordinance did not reverse any onus of proof in criminal proceedings under the Ordinance. The provision was designed to facilitate the seizure of alcohol from underage drinkers. The Minister also assured the Committee that in the interests of fairness when a young person had been cautioned under the Ordinance, and was later prosecuted for a similar alleged underage drinking offence, the circumstances of the first caution would not ground any additional offence.
States Grants Petroleum Products Schemes Amendment (Amendment No. 88/01)

A previous amendment to the Scheme erroneously omitted to include appropriate reference to 4 remote Western Australian localities as localities where petroleum products consumers were eligible to receive a petroleum subsidy. As a result since 6 March 1987 consumers had paid higher prices than was intended. The latest amendment was designed to restore the localities to the Scheme from 15 January 1988. The Committee was concerned about the consequences of the error for consumers during the period March 1987 to January 1988. The Minister, the Hon. Barry Jones, M.P. explained that two fuel distributors had supplied 24 customers. The distributors had received $12,208.30 of subsidy less than they should have received and since subsection 5 (4) of the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965 requires that subsidy be passed on to end-consumers, 24 customers paid $12,208.30 more than they should have done for fuel. The Minister suggested that the consumers might apply for an ex gratia payment by the Commonwealth. The Committee has decided to withdraw its notice of motion of disallowance of the Amendment because it is beneficial to consumers. However, the Committee has written to the Minister urging him to take the initiative by directing that the Commonwealth should make the required payments to people who have been denied a benefit, of which they were probably unaware, by a mere administrative and drafting error in the preparation of the original Amendment. The Committee considers that equity in administration of the subsidy scheme demands no less than ex gratia payments at the initiative of the Minister (not the unwitting consumer) if a premium is not to be placed on administrative error as a means of economising on certain payments which people would otherwise enjoy as a legal right.
Long Service Leave (Building and Construction Industry) (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1987 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 74 of 1987)

Where an employer failed to pay timely contributions to the long service leave fund the penalty was a $10,000 fine. The Ordinance reduced that penalty to $500 on the assumption that for each day of non-payment after the obligation to pay had arisen, a fresh offence, carrying a penalty of $500, arose. Thus, the deterrent effect of the old law was thought to remain no less effectively but perhaps more reasonably in the new provision for the protection of employees. However, the Committee pointed out to the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., that the new provision had not legally created an adequate mechanism to make it certain that a continuing daily offence had been created. The relevant section of the Ordinance (s. 11), and of the Interpretation Ordinance 1967 (ss. 33B and 33C), had not referred to ``a day'' as being the period of time on the expiration of which a fresh offence arose. Provisions of other legislation did make such express reference to the relevant period. Such reference was probably essential to avoid uncertainty as to the frequency with which a continuing offence was repeated, (e.g. an hour, a day, a week), uncertainty which could have undermined the deterrent effect of the reduced penalty. (See, for example, section 87 of the Taxation (Administration) Ordinance 1987, regulation 7aa contain the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations (Amendment) (S.R. 1985 No. 275) and subsection 4K (2) of the Crimes Act 1914 contained in section 11 of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act 1987). The Minister agreed to correct this flaw by amending the Interpretation Ordinance to specify that a continuing offence would arise on every day that overdue contributions had not been paid.
Canberra Sewerage and Water Supply Regulations (Amendment) (A.C.T. Regulations 1987 No. 19)

These Regulations enabled the A.C.T. Engineer to refuse a permit for building work unless he or she was satisfied that an adequate drainage device, namely a back-flow prevention device, would be installed to prevent contamination of the Canberra water supply. An unfair refusal could seriously disrupt building operations. The Engineer could also refuse to approve of new devices designed to achieve the same effect as devices described in a Schedule to the Regulations. An unfair refusal to approve could cause a designer, manufacturer or supplier commercial damage. While in no way suggesting that the Engineer had or would make decisions other than those properly based on professional judgments and expertise, the Committee was concerned about the absence of review rights. The Committee suggested to the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P. that, on the grounds of principle, the AAT should have power to review these two discretionary decisions and the Minister undertook to amend the Regulations to so provide.
Environment Protection and Management Ordinance 1987 (Heard and McDonald Islands Ordinance No. 1 of 1987)

The Ordinance provided for interested persons to make representations about proposed plans of management for the Islands. However, it did not specify any definite and reasonable minimum period for submission of such representations. It left open the legal possibility that submissions could be refused after an unreasonably brief period. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator the Hon. Graham Richardson, undertook to amend the Ordinance to specify a reasonable period for submissions to be lodged. The Ordinance contained numerous strict liability offences and offences for which there was no express defence of reasonable excuse. In many cases these were coupled with penalties which were higher than usual for regulatory offences. The Committee was concerned about this as a matter of principle. However, the Committee also acknowledged that the Islands exhibited unique environmental attributes which required stringent protective measures. The Minister agreed that his officers and officers of the Attorney-General's Department should review the offences and penalties in the Ordinance in the light of the Committee's concern. The Minister also undertook to amend the Ordinance-(i) to limit the level of fees that may be imposed by Island Territory regulations; (ii) to require use by inspectors of proper photographic identity cards; (iii) to specify a maximum time limit for the notification of certain decisions; and (iv) to correct some possibly confusing drafting of definitions in the Ordinance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes amendments to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 to empower a Minister, with the agreement in writing of the Minister responsible for the Act, to make minor changes in the provision of tariff assistance to industries in narrowly defined circumstances without the requirement for a prior report of the Industries Assistance Commission. At present, section 23 (3) of the Act prevents changes in prescribed forms of assistance unless a relevant report of the Commission has been received by the Government within the preceding 12 months. The only exceptions are for changes that relate to bilateral or multilateral trade negotiations or to tariff preferences for developing countries.

Section 23 (3) is of fundamental importance to the Act and to the role of the Commission. It aims to ensure that, when governments make decisions on matters involving assistance to particular industries, they have available to them up to date, independent and informed advice by the Commission on these matters.

The Commission's reports, being based on processes of public inquiry in which the views of all interested parties can be presented and examined, provide a vital means for allowing public scrutiny of the claims of individual industries for assistance before decisions are made. The Government fully endorses this objective and will continue to maintain the role of the Commission.

However, section 23 (3) is at present very widely drawn. Apart from the two exceptions I have mentioned, it prevents all changes in prescribed forms of assistance, no matter how minor, in the absence of a relevant report of the commission or legislation by the Parliament. The proposed amendments will provide a very limited degree of additional flexibility to make minor changes in industry assistance in specified circumstances. The amendments relate only to changes in assistance provided through customs duties, not other forms of assistance, and the circumstances are precisely defined.
These circumstances are:
where action is necessary to correct anomalies, errors or ambiguities in the Customs Tariff Act;
where action is necessary to correct an error in the implementation of a government decision on assistance to industry where that decision arose out of a report of the Commission;

Where action is necessary to vary details of industry assistance arrangements because of changes in circumstances where provision for such action was made in the Government decision establishing those arrangements and where that decision arose out of a report of the Commission;

where action is necessary to maintain the level of assistance previously applying where a decision by a tribunal or a court has had the effect of altering the rate at which duty on imported goods is collected; or
where action is necessary to keep tariff classifications in line with the Australian Customs Service co-operation council nomenclature.

The last of these circumstances relates to the implementation of tariff classification rulings by the Customs Cooperation Council under the International Convention on the Harmonised Commodity Description and Coding System. The Bill makes clear that such changes are covered by the existing exception in section 23 (3) relating to multilateral trade agreements.

The provisions in the Bill relating to the other four circumstances involve the establishment of new exceptions in section 23 (3) under which tariff changes can be made when more than 12 months have elapsed since the receipt of a relevant report by the Commission. In each case, the circumstance is carefully defined and has the objective either of correcting anomalies, errors or ambiguities, or of maintaining the intention of earlier government decisions on industry assistance where those decisions have been made on the basis of Commission reports. As an additional safeguard to ensure that the role of the Commission is not eroded, action by a Minister under any of these four circumstances requires the written approval of the Minister administering the Industries Assistance Commission Act.

The provisions in the Bill relating to anomalies, errors or ambiguities, and to errors in the implementation of decisions, are intended to apply to simple clerical mistakes, such as the misspelling or misspecification of an item, or the like. They do not apply to situations where a government may wish to change its mind after the 12 month period following the receipt of a report of the Commission has elapsed.

Similarly the provisions in the Bill relating to changes in circumstances are restricted to situations where a government has decided, at the time it made its decision on assistance arrangements for an industry following receipt of a report of the Commission, to allow specific actions to be taken if those changes in circumstances occur. These provisions are intended to provide scope for variations in tariff rates to be made in response to changes in economic conditions affecting an industry where the variations are within predetermined limits set at the time of the original decision and the circumstances involved were specified in that decision. For example, an industry plan might make provision for variations in the duty rates applying to out-of-quota imports in the event that imports of the goods concerned exceed specified limits.

The Bill also provides for variations in tariff assistance to particular goods following a decision by a court or tribunal. Under Australia's tariff system, an appeals mechanism exists on the classification of goods. Such appeals are decided on legal grounds, although a decision to vary the classification of particular goods usually results in a change in the level of assistance provided to a domestic industry.

The provisions in the Bill will allow action to be taken to reinstate quickly, and with minimal loss of revenue, the level of assistance previously decided by the government where the government's decision arose out of a report of the Industries Assistance Commission. These provisions in the Bill will not overturn a ruling of a tribunal or court on the classification of goods between tariff items. Such rulings will stand. However, the provisions will permit the intent of government decisions on levels of tariff assistance to be maintained.

Changes in tariff assistance following government consideration of a report of the Commission are normally introduced initially by way of customs tariff proposal when Parliament is sitting, or Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice of intention to propose a customs tariff alteration when it is not. The provisions of the present Bill will allow these procedures to be utilised, in the specific circumstances I have outlined, where a period of more than 12 months has elapsed since the receipt of a relevant report of the Commission. In each case, the action taken will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny when the corresponding Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is introduced.

The proposals put forward in the Bill are expected to have only a minor financial impact. The Bill does not involve any additional staff or resources for the Industries Assistance Commission or the Australian Customs Services, which is responsible for implementing changes to the Customs Tariff Act. Present practice is to introduce a Customs Tariff Bill into Parliament to give effect to the proposed changes in the Bill. This delays the collection of duties.

The financial impact of the Bill would result from more timely changes to the rates of duty which may flow from the proposed amendments, but it is expected that any such changes would be minor. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Lewis) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill contains amendments to a number of Acts administered by the Transport and Communications portfolio. The amendments are of a kind which it has been the practice, in recent years, to make in an omnibus Bill of this nature.
Amendments of the Navigation Act 1912

Under the Offshore Constitutional Settlement in 1979 it was agreed that jurisdiction over offshore industry vessels would normally be exercised by the States and the Northern Territory. However, section 8a of the Navigation Act 1912 provides that the Minister may, following consultation with State-Northern Territory Ministers, declare an offshore industry vessel to be a vessel to which the Act applies, where the owner declares that the vessel's operations will not be confined to the waters of one State or Territory during the subsequent three years.

At the 74th Australian Transport Advisory Council in July 1987, Federal, State and Northern Territory Transport Ministers agreed that the statutory constraints upon the Minister's declaration should be dispensed with. The Bill, in clause 5, gives effect to that agreement.
The efficiency scrutiny unit established by the Government in 1986, and headed by Mr David Block, reviewed the functions and administration of mercantile marine offices.

The review found that many of the functions performed by the Government through mercantile marine offices were out-of-date and wasteful of resources both of the taxpayer and the maritime industry. Significant streamlining measures were recommended and after consultation with the industry, involving both maritime unions and shipowners, have been given effect by clause 6 and schedule 1 of the Bill.

The proposed amendments will accordingly eliminate detailed involvement by the Department in the engagement and discharge of seafarers. The Act will, however, maintain a legislative framework ensuring the welfare of seafarers in accordance with International Labour Organisation conventions.

The opportunity is also being taken to remove references in the Act to indentured apprentices. Such references are obsolete and contrary to the future training initiatives recently taken by the maritime industry through the Maritime Industry Development Committee.
At the same time, a now obsolete transitional provision in the Navigation Amendment Act 1979, relating to ships' crews is to be repealed.

Unproclaimed amendments contained in the Navigation Amendment Act 1980 and the Navigation Amendment Act 1981, which were intended to introduce a contract of sea service as an alternative to articles of agreement in the offshore industry, are to be repealed as being no longer required following the Department's reduced involvement in the employment of seamen.

The levels of penalties under the Navigation Act 1912 have been revised by Attorney-General's Department to conform to penalties applying to similar offences in other Federal legislation. Clause 7 and schedule 2 of the Bill give effect to these.
Amendment of the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952
The amendment of the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 is to make decisions in respect of remission or refund of charges due or paid under the Act reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Amendments of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986
The amendments of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 are:

to ensure that the Corporation's liability for accrued staff entitlements including annual and long service leave transferred by the Commonwealth to the Corporation is taken into account in determining the capital of the Corporation;
to clarify the power and procedure relating to the determination of charges under the Act;
to enable the Corporation to establish a second superannuation scheme for short-term contract staff;
to make a minor editorial correction.
Clauses 11 to 15 inclusive of the Bill give effect to these amendments.
Amendments of the Shipping Registration Act 1981

The amendments to the Shipping Registration Act 1981 are to ensure that where a ship or a share in a ship is disposed of, the registration certificate for the ship is returned to the Registrar of Ships for registration of the change.
Amendments of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983
Amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 are of an editorial nature to correct erroneous cross-references.
Financial Impact Statement

Implementation of the scrutiny review recommendations regarding mercantile marine office services will achieve savings through more efficient utilisation of staff and accommodation. All remaining services provided to industry will be fully cost recovered from users.
In 1988-89 it is estimated those savings will amount to $0.7m (reflecting gradual implementation of new procedures) and in 1989-90 savings of $1.4m will be achieved (based on 1987-88 costs).
There will be no significant costs, revenues or savings to the Government arising from the other amendments in the Bill.
None of the amendments proposed in the Bill are of a controversial nature and I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
