SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulation 3 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1987 No. 322 and made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987, be disallowed.

The Opposition indicated some time ago that it proposed to move for the disallowance of the definition section of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations, not because it opposes all of the definitions contained but quite specifically because it is concerned with one particular definition, namely, that of a member representative in relation to a board or committee of trustees of a superannuation fund. As the motion indicates, the regulations were made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987, which is a very broad Act providing the Government with considerable regulation making power with respect to the rules which are to be applied to occupational superannuation. That legislative action is occurring in the context of a considerable expansion of occupational superannuation following decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission relating to a 3 per cent wage rise being taken in the form of occupational superannuation.

I think it is generally welcomed that there should be expanded access to superannuation for the Australian work force. The concerns which have arisen relate to the extent to which expansion of superannuation is used for purposes other than the provision of superannuation benefits and the best possible superannuation benefits for the employees concerned. I noted in his somewhat irritable comment following the refusal of leave to incorporate a second reading speech a suggestion--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would rather have the Kelly brothers running the funds.

—There was some suggestion from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), which has now been repeated, that I might rather have some particular individuals whom he has named running the fund. I make it quite clear that the Opposition is concerned to ensure that the fund should be run by people who are genuinely representative of the members of the fund, people who will benefit from the fund and not anyone else, whether they be employers with a quite separate interest--
—You are full of sanctimonious humbug.

—It is typical of the way Senator Walsh conducts debate in this place that before I have a chance to outline my case he interjects with statements like `sanctimonious humbug', and so on. The Opposition is totally fed up with, and sick of, the childish behaviour of Senator Walsh in this place and his refusal to debate these matters sensibly. I simply point out that I find his intervention from the front bench, firstly, childish and, secondly, unlikely to ensure that we will be able to deal with this matter sensibly and briefly so that we can get on with Government business in this place. The Government has set an impossible legislative target for the Senate and it is unlikely that we will be able to make much of a dent in it while Senator Walsh continues to interject from the front bench in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: However, to return to the motion, the Opposition is concerned to ensure that where contributions are made to superannuation funds, whether by employers or employees, they are directed to providing the maximum possible benefit to those who are supposed to benefit from those contributions, namely the employees, and that they achieve the maximum possible retirement benefits from the investment of those funds.

I take it from the Minister's interjection that he is concerned that in the past there have been occasions when individuals, including employers, have ensured that superannuation funds were used for their benefit rather than for the benefit of the employees and their retirement incomes. I would just like to make it utterly clear that it is in no way the desire of the Opposition to protect any malpractice, past, present or future; our sole concern is to ensure that the employees concerned get the maximum benefit from the money which is invested on their behalf. To the extent that the Government moves to prevent abuses of superannuation, that will have the support of the Opposition. To the extent that the Government enables people to obtain access to or control of superannuation funds in a way which might not be used for the benefit of the employees, then the Opposition will object, as it is doing in the present case.
Our concern about this particular regulation is quite simply for the reason that it provides:

`member representative', in relation to a board or committee of trustees of a superannuation fund, the board of a body corporate acting as the sole trustee of a superannuation fund or a management board, management committee or other management body that exercises actual control over the policies of a superannuation fund, means a member of that board, committee or body nominated by the members of the fund-
here we come to the words that concern the Opposition-
or by trade union or other organisation representing the interests of those members.

So we find in the definition that a member representative may be a person nominated by a trade union or other organisation representing the interests of those members. In reality what this definition permits is for a superannuation fund to have as a member representative or, indeed, as member representatives people nominated by trade unions who themselves are not members of the fund. In other words, there is no necessary connection between the nomination by the trade union and the actual direct interests of the members of the funds. It may well be that that person is not a member of the fund. It certainly may well be that that person is not put there with the acquiescence or the approval of the members of the fund. In other words, it puts beyond the capacity of the members of the fund the control over who will represent them and permits people to be there who may have no real interest, their only interest in the fund being to get the maximum possible retirement benefit from it.

It is important to understand that this push for the involvement of trade unions in the administration of superannuation funds is something which is causing concern to many people. The Life Underwriters Association of Australia on 9 September 1987 issued a media release which, to some extent, is representative of the sorts of concerns which are held much more widely. The Association asked in that Press release:
Does this mean that union leaders are now able to influence the investment decisions by the Trustees of union superannuation funds?
It referred earlier in the Press release to:
The threat by trade union leaders to use the vast amounts of investment funds accumulated in union controlled superannuation funds to buy public utilities . . .

That is just a single example of the expressions of view by trade union representatives over recent years that superannuation funds should be used not primarily to protect the retirement incomes of the people who are members of the funds but to pursue other social or political objectives. In the case commented on in the Press release of 9 September 1987 by the Life Underwriters Association, it involved the assertion that trade unions could use these accumulated investment funds in union controlled superannuation to buy public utilities. It may well be that there are people in the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement who see the public ownership of certain utilities as being in the national interest. Interestingly, the Minister at the table, Senator Walsh, about whom I was complaining a few minutes ago, had some very sensible things to say about the ownership of public utilities and where the public interest lay. I congratulate him on his recent contribution to that debate, because I believe that it was a rational and sensible contribution which will, I hope, help to produce rational and sensible responses from the Party of which he is part.

TALK.START.PARA: —He described the arguments of some of his colleagues on this matter as `the three great lies'.
—That is right. I am assisted by Senator Stone, who reminds me that what Senator Walsh was talking about were the three great lies which are propagated in this debate.
—Some of the quasi theft, or actual theft, is practised by the Queensland Government; it is taxpayers' money. Senator Stone would agree with that too.

—Senator Walsh interjects on the basis that there has been quasi theft by the Queensland Government with respect to some superannuation funds. I made the point earlier in the debate that it is no part of the Opposition's wish to see other than the most effective management of superannuation funds for the benefit of employees. What the Life Underwriters Association is talking about is the clearly expressed view by some trade union representatives that superannuation funds ought to be directed to achieving social and political objectives which bear no relationship to the immediate requirement-to the primary, and indeed the only, requirement-on those superannuation funds which is to provide the best possible retirement benefits for the people whose money it is.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other elements of concern around. Again, I quote from a source outside politics, the Australian Association of Independent Businesses Ltd. In its newsletter of March 1988 in an editorial headed `Union juggernaut rolls on', it referred with concern to union activity being on the increase in the superannuation area, with awards being varied daily to force employers to make contributions to superannuation funds for their employees, and to unions stipulating which superannuation fund the contribution must be paid into. The editorial states:
Yes that's right-``no freedom of choice''-except in some cases where Employers or their Associations have stood up and demanded a fair go.

The reality is that the trade union movement is undertaking this superannuation push for a number of reasons. Some of the reasons relate to a perfectly proper and sensible desire to see the benefits of superannuation extended more widely to the non-government work force. Again, let me say that, as an objective, the Opposition believes that is entirely appropriate.

The secondary agenda falls into a number of parts. There is the element to which I have already referred-the other social and political objectives-and the fact that unionisation of the work force is declining. In the Senate chamber this morning there are a number of senators whose backgrounds are in trade unions. They would know-and I am sure that they would share the concern of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and people who have spoken on this topic-that interest in being a member of a trade union is declining. Only 46 per cent of the Australian work force is unionised. The great proportion of unionised people lies in the public sector. Nearly 70 per cent of people employed in the public sector are unionised. In the private sector, which is the sector that badly needs expansion and which is expanding in Australia, between 65 and 70 per cent of the work force is not unionised. That is a matter of choice. It is a choice which some trade unions seek to circumvent by use of the procedures for giving preference to unionists. De facto compulsory unionism can be imposed in some circumstances. The simple truth is that in the Australian community in 1988, a declining proportion of people are choosing to join trade unions. They do not see that as being in their best interests.

That is a matter about which the Labor Party and the trade unions are entitled to be concerned. They are entitled to take action to try to reverse that trend, but they are not entitled to take action to force people to join trade unions. It is one thing for the trade union movement to offer better and improved services to its members-a higher standard of servicing, better results and so on-and thereby attract people to its ranks; it is a totally different matter to use trade union or industrial muscle of one sort or another or superannuation schemes to increase in an involuntary way the membership of trade unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of those people want to join a union. If they are not in one, they will get the sack.

—That interjection comes from a senator from Tasmania who has a trade union background. Let me make it clear that I respect his trade union background. But I disagree with the spirit of his intervention in this debate by way of interjection because the reality is that trade unions by and large are not seeking to expand their membership by increasing the attractions of membership. They are trying by various means to coerce people into membership. The greatest possible condemnation of the trade union movement is that it is not prepared to go out and win its membership on the basis--
—Name them.
—Let me say that in the north of Melbourne, for example, at the time of the last election--
—Even if that were true, what has it got to do with this motion?

—It has a lot to do with this motion. This motion is about a regulation which requires people to have as their member representatives and trustees on superannuation boards people who are the nominees of trade unions. That is something--
—That is a misstatement of fact for a start. It does not require; it provides.

—The Minister intervenes and says that it does not require. In one sense that is right. But in another sense it is wrong, because in many circumstances individual employees are not being given a choice as to where their superannuation funds will go. In those circumstances, people who may not even be members of a trade union may well be forced to be members of a superannuation fund on which trade union representatives are the trustees.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go back to the point that I was making when Senator Walsh again interjected. The simple fact of the matter is that in numerous discussions that I have had with employers I have found circumstances, particularly in the context of small business, where membership of trade unions is forced upon an unwilling work force and where the complaint is that, membership having been achieved, the unions do not then service that membership. I can cite, for example, a person running a building supply operation in a northern suburb of Melbourne who resisted at first, along with his employees, unionisation of the work force. But in the end the union came along and said, `There are safety problems here'. The work force was enrolled and the union was not seen again. The employer rang the particular union on numerous occasions and said, `You have claimed that there are unsafe conditions of work here. I do not wish my employees to have unsafe conditions of work. Come to my place of work and show us what is wrong because we wish to rectify it'. There was no interest on the part of the union and no visit.
I am not suggesting that there are not excellent trade unions that are providing excellent services for their members and attracting membership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?

—I have a doubtful interjection from Senator MacGibbon, who is sitting behind me. I am prepared to say that in my dealings with the Vehicle Builders Union, for example, I have been impressed by that union's concern for the welfare of its members. I have been impressed by its overall approach to the industry in which they work. I cite that union as but one example of what I would see as positive trade union activity. But I am also saying that there are many elements of negative trade union activity.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time that remains to me, let me return to the simple reality that under this definition individual members can be effectively forced to be members of a fund, given the combination of circumstances which now apply in terms of Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decisions about superannuation and so on, of which the trustees are not representative of members of the fund in the sense that those members have absolutely no say in who shall look after them. That may well be determined by factors totally outside the control of the members. That is the narrow point of concern which underlies this motion for disallowance. I hope that a whole lot of red herrings are not drawn into subsequent debate. I want to be quite precise. Our sole concern is with the reality that, under this definition, members of a fund-incidentally, they may not be members of a trade union-without any say on their part, will be represented by nominees not of themselves but of a trade union.

I return to the point that there is a serious doubt as to whether all trade unions are concerned to achieve what members wish to achieve, which is the maximisation of their retirement benefits. The simple illustration of that is the formal document produced by the ACTU entitled Australia Reconstructed. That document represents a statement by the ACTU on which a great deal of work was done by the trade union movement. It makes considerable reference to superannuation in the section dealing with the proposal of the ACTU that there should be a national development fund. The relevance of that to this disallowance motion is the specific recommendation in Australia Reconstructed on page 23 under the heading `Funding the National Development Fund'. Recommendation No. 1.6 states:
All superannuation funds be required to make available up to 20 per cent of their future income to be drawn on by the National Development Fund.
Recommendation No. 1.7 also affects investment by superannuation funds. It states:
Those superannuation funds which already have more than 15 per cent of their investment overseas should be required to reduce such investments according to the following timetable:

It then sets out a year by year reduction schedule to apply from 1987 to 1992-presumably, those dates would have to be adjusted to fit in with the timing of the introduction of this proposal-bringing such investments down to a maximum of 15 per cent. In other words, the trade union movement is saying in this formal document that it believes that a significant proportion of the funds should be directed to funding this national development fund. The document makes it clear that the national development fund is to be used to achieve other economic and social objectives. For example, it will be specifically concerned to ensure the achievement of long term investment. That may well be a very good thing to achieve in a broad theoretical sense; whether or not it is a good thing to achieve for a particular superannuation fund is a matter which, in the view of the Opposition, should be judged according to whether that represents a sensible investment for the membership of the fund. Page 22 of Australia Reconstructed reads:

Since the projected growth of superannuation funds is rapid, there is an argument for using some of the funds for housing in addition to industry finance. On social welfare grounds the highest returns would be gained if funds were concentrated on the building of modest houses, preferably through the public housing authorities, for sale on income-related mortgage instruments. The balance of investment between housing and industry would depend strongly on whether these needs can be met from other sources, and would have to be aligned with the overall economic strategy.

That is perhaps an unexceptionable statement of social policy. If we were debating the way that taxpayers' funds, government funds, should be used to assist socially people on low incomes with housing, that would make a lot of sense. But we are not talking about the general pool of taxpayers' funds here; we are talking about a pool of funds which are accumulated from the contributions of employees and employers towards the long term retirement incomes of those employees. It is suggested here that what may well be laudable social welfare objectives should be pursued using those funds. The Opposition's simple point is that that is not the correct source of such funds. It flies in the face of the requirement which should be and has always been on the trustees of superannuation funds to maximise the returns for retirement incomes. That is why we are concerned about the suggestion that there should be some compulsory limit on investment out of this country. Again it is being said that the interests of the employees in having a maximised retirement income is to be sacrificed to a separate economic or social objective. Again, on page 22 we find these words:
Decisions would also need to be made on the appropriate rate of return on the AIDC Fund-
that is, the Australian Industry Development Corporation fund-
that would accrue to the superannuation funds either as an equity return or as a nominal interest return.

The simple point to be made in respect of that is that again it represents a step back from the fundamental principle which has always dictated the actions of trustees in the past; namely, that they should maximise the return which can be achieved for the membership. To the extent that Senator Walsh chooses to enter into this debate and make it a vehicle for discussing what he sees as past abuses by participants in the superannuation industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —You know the Kelly brothers were abusing it.

—I am not making a prejudgment on the examples that might be brought forward. I simply want to make it clear that no part of the case made by the Opposition concerning this regulation in any way defends the abuse of superannuation funds by people who use them for a purpose other than the purpose for which they are put together.
—The Bank of Adelaide.

—The more the Minister chooses to multiply the examples the more I would wish to say in response, `Do not add to the possibility of future abuses by putting in requirements which will mean that we may have trustees who have duties other than a duty to the members'. In other words, if Senator Walsh is going to say there have been abuses, and by abuses we mean an attempt to divert the use of the funds from providing benefits for members, all I can say is that we wish to make common ground with him and to establish that this should not become an opportunity for future abuses. There are plenty of statements on the public record. I have chosen to quote some in the debate. Significant elements of the trade union movement would argue that the direction of superannuation funds should be for purposes outside the provision of a maximised benefit for the employees. That is our point of concern and that is why we seek to disallow this regulation. We seek to disallow it on the basis that the Government can then remake the regulation containing all of the other definitions and simply remake even the particular regulation to which I have referred-the definition of `member representative'-but omit the words `or by a trade union or other organisation representing the interests of those members'. We are looking for control by the members of the fund of those member representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments that I think can be put up basically relate to questions of whether there is any cost to be incurred in ensuring that these member representatives are genuinely representatives of the members of the fund. That is no different from the costs which are incurred in a public company where the membership of the board of directors is left with the control of the owners of that company, the shareholders. In exactly the same way costs are incurred in the trade union movement in ensuring that the management of the trade union movement is elected by its membership. Yes, there are some economic costs in that but I believe those costs are minuscule compared with the absolute requirement that the member representatives of committees of trustees ought to be people whose sole responsibility is to the members of their fund and who do not have a separate agenda in their activities as members of boards or committees of trustees.

The position the Opposition has taken is clearly correct in principle. I believe it should have the support of the Senate, and I commend the motion and ask the Government to give very serious consideration to the amendment of this particular regulation to provide genuine protection for the workers of Australia who will be contributing to these funds for their future retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney said several times during his contribution to the debate on this motion for disallowance with regard to occupational superannuation standards regulations that he did not want to see red herrings take up a great deal of time, and yet I suggest that the greater part of his speech was devoted to precisely those red herrings. He talked about the fact that members of superannuation funds would not have any say in how the funds were invested or in the appointment of union representatives on boards as trustees. I wonder how often members of the funds are consulted, in any event, no matter who the trustees are. I wonder how often members of superannuation funds are consulted about how those funds are invested.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney argued that the main responsibility of trustees is to maximise the return to the benefit for the members. That is fine as far as it goes, but he was talking about it in the context of offshore investment by those superannuation funds. I think it is worth while pointing out that taxpayers are subsidising those returns on investments, because the profits of superannuation and life funds are not taxed and, as we all know, the majority of taxpayers are not members of superannuation funds. For a variety of reasons, the majority do not benefit from superannuation. It seems a little questionable to argue that taxpayers generally, as a group, should subsidise a part of their group who do benefit from belonging to a superannuation fund, even when such a fund invests offshore, and in so doing deplete domestic lending reserves.

For a variety of reasons of his own, Senator Chaney threw quite a lot of red herrings across the path of this debate. Apparently, what it boils down to, having listened to Senator Chaney, is that he, and I presume the entire Opposition, is concerned about one aspect of regulation 3; namely, that relating to the definition of a member representative. Under regulation 3, `member representative' is defined as:
. . . a member of that board, committee or body nominated by the members of the fund or by a trade union or other organisation representing the interests of those members.

According to Senator Chaney, apparently the Opposition wants fund members to elect member representatives to a board, committee or body corporate, rather than simply nominating members. I would think that the attitude of the principals of the fund in this case should be considered by the Senate chamber. They surely have a place in this debate, and their opinions ought to be considered to be quite relevant to this.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has approached us with its views on the matter, and it takes a much more cautious, if not to say rational, approach to the problem. In the memorandum forwarded to us, dated 18 April, referring specifically to the Opposition's proposal to disallow regulation 3, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia said:

Supporting this proposal would be a very serious step. Regulation 3 contains the definitions which are then used in all other regulations, and the step would therefore bring the operation of the regulations to a halt.

I point out that the superannuation funds have been under some considerable pressure over the past year or two because of slowness on the part of the Government in getting its act together in these areas. We have all had plenty to say in this place on legislation by Press release, particularly when the Press release is made six months or a year or more prior to the Government actually introducing the relevant legislation. To then meddle in the area of delegated legislation, in the area of regulation, is not making it any easier for the funds to operate, to know where they are going, or to have any certainty at all in their method of operation.

I understand from Senator Chaney that the Opposition would prefer that the word `nominated' be replaced by the word `elected' and for all the words relating to appointment by a trade union or similar body to be deleted. This minor paranoia that Senator Chaney seems to have about all those unions other than the ones involved in building cars is a little out of place in this debate, I would have thought, but it certainly seems to be behind the motion that Senator Chaney has moved today. Again, I think it is worth while pointing out what the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has to say on this matter. It is very clear. In opposing the Opposition's proposals, the Association has informed us:

The industry could not support either of these specific changes. Election must not be the only acceptable method of appointment. Also, for industry funds, particularly those established jointly by an employer organisation and the ACTU, it is quite appropriate for some trustees to be appointed by the ACTU or a trade union.

On the question of election versus nomination, the Senior Superannuation Actuary of the Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP) in a letter of 21 April specifically addressed the matter of the definition of `member representative' in regulation 3 and in particular the fact that nomination by a trade union satisfies this definition. The AMP had this to say:

While this may well have been a concern prior to the advent of `productivity superannuation', the fact that this development emanates from the industrial relations arena changes our attitude somewhat. Where a productivity plan arises through a consent award through the Arbitration Commission we believe it is natural that the parties to this consent award are represented as trustees of the ensuing plan. The wording of the definition is wide enough to embrace this situation without requiring it. To require an election of trustees in a multi-employer industry plan would we believe be impractical and we don't see this as a satisfactory alternative.

The memorandum from the AMP also points out-and I do not recall Senator Chaney addressing his attention to this-that regulation 14 in fact requires a two-thirds majority for trustee decisions, and this ensures that neither employer nor union representatives can force decisions without some support from the other.

Senator Chaney did not indicate in his contribution why he thinks that regulation 3 would somehow mean union domination of the decision-making capacity, when regulation 14 quite clearly requires a two-thirds majority for a trustee decision, and it is unlikely that the union representatives will form a two-thirds majority of any group. So, unless the employer representatives also concur with the proposal, there is little likelihood of some sort of hidden agenda pursued by the unions being forced through.

I am sure that honourable senators will recall that the Opposition did everything it could at the end of last year to reject, or at the very least hold up, the passage of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987. The delayed introduction of that Bill by the Government, following its Press release, had already caused concern in the industry and again we were contacted by senior groups in the industry requesting that we not support the Opposition in delaying or defeating that legislation. They were already in a confused enough state over what delays had already occurred and they did not want any more. What appears to have happened is that yet again an opportunity to do a bit of union bashing has got in the way of concern for the effective and efficient operation of an industry. Frankly, it is no wonder that Ian Macphee, who I remind the Senate was Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government, was moved to say in the Melbourne Herald only last month:

I frankly am in no doubt that the wages outcome which has been delivered so far by the Government could not have been achieved by a Coalition Government, even if I had been Industrial Relations Minister.

Given that the Opposition parties, through Senator Chaney and with the enthusiastic support of Senator Stone-who twitches madly at the very mention of the word `union'-seem to be basing their opposition to regulation 3 on the fact that a union representative will be part of the trustee system and, worse, that he will be a nominated instead of an elected person, I can see absolutely no justification at all for supporting the motion. At the behest of the industry most affected by these regulations, an industry very keen to be able to get on with doing what Senator Chaney argues it is there for-maximising returns and benefits to its members-the Australian Democrats will not support Senator Chaney's motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has suggested that all Opposition members are paranoid about unions. In general, I agree with that, but it is not entirely true. I recall that when the Australian Capital Territory branch of the doctors' union-the Australian Medical Association-was blackmailing taxpayers, it had the public support of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Thus, while Senator Haines is generally right, there is the odd exception to the hostile paranoia that the Opposition displays about unions. To unions in general, the Opposition is hostile and paranoid, but when it comes to the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Australian Medical Association it is highly supportive of the doctors' union when it attempts to blackmail the taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I should clear up at the outset an important matter, otherwise something quite wrong could be read into the remarks made by Senator Chaney. Regulation 3 does not require that there be union representatives on a superannuation fund. It allows for the nominee of a union to be appointed as a trustee. It is not mandatory; it is a provision that allows it to happen. Senator Chaney, in putting his case, produced no evidence whatever of any malfeasance or malpractice by union nominees who were trustees of superannuation funds. He just speculated about the possibility of there being some malpractice in future by union nominated trustees.

However, on the other hand, we have hard evidence-which I know Senator Chaney does not want me to regurgitate-of malpractice by employers in managing superannuation funds in the past. There was the celebrated case of the Kelly brothers, to whom I referred, who ran a moderately sized business and had a superannuation fund for their employees, although most, if not all, of the employees were unaware of that fact. The Kelly brothers paid into this fund tax deductible payments over a number of years-quite a long period. However, to qualify for any benefit an employee had to remain for, I think, 15 years in continuous employment. The Kelly brothers ensured that no employee actually remained employed for 15 years. Ultimately, of course, the assets of the fund would have reverted to the Kelly brothers without employees ever getting a cent out of that fund.

That was tantamount to theft. The Government could not do very much about it because, although it was tantamount to theft, it was not technically theft. The Government could not do much about the fact that the Kelly brothers had ostensibly made a payment to their employees when they had no intention of ever making one. However, the Government could do something about the taxation implications of the matter. It introduced a Bill to deny to the Kelly brothers and others who had similarly rorted the superannuation system the tax deductibility of the payments they had made ostensibly for their employees but in fact for themselves.

What happened then was that the Opposition ensured that the money remained tax free, even though the Kelly brothers had already effectively stolen it from their employees. None of this became public until these rogues fell out, and one Kelly brother started to spill the beans on the other. They were regarded as, if not shady and disreputable characters, fairly inconsequential people.

However, there was another example of mismanagement of a superannuation fund by employers, by no less than the Bank of Adelaide, a pillar of the Adelaide establishment, which was using the employees' superannuation fund to buy the bank's own shares on the stock market. Thus we have hard evidence of employers manipulating and misusing their powers on superannuation funds. On the other hand, we have wild and paranoid speculation about the possibility of union nominees doing that. The Opposition says that we cannot allow union nominees to be trustees of a fund, while saying nothing about employers.

Let me make it perfectly clear that I am not suggesting that a large number, let alone a majority, of employers behave as the pillars of the Adelaide establishment, who were trustees of the Bank of Adelaide's superannuation fund, behaved, or as disreputable characters such as the Kelly brothers behaved. Those cases are atypical of employers but nevertheless such abuses have taken place in the past. The Opposition expressed no concern about that fact but used its numbers in the Senate to ensure that the money effectively stolen by the Kelly brothers from their employees remained tax free in the hands of the Kelly brothers.

If this motion for disallowance were to be carried-and I have noted that Senator Haines has said that the Australian Democrats will not support it, so that it will not be carried-it would raise the question of what would replace regulation 3, and Senator Chaney did not address that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did address that.

—I am sorry; I did not hear him do so. I was going to say that that matter was addressed by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) in the House of Representatives, who suggested that an election should be held. Incidentally, an election is not precluded by regulation 3. It is one of the options available, just as one of the other options available is for a union nominee to represent the employees on the fund. If an election were to be mandatory, as the honourable member for Bradfield suggested-and I am not sure what Senator Chaney was suggesting-it should be noted that a statutory requirement to hold elections would bring with it a considerable extra layer of requirements, including such matters as the frequency of elections, how they are to be conducted, who oversees the operation, and procedures for handling disputes. I am advised that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission's contact with industry bodies has shown that there is no need to impose additional and costly legislative requirements of this kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines referred to correspondence that a national organisation and the Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP) addressed to the Australian Democrats. I think the AMP is the largest superannuation fund; if not, it is certainly among the largest. Neither of them is supporting the Opposition's action. I am also advised by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission's office that no complaints have been received from either employers or employees about regulation 3, which the Opposition proposes to disallow.

If this motion of disallowance were to be carried-and, as I said before, clearly it will not be-I am advised that it would not only affect the question of rules under which trustees representing employees could be appointed but also remove all of the definitions from the occupational superannuation standards regulations, not just the one relating to the members' representative. This would obviously also cause confusion about regulations in the industry as well as difficulties in administration. It would, of course, also undermine the equal sharing of control principle which the regulations seek to establish, as well as a number of other important standards designed to protect member interests; for example, minimum vesting requirements. That points directly to the matter I raised earlier. If there are no minimum vesting requirements, it certainly opens the system up-much more so under this regulation-to further abuses of the type practised in the past by the Kelly brothers and the directors of the Bank of Adelaide.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walsh has the call. The other two honourable senators should have their discussion privately.

—I do not think I need to say very much more. I do not have to convince the Democrats; apparently they have already made up their minds and have reached a sensible decision. I am a bit puzzled as to what motivates the Opposition. It has these obsessive attitudes and hysterical, irrational reactions any time the word `union' appears in front of it or when the word is mentioned; it could be that, or it could be that in the absence of any significant policies of its own it continues to play a spoiling role about everything.

SPEECH.PARA: The only point which Senator Chaney has put up in favour of this proposition is that in the future there might be some union nominee who will abuse his position as a trustee of a fund. He then drew a longer bow and alleged that there was coercion by some unions of employers and their employees to enrol members for no reason other than to swell the unions' income flow. That may be true. However, if it is true it has nothing to do with this question. The Opposition is essentially saying that one cannot allow union nominees to be trustees of superannuation funds because they will abuse their position. The Opposition produced no evidence of union nominees having abused their position-and they have been sitting around superannuation funds for at least 15 years. Senator Devlin probably has a better idea of that than I. Is it longer?

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit longer.

—Senator Devlin tells me it is a bit longer than 15 years. There is no evidence that I am aware of and certainly none has been produced by the Opposition that any of these union representatives have abused their position over the last 15 years and beyond. But the Opposition says that they might abuse their position. However, as I have mentioned, there is hard evidence of employers having abused their position. But we, on the Government side, do not say that because there are a couple of crooks called Kelly and because the pillars of the Adelaide establishment decided that they would sacrifice the funds of their employees' superannuation fund in order to protect their position, we will not allow any employer representation on the funds. It is a pity that the Opposition cannot be equally rational. We do not draw general conclusions from a couple of isolated incidents. On the other hand, the Opposition draws general conclusions on the basis of no evidence at all, just the possibility that something might happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, hanging over all this is the fact that these jointly managed funds must still comply with the rules laid down by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and that that Commission has an ongoing oversighting role to play to ensure that superannuation funds are properly managed. Of course, that does not entirely remove the possibility. No system yet devised by human society is perfect. We cannot guarantee absolutely that the Commission will ensure that there is never any abuse of any superannuation fund. But here is an additional and totally independent overseeing body which is charged with, amongst other things, the responsibility of seeing that funds are properly managed. I do not intend to say any more. It is clear that the disallowance motion will not be carried, and a good thing too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The speeches made on behalf of the Australian Democrats and the Government had a number of points in common and, in the interest of time, I will deal with them in common. I will first dispose of the furphy which was put, I think more forcefully by Senator Walsh than by Senator Haines but indeed put by both of them, that in some way the Opposition in moving this disallowance motion is trying to dispose of the whole of the definition. In moving this motion I made it quite explicit that what is objected to by the Opposition is essentially one line in the definition of `member representative' which permits the appointment of a person who is nominated by a trade union which is not necessarily a trade union of which the members of the fund are themselves members.

SPEECH.PARA: It was simply suggested that the effective deletion of that line from that definition would adequately meet the Opposition's concern. With the disallowance being moved, there is no technical reason why the other definitions cannot be restored and, indeed, why this amended definition cannot be restored. So it is a complete furphy for the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and, indeed, for Senator Haines to suggest that some great vacuum will be left. There is absolutely no need for that.

The simple reality is that when the Government chooses to legislate in an important area such as this by means of subordinate legislation-that is, the use of regulations-there are limitations on the capacity of the Parliament to move amendments. It can move disallowance motions only in terms of a section or a clause of the regulations. That is one of the reasons that, in important matters such as this, we should see these matters dealt with by proper legislation rather than regulation because there is that restriction on us. But, in this case, there is absolutely no ground for the Australian Democrats to hide behind that technicality in indicating why they will not support this particular disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I said we would not support it because the industry does not want to support it.

—I am very glad to have that interjection from Senator Haines, who now says, in her irritated manner, that the Democrats will not support this because the industry does not want them to support it. In this debate, we are not speaking for the Australian Mutual Provident Society; we are speaking for the people in this country who have superannuation benefits. The Australian Democrats may choose to listen only to those whose basic interest is accumulating superannuation funds for their administration. We are concerned with the basic interests of the members of superannuation funds who may be in a situation where their benefits are not being maximised. We do not feel it necessary simply to listen to those people who have the administration of the funds; we are concerned with the interests of the members of those funds. It is a pity that the Australian Democrats do not remember that we are here representing people-we are not here representing narrow interest groups. However, there is no question of difficulties and confusion arising; procedurally, there is not a problem. The suggestion by Senator Walsh that this course of action should not be taken because it is costly is exactly the same objection that could be taken to having democratic control of corporations or of trade unions. Clearly either of those propositions would not get a hearing in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that the principle that we should be most concerned with is ensuring that those people who are supposedly there to represent the members do in fact represent the members and not other interests. In fact, the difference between the Government and the Opposition and the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in this matter I think basically comes about because neither the Government nor the Australian Democrats are prepared to accept that a union nominee may, in the clear terms that have been indicated by the trade union movement itself as to its attitude to superannuation, find himself in what is essentially a conflict of interest situation. The reality is that the trade union movement has spelled out through the Australian Council of Trade Unions and through the document Australia Reconstructed that it believes that superannuation is there to serve purposes which go beyond the direct interests of the members of a fund in obtaining good retirement incomes. The simple reality is that there is therefore a possibility of a conflict of interest and, as law-makers, we should be concerned to avoid that.

I will address a point that was made by both Senator Haines and Senator Walsh about what they call the Opposition's paranoia about unions, and I do so because each time an issue relating to trade unions is raised in this place, and raised in a way that is not laudatory of the trade union movement, there are allegations that the Opposition is union bashing. I find that a very interesting allegation. It comes in particular from Senator Haines but it also comes from members of the Australian Labor Party. I think, as I have said often in the past, that the trade union movement has more than one face in this country. It has the smiling and generally responsible mask of Mr Crean and it has the less smiling but overall broadly responsible mask of Mr Kelty. The reality is that many people in the trade union movement are as anxious as any member of the Government or the Opposition to see Australia prosper, and they have the same concerns about the wider national interest. That is part of the truth about the trade union movement in Australia. I acknowledge that now, as I have acknowledged it before audiences of industrial relations societies in different States, before the H. R. Nicholls Society and before any audience to whom I have spoken on this subject. However, I think it is arrant hypocrisy to deny that there is another face to trade unionism in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same as the employers.

—The good senator from Tasmania, Senator Devlin, says, `The same as the employers'. He is right-there are saints and sinners and in the main just pretty ordinary blokes on both sides. Part of the reality with which we as parliamentarians must come to grips is the very ugly side. One can look at many reports that have nothing to do with politics, for example, the report of the Sweeney Royal Commission into Alleged Payments to Maritime Unions. Senator Devlin knows more in a practical sense about the waterfront than I could ever know because he has worked in that industry. I would say that if Senator Devlin went away and read the Sweeney report he would not be able to come back into this place and say, `Mr Justice Sweeney was afflicted with paranoia; of course all those dreadful things never occurred'. I do not believe that Senator Devlin would come into this place and say that because he knows that in a sector of the trade union movement, of which he has direct and, as I understand it, virtually lifelong experience, there are examples of abuse which would make him and any other decent Australian ashamed. Mr Deputy President, when you are not filling your present role but are serving in the capacity of a senator, you have raised issues relating to the trade union movement on the waterfront and in the coastal trade, and so on-issues which I believe are worrying for any Australian. That is also part of the less smiling face of trade unionism.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sick to death of the prissy rubbish with which Senator Haines goes on with respect to paranoia about trade unions, so I will quote not what politicians have to say but what some pretty impartial observers have said about some of the conduct of trade unions in this country, the sort of thing that sickens the men and women of Australia and leads 80 per cent of them to believe that trade unions have too much power. Until the representatives of the trade unions in this place, like Senator Devlin and the 26 other Labor members of parliament who have come from the trade union movement, are as loud in their condemnation of thuggery and bullying in the trade union movement as any Liberal, we will not have a decent country and a decent place for every man and woman in which to work. When the Dollar Sweets case got out of the political arena and into the courts, evidence-not assertions by politicians, whether Labor, Liberal or National Party-was given and we heard some of the things which make me very angry and which lead me to complain in a way that Senator Haines has the cheek to say is an example of paranoia. I refer to what was done by the picket line in Melbourne. I will read from the judgment, not of a politician but of a judge:

Then a number of women who were in the picket line punched and kicked Mr Lendon. The fourth-named defendant . . . ripped a hairpiece from his head, which he said caused him to bleed. Mr Lendon could not break free from his assailants.-

This is a worker being assaulted-not a politician, a policeman or an employer, but a worker, a man driving a van, a truck or something else and he was assaulted by his fellow workers. The judgment continues:

Mr Lendon could not break free from his assailants until two other truck drivers came to his assistance. The police were called but the picketers by this time had dispersed, at least for a moment. The uncontradicted evidence is that Mr. Lendon has, as a result of the assault, been required to have an operation on the retina of his eye, and now wears glasses.

Furthermore, he has received a number of abusive phone calls during which threats were made to him. The obstructive tactics of the picket line directed to him have continued since that day. A number of his fellow employees, drivers employed by Erand Transport Pty Ltd have perhaps not unnaturally, refused to take deliveries to the plaintiff's premises because of fear of physical violence should they venture to pass through the picket.
I infer that their fears are more than justified, and the knowledge of the assault on Mr. Lendon has lent strength to the intimidation caused by the obstructive and violent tactics of the picket.

I do not believe that it is some form of paranoia to raise these matters, whether it is in this debate or elsewhere. It is part of the reality that men and women in Australia must put up with, and I think it is a crying shame.

I turn to one other document from which I have quoted before but it is a more recent example and it occurred in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Mr Commissioner Baird is an ex-trade unionist-he is not a Liberal politician or some sort of outsider; he is a man with a lifelong involvement of the sort that Senator Devlin has had. I will read part of his account of his dealings with the building unions here in the ACT. I point out that he is not a union basher or a man afflicted by paranoia; he is a man who has struggled to get sense where there is none. He says:
There is almost no credibility with the undertakings given by the unions.
A little later he says:
. . . I find that while there are a number of cases where they are adhered to, the preponderance of disputes occur as if no agreements existed of any kind . . .
A little later he says:

Now, am I to assume that the union is going to support liars and frauds, because that is really what I am faced with, and I must say it is getting to a stage where the description of anarchy is the only description.
A little later he says:

I must say, if I were an employer I would have no hesitation, if I could not get the work done, and had issued a lawful instruction to take whatever course was available to me to either enforce the order or shut the job down.

It has gone beyond the normal industrial relationships, where the official can talk with the employers, and their representatives, in a manner-a rational manner-out of which some resolution of the dispute normally can take place.
He continued:
I could go on to give some other interesting examples of things which have happened; threats about demonstrations when I wanted to carry out inspections-

I interpolate: Here is a commissioner not, as I understand it, known as an enemy of the trade union movement, who tells us that there have been threats about demonstrations when he has wanted to inspect a building site. He continued:

verbal abuse at a football club, which I underwent by members of the FEDFA, while I was having dinner; and a number of other incidents, which, in my view, reflect the fact that there is an anarchistic situation there, which will only be resolved by very firm action both by the union officials, and I know there are a number of them that are very unhappy about the position, and by the employers.

I am sorry to divert this debate but I find it absolutely extraordinary that the Australian Democrats are not prepared to face the fact that that is also part of the industrial relations reality in this country. I am accused of paranoia when all I have done is simply quote what the trade union movement itself had to say about superannuation. Senator Walsh says that I am acting on suspicions and concerns about what might occur. All I can say is that a lot of time, effort and money-a lot of it public money-went into drawing out these views of the ACTU on the purposes for which superannuation should be used.

I am sorry, but I am not deeply moved by the authorities cited by Senator Haines nor, indeed, by the AMP because I do not believe that those authorities-the AMP or, indeed, any other body-are speaking for the people of Australia. They are quite properly speaking for the interests they see themselves as representing. What I am saying is that this regulation leaves it open for some of the members of these boards to have a genuine conflict of interest. I think that until commerce in Australia wakes up and remembers that conflicts of interest matter we will go on having the sorts of difficulties that the Minister at the table now, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), is unable to deal with at Question Time-that is, about what is happening in the capitalist system in Western Australia.

I think that a lot of the issues we are called upon to deal with show that people have forgotten what their simple duties are to shareholders and what problems arise when there is a conflict of interest-in this case the potential of a conflict of interest between a view of superannuation funds as a source of strategic investment to meet the housing needs of poor Australians, a view that superannuation funds are there to meet strategic investment requirements for an industrial renaissance in this country, a view that the superannuation funds of Australia should be directed not to invest overseas, even if we are not delivering a proper investment environment in Australia, and the view that the mobility of capital should be restricted because it does not meet political, strategic and economic objectives which might be the objectives of the trade union movement, of the Government or whatever. I simply say that there is a problem here that could be avoided. I believe that it is symptomatic of how pathetic this Parliament has become that one cannot get an intelligent, sensible response from the Australian Democrats without them indulging in the sort of abuse we got. I believe that the Minister at the table, who, of course, is an appalling example, is symptomatic of the inability of this Government sensibly, openly and honestly to debate serious issues.

It is quite clear that this motion will not be carried. However, I am very glad that I brought it forward on behalf of the Opposition and Mr David Connolly, the shadow Minister for the conduct of superannuation matters. I think, if nothing else, it has served to expose some of the deficiencies in the way in which we debate these issues in this country and the lack of concern for principle which is evident in many of the responses. I commend the motion. I trust that it will be carried. I know from the speeches that have been made that it will not be. I believe that is a pity. Given the depth of feeling that the Minister showed he had about abuses by employers-people he described as crooks of the superannuation system-it is a pity that both he and the Government should not be assiduous in ensuring that people on these bodies which have the responsibility of looking after these funds should avoid any risk of conflict of interest.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when the legislation was before the Senate I said that I wished to speak about the new Brisbane Airport and the particular points I wished to raise related to the mismanagement of that new facility by the Australian Labor Party. I outlined the history of the old airport and the reasons that it was totally inadequate and said that a decision to build a new one was taken in the late 1960s. The principal reason for that decision was that the pressures on residential areas around the airport were getting to be unmanageable. The airport was technically inadequate. The runway length for heavy international traffic was such that aircraft could not depart at their maximum all-up weight. I talked about noise in various suburbs and said that one of the design parameters was that there be a significant reduction in noise for the surrounding population.

SPEECH.PARA: We have developed, through the Department of Transport and Communications, our own noise assessment technique-the Australian noise exposure forecast (NEF). That is not a straight measure of noise intensity or a straight decibel count; it is something that we have developed in Australia which takes into account the unpleasant qualities of noise as well as volume. It represents a serious attempt to measure the discomfort, irritation and unpleasantness of noise, rather than just measuring the straight noise intensity, because the degree of unpleasantness depends on the frequencies of the sound waves themselves, as well as many other factors. The Australian noise exposure forecast contains four significant scales-20, 25, 30 and 40; that is, in increasing levels of unacceptability. The 25 NEF figure is regarded as the acceptable level for suburban noise. With the old airport, the suburbs of Doomben, Ascot and Hamilton, which are quite closely settled, had a 40 NEF figure-I think it is a logarithmic scale-which was very much above the acceptable level. Doomben, Whinstanes, Ascot and Bulimba were in the 30 to 40 NEF range. A larger number of suburbs were above the 25 NEF level, which is regarded as the cut-off point. In 1974, the Department estimated that at least 3,500 houses were above the 25 NEF level.

The figures that the Department published in relation to the study showed that the noise discomfiture with the new airport would be a whole magnitude less. Its estimate was that 49 houses, rather than 3,500, would be discomfited to a considerable level. The offer was made at that time to resume them and pay adequate compensation. There was never any promise made that the airport would be noise free because such a condition is absolutely impossible when residential areas are nearby. However, the reduction in noise was to be quite enormous. According to the figures that the Department published, about 200 to 300 houses would get some noise exposure and the level would be significant for only 49 of those. That was important because one of the design parameters of the airfield was to create a curfew-free operation. I have mentioned noise because there has been quite a degree of complaint in the Brisbane community since the airport has been opened.

I return to the history of the development of the new airport. When the Liberals went out of office in 1972, the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, promised that the airport would go ahead, but, in the usual style of Labor Prime Ministers, funding for the new airport was discontinued in March 1973. Despite repeated attempts by interested parties to get the airport back on the agenda, the Labor Party refused to do so. In 1976, an independent study by the Bureau of Transport Economics recommended that the airport should proceed. The Liberal Government of the time, under Malcolm Fraser, went ahead with it and, in December 1977, committed $12m. On 5 June 1980, the first sod was turned to mark the start of the construction. I was one of the few people who are still in the Parliament who was there when Malcolm Fraser drove a backhoe on what was the western side of the new airport to start it going. The construction of the airport then proceeded. In 1983, the Fraser Government lost office and the Labor Government came in. The Minister responsible for the airport at that time was Mr Hurford, the Minister for Housing and Construction. In Brisbane in 1983 Mr Hurford said:
Priority for funding the Brisbane Airport development would not be changed under the Labor Government.

Less than 12 months later-in fact, in March 1984-out of a Budget allocation of $70m in the Supplementary Estimates for that year, the Labor Party took $20m, despite Mr Hurford's promises that the airport would not be affected. But we have come to expect such things from a Labor government. It promised that there would be no capital gains tax and no tax on gold. Words mean nothing to the Labor Party.

As a consequence of those Budget cuts, the airport took a lot longer to finish than it should have. Nevertheless, it was finished. It was finished nearly 12 months ago. I am at a total loss to understand why the Government did not open the airport in March or April 1987 because it was finished. It just sat there. It was the woolly-minded or featherbrained activities of Cabinet that let this great asset sit there. It is hard to put an accurate price on the new Brisbane Airport, but it is about $600m in today's prices. A completed asset for which the Australian taxpayer had paid sat there collecting dust because of this Government's bureaucratic incompetence. In interest payments alone, it cost the Australian taxpayer between $60m and $80m. We had paid for that asset and it sat there doing nothing. That is absolutely incomprehensible to anyone with any business sense and it is something which private industry would never do. The airport was finally opened at 2 p.m. on 19 March 1988.

I was interested to read in the paper this week a comment by Dr Alan Reynolds, who came to Australia as a consultant to look at the Australian economy. He has been widely reported this week as saying that Australia is a big country that thinks small. I have no doubt that he reached that conclusion after meeting members of this Government. This Government has a minuscule vision of Australia's opportunities. Mr Hawke has a dwarfish view of what the possibilities are for himself, his government and the country. It is quite different from the view that was held by Malcolm Fraser and John Gorton, let alone Bob Menzies and even Mr Whitlam. They had a much wider vision of what this country should be.

This sort of thinking was shown in the way in which the Government opened the Brisbane Airport. I have never known a government in this country that plays politics so hard, that so selfishly keeps public events to its own friends and supporters. Not one Liberal from Queensland was asked to the opening of the airport. Mrs Tonia Cairns, the widow of the Hon. Kevin Cairns, the man who started off the whole airport movement, was not asked. I think that was an execrable display of bad taste. The only two Liberals who were asked were Mr Howard, Leader of the Opposition, and Mr Beale, the shadow Minister responsible for this area. I represented Mr Howard at the opening and Mr David Jull represented Mr Beale. Apart from that, there was no-one from any other political party at the opening, which was full of Australian Labor Party apparatchiks, their families and friends. It was most galling to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with his eyeballs rolling round the ceiling, looking at no-one, taking full praise for himself and his Government for the construction of this new airport-an airport which he and his Party have done everything to obstruct. Nevertheless we now have a very fine airport. It is by far and away the best airport in Australia and a major asset for the Australian community. Having made that investment, this Government has an obligation, however much it might try to avoid it, to maximise the airport for the benefit of all Australians.

The airport is suffering from a few problems. It has some major problems and some minor ones. The first major problem relates to the absence of a decent international terminal. An adequate international terminal was a fundamental part of the original design proposals for the airport. Every publication by the then department shows the international terminal side by side with the domestic terminal. At the moment a store shed designed by the previous Whitlam Government is being used as an international terminal at this $600m airport. If one can imagine a shed that Mr Charlie Jones, the former Minister for Aviation in the Whitlam Government, would design, one would have a pretty fair concept of what the international terminal is like at Brisbane Airport. It is totally inadequate.

One day recently five 747 aircraft were pulled up in front of the terminal. Another 747 and a DC10 were waiting to get onto the apron. Seven international aircraft were parked before this small shed. At least four direct flights a week from Japan bring in thousands of tourists. There are no covered walkways at the airport. Passengers get off their aircraft and move to this tiny little overcrowded shed. Despite the plans that are on the books to build the new international terminal, the Labor Party refuses to do anything until 1992. This is an absolute disgrace.

It is not only passengers who are inconvenienced by being packed into a totally inadequate facility for Customs, baggage and all the rest of it. There are also some big operational problems. The international terminal is not even on the airfield. That is how absurd the situation is. There is at least an-8 kilometre taxiway from the start of the runway to the international terminal. A fully loaded aircraft like a 747 takes a great deal of time to taxi that distance. Because these aircraft are taxied at no more than walking pace, maybe half an hour to three-quarters of an hour is lost by aircraft having to travel this distance. There is also a technical problem in terms of brake overheating. These aircraft are steered only by wheel braking and at low speeds the brakes cannot be cooled. Therefore, the handling of this type of aircraft in that very long taxiing situation is a real economic and technical penalty for the airlines. They do not like doing it, they do not want to do it and they should not have to do it.

In addition, the taxiway is a one-way street. Once an aircraft enters this very long taxiway of four to five kilometres, into the field beside the airport, the taxiway is immobilised for 20 minutes until the aircraft has turned off it. The amount of traffic is such that this creates a great deal of congestion. Of course, the taxpayer had to pick up the cost of building this four or five kilometres of high strength paved taxiway purely because the Government would not build a new terminal.

It does not matter if the Government does not have the money to build a new terminal. Queensland and Australian commercial interests have made many offers to build the terminal and to lease it to the Commonwealth. The design has been completed and the site preparation has been done during the construction of the airport. All that this Government needs to do is to get away from its ideological obsession of doing everything through the Public Service. Let private industry build the terminal. Let the Australian community get the benefit of it. All of the preparatory work has been done and the terminal could be built and in service within six to nine months.

The other major problem we have with this airfield relates to complaints about noise. I have been involved with the planning stages of this airport for well over a decade. The original submissions by the then Department of Aviation indicated that noise should not be a problem. But it is a problem. One of the reasons why it is a problem is that suburbs which had never experienced aircraft noise are now having aircraft flying over them. It is not so much a question of noise intensity but the fact that now people are hearing noise from aircraft which previously did not overfly them. This is because the airport is sited in a different place and the runway directions are different from what they were at the former airport.

Putting that aside, a considerable number of houses are being affected by aircraft approaching and departing. I raised this problem with departmental officers when they appeared before the relevant Estimates committee. I simply do not see why there should be a noise problem. Aircraft using runway 19 take off to the south. I do not see why aircraft which start at the threshold of that runway cannot make a left hand turn at 500 feet, clear the built-up areas entirely and go out over Moreton Bay. I do not see why that cannot be done. Aircraft are being sent straight ahead over the densely populated city of Brisbane residential areas. I see no air traffic control requirement for that to be so.

The other night I was on a flight to Rockhampton which took off on runway 19. We maintained the runway heading right over Morningside and Annerley. We eventually made a right turn over the central business district of Brisbane. I was sitting on the left side of the aircraft and when I looked down I saw Expo underneath us. I see no reason at all why those sorts of flight paths should be implemented. It is important to note that these flight paths are quite at variance with the flight plans that the then Department showed us during the construction stage of the airport. Aircraft taking off to the south have the option of making a left turn-there are about 50 to 100 houses in Pinkenba which would experience some noise level-keeping to the north of the river over an essentially industrial area with no residential population at all, and then going out over the bay. Alternatively, we could go back to the original proposal put up by the then Department eight to 10 years ago in the planning stage of the airport. Aircraft could make a slight left turn after lift-off and pass between the residential areas on the bay side of Wynnum-Manly and Lota and Seven Hills and Carina on the right and depart over the Leslie Harrison Dam where there is a corridor essentially free of residential build-up. But it is for the Department to correct that matter. I believe that there are solutions to it and I do not believe that the people of Brisbane should be subjected to the annoyance of the noise from the new airport. I rather suspect that some sort of warfare is going on between the air traffic controllers and the Department about the second tier wage negotiations, and I think the controllers see part of the battle as being fought by annoying the general public.

There are minor problems with the airport as well. They relate purely to the managerial incompetence of the Federal Airports Corporation. There are a lot of nitpicking bureaucratic problems such as the way Commonwealth cars are not allowed to wait at the kerbside for more than two minutes to pick up passengers. The only place at which Commonwealth cars or hire cars can wait is a car park a very long way from the terminal building. The Federal Airports Corporation's response to that was to put up a monitor in the car park, which for a long while showed only departures, which is useless for Commonwealth car drivers picking people up. The argument was that the Commonwealth drivers in the car park area could watch the television monitor to see the arriving flights, wait 10 minutes and then go to the terminal building. That simply does not work. As I said, the monitor was showing only departures instead of arrivals and even today it shows only one company-I cannot remember whether it is Ansett Airlines of Australia or Australian Airlines. The solution to the problem is very simple. It is quite possible to let drivers of Commonwealth cars hold on the other side of the kerb across from the terminal. My advice to the Government is to get rid of that Corporation before it creates further problems. It is just a monster which is spending money and making life increasingly difficult for anyone who has business in the airports over which it has control.

To return to the problem of the cars, it would be quite easy to have a pick up point on the other side of the kerb. When I put that proposition to the Federal Airports Corporation I received a letter telling me that it would be highly dangerous for us to walk across the roadway to pick up cars on the other side of the kerb. If it is highly dangerous, why does the Corporation allow the general public to cross that road to get across to the second road to get taxis or rental cars? It is absolute nonsense. There are other problems that can be resolved by a bit of goodwill and a bit of intelligence on the part of the Federal Airports Corporation.

The final point is that Brisbane now has the best airport in Australia. Geographically, it is located in the ideal site to be the entry point and the exit point for Australia. It should be Australia's prime international airport. We have made the financial investment and we have the facilities there. We need an international terminal and we need the Brisbane City Council and the Queensland State Government, which have been totally uninterested in this great asset on their doorstep, to get behind this facility and to develop it because there are great commercial opportunities for Australia and for Queensland in particular.

We need a change in mind on the part of this Government, instead of the blatant opposition to it and the statements from the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, that it is the greatest white elephant ever in Australia. A total opposition to doing anything constructive to make the airfield work is operating very much against the interests of all Australians. The condition of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, which is Australia's main entry point, is such that, with overcrowding, the lack of runway facilities and the argument over a new airport in Sydney, the problems in Sydney are insoluble inside 15 to 20 years. We have a developing tourist trade and we want to develop our international freight trade. The new airport in Brisbane is the place to do it. Let us get behind it and make it work, whatever views the Labor Party might have had about how it came about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills and the Supply Bills, I wish to comment on the economic situation facing Australia today and the outlook for the future. I will reserve some of my detailed comments on specific issues until the committee stage of our deliberations.
