SPEECH.PARA: I support the second reading motion amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) foreshadowed by my colleague Senator Stone, which seeks to add to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time the following notation by the Senate:
``, but the Senate notes:
(a) Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1185 million during March 1988;
(b) the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest levels in post-war Australia; and
(c) the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to our current economic difficulties''.

Senator Stone foreshadowed that amendment yesterday on behalf of the Opposition-but an hour or so before the April 1988 balance of payments figures were released. Those figures showed a significant improvement in the sense that the deficit figure for April was of the order of $396m compared with the much larger figure of over $1 billion for March, but there were some fortuitous factors concerning the April figure and I will come back to that later in my remarks.

The words of Senator Stone's amendment contain the essence of the Opposition's concerns about Australia's economic outlook and the reasons for those concerns. In a nutshell, we are concerned at the quite massive level of our foreign debt and the massive rate of increase in that debt which has occurred since Labor came to power. We are concerned at the totally inadequate and inappropriate policy responses by the Government to the debt build-up. Indeed, we are concerned that the Government does not even seem to be aware that its policies have been the major contributors to the debt problem. We want to stress the urgent need to reduce public sector spending as a whole if we are to be able even to make a start towards tackling the problems we face and to avail ourselves of the great opportunities which face us if we adopt the appropriate economic policies, both micro and macro.

Let me stress the latter point. It is often said that the Opposition simply talks negative gloom and doom about the economy. I refute that assertion very strongly indeed. The Opposition is not talking gloom and doom for the Australian economy-quite the contrary, we believe that there are enormous opportunities for sustainable long term growth and development in this nation. But that will occur only if we put our economic house in order. There is no point in standing Canute-like as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have been doing until very recently and saying that we have turned the corner, that a rosy future is assured. That is a cargo cult mentality. Indeed, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been guilty of an even more serious error. Until very recently they have been determinedly attempting to talk up the economy at the very time when there was a crying need for responsible leadership and debate on economic matters.

If one compares the Australian economy today with the economy that Labor inherited from the previous coalition Government in 1983, it is clear beyond any doubt that Australia is now a much less fair society. Under Labor, Australia is rapidly becoming a land of shattered dreams and abandoned hopes. Let me just give some examples. In Australia today there are 140,000 young Australians unemployed. There are 100,000 low income Australians who are condemned to interminable hospital waiting lists because of the Medicare debacle. We have 700,000 more Australians living below the poverty line-almost three-quarters of a million more-than five years ago. The total figure nowadays is about 2.7 million people living below the poverty line-700,000 more than when this Government took office.

Public housing waiting lists now exceed 150,000-and 40,000 Australians now live and sleep in the open or in refuges. We have had an increase in loan repayments as a proportion of average incomes to a level which has placed home ownership outside the reach of many Australians, especially young married couples. We had a fall last year in real household disposable income. That was the first fall in 30 years. Today, average wage earners are paying 40c tax on each dollar of additional income earned, compared with only 30c when Labor came to power. We have seen in the last five years a fall in the standard of living of virtually every Australian, particularly young couples with children. A two-parent single income family with two children, with the income earner on average weekly earnings, has suffered a $42 per week fall in that family's standard of living over the past five years. I could give numerous other examples but those I have given amply prove the point that for a vast number of Australians the past five years of Hawke Government policies have been accompanied by enormous hardship and a rapid march backwards in their living standards and in their legitimate expectations of a fairer and more prosperous society.

Perhaps Australians might have been prepared to accept these hardships if they could see long term benefits arising from their sacrifices over these last five long hard years, if they could see that the structure of the economy had been fundamentally changed in ways that would augur well for Australia's future, if they could point to a leaner, more efficient and less expensive government or more incentive through a lower tax regime, more competitiveness through increased productivity or a reduced stranglehold on the nation's fortunes by the trade union movement. But the Government can point to none of these things.

On the contrary, Australians can see a worsening of the fundamentals of our economy over the past five years. What they see is not more efficient and less expensive government but rather a government which in its first three years in office spent taxpayers' money as if it were confetti and which, over the past two years, has been forced to attempt to come to grips, so far with only limited success, with the excesses of its first three years. We have seen taxation inexorably rise to and remain at the highest level in our peace time history. So much for a restoration of incentives. We have seen the highest levels of interest rates in our history and we have experienced inflation at up to 10 times the levels of some of our major trading partners-generally three to four times the average of our major trading partners. We have seen the highest ever deficits in our balance of payments on current account and the largest ever drop in the external value of the Australian dollar.

We have seen Australia placed firmly into the hands of foreign creditors and financial markets as our foreign debt has accumulated at a terrifying rate, an accumulation which has almost quadrupled our debt in the past five years to a level where it now amounts to $6,700 for every man, woman and child in Australia. This financial year alone, our debt has increased by an average of $888m each month-although that is an improvement on last year when it increased by something like $1,000m each month. We have seen no improvement in our national productivity, the cornerstones of our future prosperity. Our productivity is appallingly low and shows no sign of improving under the policies of this Government.

Those are some of the very sober facts about our economic situation over the past five years. The overwhelming cause of those facts has been the inappropriate macro-economic policies of this Government. The extent to which the Government appears to be unaware of its role in producing this outcome is almost unbelievable. It is unaware of the failure of its policies, the extent of the dangers facing the economy and the tasks ahead of us. Only last week, the Treasurer was telling the Premiers Conference:

Since our last meeting very substantial progress has been made in our economic restructuring. The Australian economy today is clearly more internationally competitive, more responsive and more dynamic than at any time in our recent history. Together we have laid a firm foundation for sustainable economic growth well into the 1990s.
A little later in his speech, he said:
The easy thing for all of us today would be to take in the revenue benefits of the recovery in commodity prices and stronger economic activity and spend it.
This is the sort of short-sighted thing Australian governments have done in the past. He said subsequently:

We must press on with economic restructuring. This task is being tackled across a broad front. The Commonwealth's ongoing reform of structural policies is contributing toward making Australia permanently internationally competitive.

That, I say without any hesitation, is a complete and utter lie. There have been virtually no structural improvements of a macro-nature in the economy in the period of this Government and, as well, there have been precious few changes in the micro-economic restructuring. Indeed, the Government's chief advisory body, the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), in a paper it released last weekend, is reported to have said:

. . . excessive regulation, inefficient work and management practices, inadequate training and skills formation and a poor research and development effort all contributed significantly to the failure of some industries to expand exports and replace imports.
The report calls for co-ordinated micro-economic reforms on a broad front. It says that this should include:

a more flexible industrial relations system, a more skills oriented education system, greater labour mobility through retraining and multiskilling, removal of excessive regulation, reductions in industry protection and increased research and development.

Those are all matters that come within the preserve of government. This report of the Government's chief economic advisory body is saying to the Government, `You have not started to tackle the basic problems in the micro-economic area facing this country'. As Mr Ross Gittins, the economics editor for the Sydney Morning Herald, said on Monday, the day after that report was released:
By rights, we should have had a thorough public debate of the issues and the priorities, followed by a well-briefed Cabinet decision on the appropriate plan of attack.
He was talking about the micro-economic constraints on economic growth-which is the subject of the EPAC paper. Instead, Mr Gittins says:

. . . the issue of micro reform blew up during the election campaign after someone accused the Government of lacking a vision for its third term. No sooner had the Government been re-elected than Cabinet's newly-formed Structural Adjustment Committee began casting around hurriedly for decisions to announce in next week's mini-Budget.

Bob Hawke got a bee in his bonnet about privatisation, so that went on the list; John Dawkins wanted to get stuck into education; Paul Keating thought they had a political problem with corporate taxation; and someone thought of tariff reform. The priorities and the sequence seem to have been decided by Topsy. And once we've seen the mini-Budget we may decide that the pace has been determined by Nervous Nelly.

They are very accurate and damning comments about the approach of this Government to the formulation and priorities for reform and restructuring of the economy. It brings to mind very vividly the great thought that the Prime Minister gave to tax reform when, during an interview on a radio station in Perth during the 1984 election campaign, in response to a question that the interviewer asked him in relation to what he was going to do about tax reform, and pointing out that he should do something about it, the Prime Minister replied, `Yeah, that's a good idea, we'll have a summit'. That is how the tax summit came about-off the top of his head and shooting from the lip, in 1984. A similar thing occurred during the Adelaide by-election campaign this year, which cost the Government dearly, thankfully, when the Prime Minister, again shooting from the lip, said, `Yes, there will be timed telephone calls'. That is just a small example of the continuing shambles of economic policy making on the part of the Government.

What are our prospects in the period ahead? What policy directions do we need from the May statement next week and from the August Budget? The economy is overheated. I accept that the Treasurer acknowledged this in his speech made at the Premiers Conference last week. Growth in gross domestic product (GDP) has been much stronger in the current financial year than was forecast at the time of the Budget. It now seems that GDP growth in 1987-88 will be of the order of perhaps 3 1/2 per cent, compared to the Budget forecast of 2 3/4 per cent. In some respects that economic growth rate is no bad thing. Looking at it simplistically, without going any further, some people might say that it is a good thing, that higher growth is desirable. In particular it has assisted employment to grow at a higher rate than expected. But there are some very worrying aspects of this growth. The most worrying is that it has come from a growth in domestic demand rather than through the net contribution of the external sector. As it is the external sector that is our Achilles heel, this is a matter of very real concern.

On the external front there has been some improvement in our balance of payments on current account, but nowhere near enough. We are still going to run a current account deficit this year in the order of $10 billion. The Government trumpets that as a major improvement-because last year it was something like $14 billion. However, only five years ago we would have thought that a $10 billion deficit was absolutely unbelievable. The overheating of domestic demand has occurred as a result of a combination of factors. It has occurred as a result of less tight fiscal policy than was required in the circumstances, a loosening of monetary policy in the latter half of 1987, a questionable policy in relation to the exchange rate, a level of wage increase through the two-tier system in excess of what the economy could reasonably afford, and a rate of increase that bore no relationship at all to productivity movements in our economy.

The overheating has sucked in imports at a rate far too high for economic comfort. Added to this, the volume growth in imports has well exceeded the volume growth in exports. The unexpected rise in prices for our commodity exports has been the major contributing factor to the somewhat improved trend in our current account deficit. In Australian dollar terms, the index of commodity prices has risen by about 50 per cent over the past 18 months to two years. As the Treasurer himself pointed out to the Premiers last week:
This year net exports are forecast to make little, if any, contribution to GDP growth.

The current account deficit will fall as a percentage of GDP in 1987-88. However, virtually all of that fall, some one per cent of GDP, will be due entirely to the lift in commodity export prices, a lift which is entirely fortuitous so far as the Hawke Government's involvement is concerned. This is a precarious base for future economic policy formulation. World economic activity and the level of international trade have been relatively buoyant over the past year, although performances have differed considerably from one nation to another. As to what has been said by commentators on this matter, I shall just take one example. The Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd in its latest issue of Business Indicators pointed out:

It is now clear that the world economy had greater underlying momentum than was thought at the time of the October stockmarket crash. This momentum is likely to sustain world activity well into 1988. Beyond that, a pronounced slowdown is expected as the USA is forced to reduce its trade deficit and debt build-up.

What is being pointed out there is that the major and fundamental imbalances which precipitated last October's stockmarket crash still exist. The enormous United States trade deficit continues. The surpluses of the new industrial giants, like Taiwan and Korea, are continuing. Japan's trade surplus is still huge, although easing somewhat. But sooner or later-and quite possibly sooner-steps will be taken to correct these fundamental imbalances. The most likely candidate is the United States of America, once the US presidential election is out of the way. This could well signal a rise in US and, therefore, worldwide interest rates, a slow-down in economic growth in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) nations and elsewhere, leading to a fallback in world trade and a consequential collapse in commodity prices.

In that event, Australia would face an enormous problem. That problem could mean a dramatic fall in our export income at a time when we are still importing at a high level as a result of an overheated economy and facing mounting internal cost and price pressures. Those increasing cost and price pressures are there at the moment for all to see. The crunch that would inevitably follow would be very severe indeed. It is this scenario that the Government must keep uppermost in mind when framing next week's May statement and the August Budget.

The scenario demands several major policy responses. The first, and overriding requirement, is for a significant reduction in government spending. It will not be sufficient simply to budget for a surplus. The Government has cash running out of its ears at the moment as fiscal drag takes its toll of wage and salary earners and as the unsustainable overheating of the economy brings short term revenue benefits for the Government's coffers.

It would appear that without any policy changes the Federal Government's Budget surplus in 1988-89 could be of the order of $2 billion to $3 billion. If that is the case, the Government should certainly be going for a surplus well in excess of that figure, to be achieved by a further reduction in its own spending, because it is only in this way that the Government can deliver on the three most important requirements facing us over the period ahead. These three requirements are: Firstly, a slowing down of domestic demand; secondly, a strengthening of our external account; and thirdly, the restoration of incentive through a meaningful and sustainable reduction in the overall tax burden. In this latter context, I must say that, if I were in business in Australia, I would not be holding my breath awaiting the outcome of the Government's review of business taxation. The Treasurer has said that any changes will be revenue neutral. Therefore, the business sector as a whole will be no better off. There is little merit in shuffling the tax pack if one finishes up with the same size pack.

The May statement and the Budget must not only tighten fiscal policy they must also tighten monetary policy. It is true that monetary policy has tightened somewhat in the past two to three months, but essentially this has been simply a long overdue correction to a far too permissive approach by the authorities in 1987. The Government must also get serious about its much vaunted restructuring. As I said earlier, when one casts aside the rhetoric there has been precious little restructuring. The Government must make a meaningful start on deregulation, and on improving competition and efficient resource usage through a carefully planned program of privatisation, through encouraging a more flexible union structure based increasingly on enterprise unions rather than taking the opposite line that it is pursuing in its current industrial relations legislation, and through taking other positive measures to lift our appallingly low level of productivity. I am not at all optimistic that the Government will tackle any of these requirements. Many of them involve firm, tough decisions. Despite the rhetoric, the hype and the media massaging, the fact is that this Government time and again has backed away from the correct and necessary macro and micro policy decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are confusing us with the Fraser Government.

—If the Government once again fails in its responsibility-and seeing Senator Cook on the front bench makes me less than confident that it will do otherwise-it will stand condemned for failing to create the environment which can so readily be created with leadership and determination and which will enable Australia and Australians to grasp the wonderful opportunities that could exist for growth and development and rising living standards in an increasingly competitive world, a world in which we have to live and compete if we intend to grow and to benefit our people.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government fails in these responsibilities, the economic and social consequences for Australia will be enormous. The one possible consolation would be that the political consequences for the Australian Labor Party would also be enormous, because until we get rid of this Government and we have a government that will take firm, responsible and leadership decisions on the fundamental issues of economic policy, direction and thrust, our nation will continue to suffer the hardship it has experienced over the last five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this cognate debate on the Appropriation and Supply Bills, I intend to address my preliminary remarks to the question arising from the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee A, and indeed address particularly the reasons why the Opposition senators who are members of that Committee chose to publish a dissenting report, technically termed a reservation. It is important to place on the record that, unless the Estimates committees are taken seriously and the information ascertained is made public, and attention is drawn to it and it is acted on, we could be described as not sensibly spending our time in those committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the most significant areas dealt with by Estimates Committee A involved the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Department of Industrial Relations, and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I was greatly concerned when, after spending many hours and addressing many important questions, we received a report that virtually said, `We came, we sat, we went'. Whether or not that has been the practice over many years, I can find no compelling argument to continue it. I believe it is important that many of the matters raised be placed on the record so that they can be read by people interested in them. I will touch on only a few of the matters in the report, but I would like also to bring to the attention of the Senate other matters that were also raised before the Committee.

One of the items in the dissenting report relates to a memorandum published by Mr Terry Hilsberg, who was then the First Assistant Secretary of the Technology and Business Efficiency Division of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. On 22 July 1987, he sent to all staff members in the Industry, Research and Development Branch a memo that stated:

I am writing to express my thanks for the excellent work you have performed during the past year. In particular, I would like to commend you for achieving that important goal of exhausting moneys allocated to the IR and D Branch during the 1986-87 financial year.
I am sure your efforts in the coming year will prove to be equally successful.

Opposition members of Estimates Committee A have simply pointed out that in our view the aim of exhausting moneys allocated can never be a justifiable goal for any government department. The sooner we see accrual accounting for government departments, the happier we will be.

The second matter I raise is also touched on in the dissenting report. I refer to the question of partnerships in development. Of course, this matter is part of the gradual development of the civil offsets program which, in turn, originally arose from military or defence offsets and which began life as corporate citizenship. Reasons were not given at the Committee hearings for the change in title from `corporate citizenship' to `partnership in development'. One could not help feeling that some sort of cosmetic manoeuvre was being made to attempt to get the offsets program viewed in a better light, because serious concern is abroad that the Government is not serious in ensuring that overseas corporations that give undertakings pursuant to the offsets program are meant to fulfil them. Many such unfulfilled undertakings are currently outstanding. No messages or signals are being sent by the Government that it is serious about enforcing those undertakings.

A further matter raised in the dissenting report related to Kirribilli House. I heard Senator Michael Baume refer to much of the extravagance that has taken place as part of the so-called updating, renovation and interior decoration at Kirribilli House. The report makes the point that the reason given for the so-called urgent renovations costing a total of three-quarters of a million dollars was that they were needed to make the residence suitable for the accommodation of guests of government, particularly during the Bicentenary. Evidence showed that it could well be that the expenditure was merely to make Kirribilli House a pleasant second residence for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

If it were true that the refurbishment was designed to make it a suitable residence for visiting guests of government, as has been the previous function of Kirribilli House, it could well be that the sort of money that has been expended is warranted. If, on the other hand, it is merely to be a second residence and it needed tarting up, then expenditure of three-quarters of a million dollars is clearly not warranted. During the Estimate Committee hearing, I asked whether I could have a list of the people who had stayed at Kirribilli House during the last decade. I asked whether any people had stayed at Kirribilli House recently or whether it had been used merely by the Prime Minister. I have received answers to those questions.

During the period from 1978 to 1983, when Mr Fraser was the Prime Minister, an average of just over one person a month stayed at Kirribilli House. These people ranged from the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester to the Prime Minister of Western Samoa, the Governor-General of the Solomon Islands and the like. This Government came to office in 1983 and the sole guest in that year was the Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands. In 1984-85 the Foreign Minister of Somalia, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Perez de Cuellar, and the Minister for Agriculture of Vietnam were the sole guests. During 1985-86 the Secretary of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the Minister for Foreign Affairs from Madagasca were guests. During 1986-87 and 1987-88 apart from the Prime Minister there were no guests at all. While Mr Fraser was Prime Minister an average of 13 guests a year stayed at Kirribilli House; in the six years that Mr Hawke has been the Prime Minister, six people have stayed-that is, an average of one a year.

It is justified to bring this expenditure to the attention of the Senate and, indeed, to the attention of people further afield because there are still more questions which need to be asked. For instance, Mr Spode, who was appointed the interior decorator to oversight the decoration of the rooms, was asked to give quotes to decorate the formal rooms, the bathrooms, the kitchens and the bedrooms. I intend to seek further information as to the expenditure on materials such as curtains, furnishings, carpets and the like to see whether ordinary Australians who are struggling to decorate their own homes are in any way perturbed about the degree of money being spent not for guests of government, such as visiting heads of state, but simply for a second residence for the Prime Minister.

The final matter that was raised in the report relates to the Department of Industrial Relations. It was a very serious matter which dealt with money which was paid in settlement of claims for compensation for industrial action taken by Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) members during the period of the deregistration hearings. The concern was not that the Government had taken the sensible attitude and moved to make payments to employers who had suffered at the hands of the BLF members, but that the Department had not taken any action at all to recover that money from the BLF funds which, as we all know by reading the Press, are quite substantial. Indeed, the whereabouts of those funds could be said to be in some doubt. It was only after fairly vigorous questioning that the Department, in answer to the questions at the hearings and subsequently in written responses, said that it would investigate methods by which that money may be refunded to the Department so that the taxpayer does not have to pick up the bill for the behaviour of BLF members.

As well as those matters which are in the report, there are several others which I would like to raise. The first of those is Austrade and the relationship that we have-or rather, do not have-with our sixth major trading partner; that is, Taiwan or its capital Taipei. During the hearings I specifically asked what would happen if I were a businessman who wanted to further my exports and do business in Taiwan, which is, as I said, our sixth largest trading partner. What assistance could be expected from Austrade? I was told that there was no Austrade office in Taipei and that I would have to do business through the Australian Chamber of Commerce in that city. However, the Department would be prepared to give export assistance of one kind or another. I quote the answer of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button):

Assistance of a financial kind may be available. There may be a capacity for advice in Australia which Austrade would give. For a businessperson going to Taipei, their business in Taiwan would be handled through the Australian Chamber of Commerce.

We addressed the question of the difficulty of the relationship between Taipei and the People's Republic of China. I pointed out that there were many examples where accommodations had been worked out. Indeed, other nations seemed to have solved their problems in a much more efficacious manner than we have here.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I want to raise a number of issues but particularly the question of the proposed Australian Capital Territory (ACT) casino. I want to discuss the manner in which decisions are made in the ACT. The casino is a very good example to use to highlight some of the problems facing residents of the ACT under the rule of this Government. We had a situation where Minister Brown-now former Minister Brown-decided it would be appropriate if the ACT had a casino. Consultants' studies were set up. Minister Brown exited stage left and Minister Punch took over. Minister Punch endorsed the proposal to have a casino in the Territory. There was substantial concern in the community about the proposal to redevelop section 19 of Civic, and in particular about placing a casino there. A social impact study was set up, although we have to wonder why because the Minister said that it did not matter what the social impact study came up with, what concerns it raised, as the ACT would have a casino.

SPEECH.PARA: But, of course, we have seen since then something of a shift by the Minister. He has now said, well, maybe not. He says some doubt has been cast over this proposal, and he has chosen to cast that doubt by saying that this whole proposal for the redevelopment of section 19 might fall apart because there is not bipartisan support for it, and if only the Liberal Party would make up its mind what it wanted to do he could proceed. The Minister would be able to proceed. We have Senator McMullan, a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, saying that perhaps this is a matter best left until self-government comes. That is what has happened, and I suggest that what we are seeing is classic Labor right wing politics-this is what the people are going to have whether they like it or not and the bully boys are going to come around and push them into it. We are not going to be a part of that.

Minister Punch's politics might be described quite fairly as punk politics, but that is not the way this chamber operates and that is not the way the coalition parties will operate. He may be a former mayor who has read some Boys Own Annual and decided that daring feats of bravado are the way to get his way.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might be punch drunk.

—As my colleague says, he might be punch drunk on the power proposal. Nonetheless, if he believes that bravado and brawn are what will get the section 19 redevelopment off the ground he is very sadly mistaken. This is not some kids sandpit where we can sit around and decide we would like to build a castle and Minister Punch wants to build a casino. It is just not that simple. It is much more complicated than that. So let us look at how much Minister Punch wanted this proposal to proceed. There has been not one approach to me by the Government, by either Minister Brown or Minister Punch, or their respective offices, in favour of this proposal-not one piece of paper offered in favour of this proposal. So, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you were the Minister and you believed in an idea and thought it was good for the ACT you would push it and you would push it by putting out a decent, well put together proposal so that your opposition could say yea or nay. You would not simply put out a Press release and hope for the best, keep putting out the old Press release about how good the casino and section 19 redevelopment would be; you would put together a proper proposal. As a result of my approach to the current Minister's office, Senator Reid and I had a meeting with someone from the Minister's office and someone from the ACT Administration. They had the temerity to come in and say, basically, to put it in colloquial language, `There you are, dears, it will all be okay; there is going to be plenty of money from this and it will be wonderful because it will provide revenue for the ACT'. So when Senator Reid and I, ignoring the somewhat paternalistic approach of the two gentlemen, said, `Thank you very much, we would like to read the financial report', they replied, `Oh, we do not know that you can have that'. It is a joke to expect coalition parties in a Federal parliament to endorse a proposal when they do not have the material before them. It did not take very long, of course, for the relevant people to accept that in the end we would have to have the details of the proposal. So, a week later, we did get a copy of the Jedd report, which details some financial plans for the casino.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had nothing since. All we have had coming to see us is lobby groups which have been told by the Minister, `It is the lousy Liberal and National parties that are blocking this development; go and give them a push'. One can imagine the look on their faces when we tell them what I have just told you, Mr Acting Deputy President, namely that the Minister has not made one effort to push this proposal with us at all-not a piece of paper. They are very surprised. They say, `Why would he not be pushing it?'. Of course I am not a psychiatrist, I cannot say what is in the Minister's mind at all. But I can say that he is big on talking in the paper and very short on producing facts that we can make an assessment on and give him an answer. We are quite happy to do that but we are not happy to go bit by bit, fiddling about. No other Minister, basically, asks for support, for example, for division 1 of a Bill, comes back a couple of weeks later and asks for support for division 2 of the Bill and, perhaps a month or so later, asks for support for divisions 3 and 4. Not at all. Most Ministers understand that if they want to get a package through they have to put the whole package before the people so they can see what they are going in for.

The Minister must understand that there has been concern not only in the ACT community but in any community where a casino has been established about the selection of an operator. There has certainly been concern raised in this chamber about the capacity of interdepartmental committees to select the appropriate tender application. So we are obligated to have that information before us before we consider the proposal. How would we select an operator? How would we run the casino? What controls would the Commonwealth have? We have heard nothing from the Minister on this; just dead silence. The Minister is clearly, in my view, trying to back off from this proposal. He has got his feet too far in the water and he wants to get out. But he wants to blame someone else and he is trying to say that the proposal is being blocked by the Liberal and National parties, by the coalition. That is a big load of rubbish because there is no proposal before us. There are a few Press releases and, sure, there is information gained under the freedom of information legislation, but nothing from the Minister-no concrete proposal about what he wants to do. If the Minister does not have the capacity to put the proposal forward he should give the job to someone else.

The question I pose to the Minister is: Does the Minister have a formal proposal for the coalition to consider with respect to the section 19 development and, in particular, the proposed casino? Does the proposal include details of how the operator will be selected and how the casino will be controlled? Until he does that he may as well stop talking to the media and stop getting lobby groups to come and try to pressure us because all we are doing is turning those people back on to the Minister. Of course this is causing uncertainty in the community. People who work in the building industry naturally want to know if this development will go ahead. Those employed on the new Parliament House site might be deciding that they would like to stay in the ACT if there were jobs. So this will be important to them. We would like to be in a position to give a yea or a nay. But we cannot do that because the Minister has not given us a proposal.

Private enterprise in the ACT, the Canberra Association for Regional Development, just about any group in the ACT, all want an answer. But the Minister has not posed the question. We are still back at the sandpit and he is saying, `Let's build a casino'. We do not have the details of any substantive proposal that will enable us to give a response. That is one example of how decisions are made in the ACT. They are made, as I say, with a typical New South Wales right wing Labor Party `You are going to have it come what may and we will sort out all the details later', and everybody is expected to fall into line. The Minister might now be finding that the Australian Democrats and the coalition are not prepared to fall into line on this or indeed any other issue, and that he will have to come forward with a proper proposal before he gets an answer.

My colleague Senator Reid will be speaking in this debate shortly. She will raise another example of how decisions are made in the ACT-an appalling example, if I may say so. It relates to the closure of the Page primary school. The only thing that I want to say about that is that when residents of the ACT, dissatisfied with that decision, indicated they were going to put in a freedom of information application to make some assessment of how the Government came to this decision, what were they told by the relevant public servants? I read this in the paper; I am not relying on what I have been told. They were told they would not get much out of it because there is not really a very good file on it; not much information there. That, of course, begs the question: Did the ACT Administration, in this respect the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, base its decision on information in an assortment of files and not bring that information together into one file particularly so that ACT residents would not be able to see the basis on which the decision was made, or was the decision made in a smoke-filled back room over a couple of drinks or perhaps over a cup of tea? Is this decision one that has been made at the whim of the Schools Authority? Certainly the response these residents were given following their indication that they were going to put in a freedom of information application indicates a gigantic reluctance on behalf of the public servants involved to have their decision put under scrutiny. Senator Reid, who will be speaking in this debate shortly, will outline the disastrous situation in relation to the closure of the Page primary school and I look forward to listening to what she has to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, as indicated I want to talk about the closure of the Page primary school. Late last year a document was produced by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority entitled Community Schools for Canberra, 1989 to the year 2000, with the subtitle, `A draft plan for matching school accommodation with student numbers?' This plan indicated that some 16 primary schools and one high school would be closed, but that eight new consolidated primary schools would open in, of course, eight of the existing buildings. This caused quite a reaction in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of the release of the draft plan the Schools Authority indicated that parents, schools and others who had an interest would have the opportunity to respond to the proposals and they were given until the end of March of 1988 to do so. Many people recognised that it was necessary to close some schools, and certainly necessary to cut costs. There has been a difference of opinion as to how this might be done. Some are totally opposed to any closures. My view was that it was likely that some would close but I want to refer specifically to one of those schools. My office received a large number of submissions from parents who were concerned about what was happening, and parent organisations made submissions to me and to the Schools Authority. Some of the schools and communities mounted very vigorous campaigns; others were less vocal about the closures. But at the time of the announcement there was also a pamphlet printed entitled Planning Schools for Canberra's Future, and I want to read a part of that pamphlet headed `Why should parents be involved?'. It states:

Participation is a key element of the public education system. To ensure that the best possible decisions are made it is very important for parents to be closely involved in examining the draft plan and preparing responses from their schools. Later it will be just as important for parents to be involved to ensure that new schools meet the needs of the new community.

They are very laudable aims, but are they able to be carried out? The parents and schools in the south Belconnen community and in the rest of Canberra took that statement quite seriously and, as I have indicated, did put in a number of submissions in response. The schools targeted for closure prepared submissions and the schools which were to remain open commenced doing what they were required to do, that is, indicate their plans to deal with the new arrangements. Five schools in the south Belconnen area were affected. Macquarie and Scullin were to be closed and new amalgamated schools were to be created at Cook, Weetangera and Page. The parents at Macquarie and Scullin were, quite understandably, involved in mounting campaigns to keep their schools open and, as I have indicated, there were in all 250 submissions made to the Authority.

There was some criticism about the way the Authority handled that aspect of the matter but eventually, on 6 May, a further report, Community Schools for Canberra, 1989 to the year 2000, with the subtitle `A final Report', was released by the Minister for Arts and Territories (Mr Punch). It indicated that some of the schools previously targeted for closure would remain open but the bombshell of the final report was that one of the schools, which had never been targeted for closure or in any way put under threat, and which in fact was preparing for its future as an amalgamated school, was then told it would close. That school was the Page primary school. One might think that there was some conflict between the interests of Page and Scullin, but that need not have been the case. I believe there was a very good reason for the Scullin school remaining open but it never entered my head that it would remain open at the expense of Page.

Page was given no warning. The parents at Page had not had the opportunity to participate and respond, as the pamphlet advised. They were a school which had been told to prepare for the enlarged enrolment that it would expect. It now would seem, the way this proposal is presented, to be a final report, that Page's closure is a fait accompli. The parents have not had the opportunity to take part in the discussions. What, I ask, has Page done to be treated in this way? There are two significant issues. Why was Page misled, why were the parents of that community misled by the Schools Authority, and on what basis was the decision to close the school made?

The initial report I have referred to, which came out last year, set the criteria for the closure of schools, and that draft report at paragraph 1.2.5. shows the suburbs of the Belconnen areas with circles with a 1.2 kilometre radius drawn around the primary schools. The radius was chosen by the Authority as it was felt it represented a reasonable walking distance for primary school children. It looked at the circles it had drawn and found that some suburbs which had their own schools came completely within the area of circles drawn from other suburb schools. Scullin in fact was one of them. As I indicated, I have no quarrel with the decision to leave Scullin open, and on the ground of the safety of children alone that should be the case. That safety aspect should be applied to the Page closure as well. The Authority has said that Scullin is to stay open because in the initial draft it had not included part of Florey as a priority enrolment area for Scullin, but that that now has been included. South-west Florey has been included in its priority enrolment area, which means that within this context Scullin does become more centrally located.

The question is: Why is Page closing? By the Authority's own criteria, Page would be the last school that one would have expected to close. Certainly there are others nearby that one would have expected to close. Forty per cent of the suburb of Page falls outside the 2.2-kilometre radius of any other school. The distance the Page children living in this part of the suburb will have to travel to attend Scullin, the school they are told they will now have to go to, is between two and 2.5 kilometres, meaning that they will have to be bussed. The school presently has 237 children, 67 from Florey, but there is no indication that those children will attend the new Florey school. Their parents may well want them, for continuity, to stay where they are. There are 102 children either at Page now or at the preschool in that area which falls outside the 1.2-kilometre radius from Scullin.

There are also in the Page area a large number of service families. There are 42 Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) houses, and a number of other service people rent in that area. They are likely to want to leave that area so they can live nearer a school. It would be strange for the RAAF to continue to have houses in an area where there is no school that the children can go to easily. There are enough problems for service families shifting around as it is without this happening to them. That is an issue which ought to be looked at by the Government when action has been taken in the way that it has been in this case.

The other matter that needs to be reviewed as far as Page is concerned is the numbers. Many of those service houses were closed for renovation and the like when the survey of numbers was undertaken by the Schools Authority in 1986. They are now occupied and presumably will continue to be occupied, so on that ground alone the matter ought to be reviewed.

What in fact is to become of the suburb of Page? Is it the Government's intention, or the intention of the National Capital Development Commission, that Page will become a retirement suburb? Part of it, in one area, already is. Is it a fact that it will not have a school, and that the sorts of facilities that will make it a suburb nice to retire in will be put in? These are the sorts of decisions that ought to be made known.

The matter of the freedom of information inquiry has already been referred to by Senator Vanstone. When parents from Page asked to see the documentation they were told that there was no point in applying, that there was not any. If this decision has been made without there being any documentation, just merely by tossing a coin or by saying `We have had a lot of lobbying from Scullin, we had better leave it open; we will close Page', it is a disgrace. The residents of Page are angry at the way in which they have been treated by the Authority and want to see the documentation on which the reversal of the decision to allow the Page primary school to remain open has been based.

It is hard to believe that this action has been taken in the way that it appears to have been taken. It is a high-handed action; it is thoroughly unprincipled. I think the whole exercise of school closures now lacks integrity. The Minister should tell the Authority that the present plan for closures in this area is to be abandoned and that the whole process should be started again. It may be that in the future Page will still be the school that closes, though I would think not if the criteria that the Authority adopted initially were applied properly, but at least the parents of Page would have the opportunity to present a point of view and not be left out in the cold and treated as they have been with this high-handed, unprincipled action that has taken place. They have been treated shabbily. It was interesting that, when the Minister released the final report, he said, in part:
The fact that the Government's decisions differ from the published draft plan is proof, if it were needed, that the consultation process was genuine.

No, Minister, it was not genuine. Certainly the Authority has fiddled with the original plan to some extent, but when we look at the way the citizens of Page have been treated we can see it has not been genuine. One can only draw conclusions as to how this came about. I repeat, for the benefit of the Minister, that if the Schools Authority is to have any credibility this part of the plan at least must be abandoned and a totally fresh approach taken to the whole of this area. We have three schools just about within walking distance of each other in one area, and now this school in another area is being closed. The only crime Page seems to have committed is to vote strongly Labor throughout. Perhaps that is the reason nobody bothers to care about them or feel that they matter in any way. I regard this decision as an absolute disgrace and I hope that the Minister will respond promptly to set right a grave injustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a matter of public interest which concerns the behaviour of one of the Ministers in the Federal Labor Government; namely, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson.
—It could be anyone.

—It could be anyone. Sadly this case is very serious. I believe honourable senators will find the Minister's behaviour just as unacceptable as I do. I am absolutely appalled at an article which appeared in today's Launceston Examiner. Very similar reports also appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Melbourne Age. The Examiner article is headed `Minister incites greenies'. That refers to a launching yesterday, by the Minister, of a wilderness inventory report at the Australian Heritage Commission. I am quoting the Examiner but I have checked with the other newspapers and the reports are very substantially the same, so I do not think there will be any question of my being unfair to the Minister with the quotations that I use from the story. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The `voice of the people' would be the deciding factor in influencing Federal Government decisions on conservation and wilderness, the Environment Minister, Senator Richardson said yesterday.
It further states:
. . . Senator Richardson said that the Government could not act unless the voice of the people was heard.
Then he is reported as follows:
`I am listening, but so far the roar isn't deafening', he told conservationists and heritage activists in Canberra. `When it is, then I am sure we can take the action you all want'.
I quote again:
. . . I hope that those environment groups who are represented here, and those of you from the Government, will . . . make sure that in the next 12 months the voice of the people is heard.

What voice of the people does this Minister want? Does he want the voice of the greenies? I would imagine that is what he is on about. Does he want the voice of the workers? I would have thought his party would expect him to be listening to the voice of the workers. He clearly says that he wants the voice of government employees. It seems to me that is rather an open admission of the fact that the Government has increasingly politicised the Federal Public Service. What about the voice of the States in a federal system? I would have thought that he should have been listening to those too, quite apart from the voice of the industry concerned.

I would also like to ask the Minister: In just what way is the voice of the people to be heard? How are we to judge how the people's voice is coming to the Government? Does he intend it to be received through violence or blood in the streets? Does he intend to receive the voice of the people through a media campaign-a campaign by the conservationists but no doubt funded by the Federal Government, as we have seen in the past? When calling on government employees was he expecting them to use their privileged position to undermine the decision of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, which was, I remind the Senate, set up and paid for by the Federal Government? Will he judge the voice of the people by the number of banners that are draped round trees, by the number of streets that are blockaded throughout Australia or by the number of letters to the newspapers? How will he judge the voice of the people? How is he going to assess that roar? I think that the Minister has very conveniently forgotten that the voice of the people has been expressed very clearly in far north Queensland over recent months.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in the New South Wales State elections.

—And in the New South Wales State elections; Senator Puplick is quite right. The Minister chooses very selectively to hear the voice of the people. I am afraid that he does not show much respect when he goes out selectively to receive the voice of the people. What worries me is not just that the Minister is on the record as saying that he wants to hear the voice of the people but that he is actually inciting them to provide a roar which will help him to undo the report of the Helsham Commission. He will undermine his Government in the process and I fear that he may incite unbalanced people to violent action. Look at the Press release which was put out on 17 May by the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook. I am sorry he is not here now; he may have been able to contribute. He commented on the Helsham report, saying that the tabling of the report opened the way for substantial and comprehensive discussions with the Tasmanian Government on the management of the Tasmanian forests. He went on at some length about what would happen post-Helsham, referring to action to deal positively with the Tasmanian forests now that the decision has been made. We also know that Minister Kerin is of like mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder what is going to be the situation in this Federal Labor Ministry when Senator Richardson and all his hordes of roaring voices are stood against the voices of Ministers Kerin and Cook. What will be the weight of opinion then? I remind honourable senators that in the debate this week Senator Puplick, our shadow spokesman, said:

The Government is now on the horns of a dilemma which it has created. The Government established this commission of inquiry for a particular purpose; it gave its guidelines and rules, supplied the resources, and selected the three commissioners. At the end of the day the commissioners have made a series of recommendations that the Government did not want to hear.
Certainly Senator Richardson clearly did not want to hear them. Senator Puplick continued:
The question will now be: What is the integrity of the Government in relation to the recommendations put before it?

All the people who wanted to give evidence to that Commission did so. It had expert advice. It had a lot of professional assistance. It had a Supreme Court judge as its chairman. It made significant judgments on the claims. Now that the Commission has reported, we expect the Government to implement its decisions and recommendations. I support absolutely what Senator Puplick said. Clearly the Government is going to have this battle ahead of it within the Ministry, and we recognise that frequently in governments Ministers have different views. I believe that a quite different matter, and very serious one, is seen in the Press today, where we read of a Federal Minister going out inciting people to unspecified but strong action to support his case and to enable him to toss a report which has been made with all the due process that one could possibly expect, and paid for by the taxpayer. This Government, this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), should condemn the Minister for his behaviour. The Government has to accept the umpire's decision, and Senator Richardson should be disciplined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention today to two matters that have become known to honourable senators. One is the annual report for 1987-88 of the Australian Finance Conference, which all honourable senators would have received in their mail today. I would like to link it with a Press report that has been distributed through the Australian Associated Press (AAP) wire. That report refers to an academic who says that car dealers take advantage of Aborigines in Arnhem Land. I quote from the AAP report:

SPEECH.PARA: Unscrupulous car dealers have taken advantage of primitive Arnhem Land Aborigines, according to a Melbourne academic.
Some of the Aborigines who had bought cars under loan agreements now owed up to $20,000 each with no way of paying their debts.
`Sometimes these dealers resort to terrible scare tactics to intimidate them,' La Trobe University genetics research Dr Neville White said.
`Many are being hounded by finance agencies after falling behind in payments of loans provided with little or no collateral.'

I have taken the time to look in detail at the report by Dr Neville White, which is a feature article in the autumn edition of the magazine Record produced by La Trobe University. Dr Neville White certainly highlights a number of social and economic problems of Aboriginals based on his experiences in Arnhem Land. He concentrates on matters right across the gamut-problems in employment, problems in health issues and problems in economic areas. Whilst he certainly drew attention to instances where car dealers had entered into unsavoury financial arrangements with Aborigines, I believe that today's Press report on his article takes this out of the context in which it should be properly addressed. It is rather sensational to use adjectives like `unscrupulous' car dealers and `primitive' Arnhem Land Aborigines or to speak of Aborigines being `hounded' by finance agencies. To give the article that sort of connotation I think is to concentrate this issue far too narrowly, albeit on the real problems.

I am not denying for one moment that we ought to be properly looking at the problems of Aborigines. But Aborigines do live in the twentieth century; they do have access to excellent education facilities, whether or not those education facilities are provided by government and whether or not they are received through television or other means of communication. But what we need to concentrate on, of course, is the fact that education needs to be appropriate to the needs of any particular community no matter where in Australia it is. It is an historical fact that Aborigines live in Arnhem Land. Denigrating them by describing them all as primitive is just not satisfactory and, similarly, suggesting that all car dealers are unscrupulous or that all finance companies hound their customers I think also adds to the problem. We need to look very carefully at the way in which consumerism is embraced in our community. The report of the Australian Finance Conference brings to our attention many of the important rules that ought to be accepted and abided by all consumers. With the leave of the Senate I will incorporate one of the chapters from the report of the Australian Finance Conference's credit advisory service which contains basically the golden rules applying to the seeking of credit. I seek leave to incorporate that document.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOLDEN RULES

Used wisely consumer credit can be of great assistance to you. Used without care, it can result in more cares than you would want to worry about. Follow the Golden Rules of Consumer Credit and your credit cares will be kept to a minimum.
DO
Remember that credit costs money; shop around for it as you would for goods.
Make sure that the goods which you are wishing to finance are what you need.
Before you apply for a loan review your total financial position to work out how much you can afford to repay.
After you have obtained finance follow the disciplines of effective money management and budgeting.
Pay the highest possible deposit so that you will have a worthwhile equity in the goods; this will result in lower repayments without leaving you too short of funds.
Carefully examine the goods to make sure that they are in good order and will meet the purposes for which you want them.
Consider the additional costs of the items you buy (e.g. annual car registration, insurance and other service and running costs) and make sure you budget for them.
Contact the credit provider immediately you look like getting into repayment difficulties.
Carefully consider all of the terms and conditions in the credit contract; do not be afraid to ask for an explanation.
If you do not fully understand the contract seek independent advice.
Think carefully before you take on the responsibility of a guarantor.

Make sure you are comparing like with like when shopping around for credit: ask for the amount of regular repayment, the annual percentage rate and whether any establishment, joining or like fees are required.
Understand how interest is charged in the contract and what happens if you pay-out early or make extra repayments.
Remember that you are entering a contract-contracts are serious business.
Make sure to keep your copy of the contract and file this along with other related documents and correspondence in a safe place.
When filling in an application form answer the questions asked honestly and accurately; this avoids embarrassment of being found out if aspects are false and reduces the risk of overcommitment.
Take great care with your credit history-it is an asset and should be well looked after.
DO NOT
Do not sign a blank form or a form that you do not understand.
Do not mislead the credit provider by incorrectly completing the application form.
Do not borrow without knowing your current and likely future financial position.
Do not borrow the deposit.
Do not confuse the different types of interest rates; do not compare a flat rate with an annual percentage rate.
Do not just buy something because you can get it on credit or because the deposit or repayments are small.
Do not be rushed into signing a contract.
Do not sign as a guarantor without carefully thinking about the responsibility that you are taking on.
Do not forget that you have rights and responsibilities-make sure that you are an informed consumer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. If we look carefully at the do's and don'ts of the golden rules of consumerism we can see there are certainly many lessons to be learnt by many people, whether they are Aboriginal or not. We need to remind ourselves that sales of vehicles to Aborigines are not limited to Aborigines in Arnhem Land. Aborigines live in all urban communities and in many other remote parts of Australia. They need to have access to vehicles. There is certainly no public transport in many of the Aboriginal communities that I am aware of, and therefore there is a very heavy reliance on vehicles. Certainly the Aboriginals of Arnhem Land do need to have access to both used car sales and new car sales facilities, according to their economic circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to be reminded that Aboriginals, as a consuming group, do not just walk into a car yard one by one and try to negotiate a sale. They usually make these types of decisions in collaboration with their families and their broader community groups. Therefore it is very unfair to describe car dealers as unscrupulous, because generally the consumer in each instance is not just one person; a group of people make the final decision.

The finance arrangements that are entered into by Aboriginals also need to be looked at very carefully. Any company that I am aware of, and certainly those that are members of the Australian Finance Conference, would assess each and every case for application for finance on its merit. That means that the person applying for finance needs to meet the criteria-the deposit, the term, the satisfactory income. That would be established at the point of credit. That, I think, is the very essence of this matter. There ought not to be any discrimination against Aboriginal people purchasing anything if they can demonstrate that they satisfy the normal community standards and rules relating to credit and finance in this country. Certainly there are problems of education. The few Aboriginals in the very remote areas have a problem in relation to the maintenance of vehicles. I think it is argued in part of Dr White's article, or in something else that I have read recently, that when a vehicle breaks down, in some instances communities do not see the need to keep up the finance commitment that they have entered into. That is surely a problem of education, of understanding what a finance contract is and what the obligations are in that instance. Similarly, there is the difficulty of understanding the very complex and detailed nature of a hire purchase or other finance arrangement.

As I said a few moments ago, I do not believe that finance companies or agencies would negotiate for finance unless it could be demonstrated that the borrower had adequate collateral. It is very unfair on the finance companies to imply that they would enter into special deals with Aboriginals without security. They would apply the normal community standards in each of those particular areas.

The main point that I am trying to stress today is that Aboriginals are now a very important and integrated part of our economic community. There ought to be absolutely no suggestion of any discrimination with regard to what they can or cannot do in the commercial arenas of Australia and what areas of finance ought or ought not to be available. It is very easy and bland to try to draw these threads together with funny adjectives. I would certainly agree that in all communities, whether we are talking about teenage, adolescent or particular ethnic groups, we do need to ensure that the rules that apply to managing money and credit ought to be properly looked at. We must ensure that the education systems in these areas do meet the needs of the consumers. I therefore commend the Australian Finance Conference on its booklet How to Manage Money and Credit which was launched during the last year. But I would suggest to its members that they look carefully at the areas requiring specific targeting, areas of specific need where they may have to tone up the document and look at particular communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters that I want to deal with, and the first relates to problems in Eritrea. The recent reports that have been received in this country indicate quite clearly that there has been a dramatic turn of events in that troubled area, and in particular it is now increasingly clear that the Government forces are in retreat. As a result of the events of 19 March, something like 20,000 Ethiopian soldiers were either killed or wounded and since that time there have been several divisions imported from the Ogaden and there are threats that upwards of 100,000 troops will be brought up from the south to continue to wage the war against the Eritreans, that war having been continuous since 1962.

SPEECH.PARA: The real tragedy of the matter is that there has been so far very limited international response despite the fact that I am sure most of the international community would recognise the rightness of the Eritrean cause and the abhorrent nature of the Mengistu regime. It is now pretty much a fact that as a result of recent events the whole of the west of Eritrea has been freed up. The Dergue has abandoned a number of the cities in that area and left the countryside open to movement by civilians and military forces of the Eritrean Peoples Liberation Front. But despite that the Ethiopian Government persists, in its death throes, and it is widely reported as using napalm and anti-personnel cluster bombs. There is talk of nerve gas possibly being introduced, and the Government has given explicit warnings that expatriates working for relief agencies should withdraw from the region immediately.

The result of that is that there are now very many more starving Eritreans, not least because many of them have fled from the area and those who have remained are no longer being effectively supported by the military. As a result there is a very serious need for assistance, estimated by the Eritreans at something in excess of 130,000 tonnes of wheat. The Australian Government made a grant of food aid last November, and more recently it announced a $300,000 cash grant which will be given to non-government organisations for channelling through to the Eritrean people, but I would have to say that I regard that as manifestly inadequate and I am very disappointed at the Government's lack of response.

A very respected former Attorney-General in Ethiopia, Professor Bereket Habte Selassie, is currently visiting this country. He has been here for several days. I can well recall reading his book in 1980 when I visited Ethiopia, and I think he is a very responsible spokesperson for the Eritrean cause. He has made it clear that despite the fact that Australia has given 2,100 tonnes of food to the Liberation Front in the past 12 months, there is a desperate need for much greater assistance. It is very sad that he has been in Canberra for the last several days, he is leaving this afternoon and the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Duffy, has not been able to find the time to see him. That is very disappointing, and so is the Government's silence on the whole issue. It should not be too much for the Government to express its disgust for the reign of terror that has beset Ethiopia since 1975 and for the civil war that has been raging in that region, a war of liberation as far as the Eritreans are concerned and one which I would have thought would inevitably end up in their favour.

So I would urge the Australian Government to take action in the United Nations in support of negotiations for a peaceful settlement of the conflict, to state publicly its support for self-determination in Eritrea, to increase the ratio of humanitarian aid to the people of Eritrea through non-government channels and to request the world food program, the United Nations Children's Fund and other multilateral organisations to provide assistance during the conflict.

Finally, I believe there are three questions which should be addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. They deserve speedy answers. The first is: Is the Government aware that on 12 May 1988 the Ethiopian Government massacred over 400 civilians in the village of Shiib, and that 80 of those victims were run over by tanks? Second, in view of the expulsion of private relief agencies from Eritrea and northern Ethiopia and the recent declaration of martial law in Eritrea, and in view of the massacre at Shiib, what is the Government of Australia doing by way of bringing international pressure to bear on the Ethiopian Government to cease and desist from committing further atrocities. Third, has the Government held any consultations with other governments or raised the question of the current situation in Eritrea with other governments, including the Government of the Soviet Union, with a view to stopping atrocities and to bringing about a just and peaceful settlement to the conflict? I think it is fair to say that the Soviet Union, in the wake of its disaster in Afghanistan, is likely to be much more amenable to those sorts of suggestions and I think there are good prospects that Mr Gorbachev would be prepared to express his concerns to Mengistu and make it plain to him that there will not continue to be unlimited Soviet support and that the time has come to call a halt to the bottomless pit of suffering that has beset the region for so long.

I turn to another matter altogether, and that is the disgraceful and craven capitulation of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, in yielding to Caucus pressures on the matter of cellular mobile telephones. It is a great tragedy for the Australian community that we have seen in recent days a decision by the Cabinet, a decision by the structural adjustment committee, that there is a need for competition in this area. It is important that this expanding growth industry be allowed to compete with the basic network, and provide services which would encourage efficiency and competition in Australian industry. Yet what we have is a very sorry state of affairs-this is a case of the tail wagging the dog if ever there was-whereby a Caucus committee, by a seven to four majority, has decided that there should be no competition in this area. In that distinguished minority we have Senator Evans and Mr Morris, the Minister for Transport and Communications Support. It is quite clear that the forces of reason were in the minority, and the forces of vested self-interest were in the majority. It is obvious that the reason for their decision was that they saw this as the thin end of the wedge for Telecom Australia's monopoly.

The tragedy of the situation and the tragedy for the Australian community, and it is something that I do not think is readily appreciated in the media or elsewhere, is that the freeing up of the radio paging market in recent years has led to a veritable explosion in that area-increased demand, increased competition, lower prices but, more importantly, more business for Telecom. Yet those sorts of rational decisions have been totally ignored by this Caucus committee and ultimately by this Government. We hear a lot about the Opposition being in disarray because somehow there are sometimes conflicts, differences of opinion on questions such as referendum matters-matters which are not going to determine the fate of governments, when all said and done, but nonetheless what in normal circumstances could be regarded as matters involving healthy differences of opinion. But, no, what do we have? The media are sooled on by the Australian Labor Party, fuming and foaming at the mouth, because somehow this is evidence of total disarray.

But what do we see on the other side? We see that the Government is controlled by a very small minority within the Caucus who have no interest in competition, no interest in expanding the Australian manufacturing sector, no interest at all except in protecting the rights of Telecom unions, the rights of a very small group of people who are not committed to competition at all. That is a tragedy. It is symptomatic of what has happened over the last 12 months, when the whole privatisation debate has been led very tentatively by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and senior Ministers who well understand the virtues and the necessity of competition. They have been overruled time and again by the economic troglodytes of the Labor Party. The real conservatives, the left wing of the Party, are too timid and too afraid to understand, ever to want to understand, the merits and virtues of competition in those areas.

This is not a question of ideology. It is a question of practical economics and what is in the long-term interests of the country. The Prime Minister knows it. Mr Keating knows it, all of the senior economic Ministers know it, but what do we find? They get well and truly overridden, thumped, ridden into the ground, and utter not a word by way of response. Senator Evans is simply the latest in a long line of those who have cravenly capitulated, who are quite prepared to settle for a bit of peace and quiet, who are not interested in the long term welfare of the telecommunications or any other industry, but who are simply interested in harmony with Caucus, in maintaining their numbers and their positions and to hell with the state of the economy. I regard that as a tragedy-one that this Government and this country will live to regret and one which will certainly be rectified by an incoming coalition government.
