SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a Bill for an Act to give effect to certain provisions of the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, and for related purposes. To put this Crimes (Torture) Bill in context, I remind the Senate of a debate in this chamber on 5 April 1984 on the subject of torture which immediately followed the release by Amnesty International of a major book on the extent of torture throughout the world, and the use by governments in particular of torture. The Amnesty International report indicated that torture was occurring in some 98 countries. On that occasion we specifically debated a motion put down by my former very good friend, the late Senator Missen. Part of that motion contained a request that the Australian Government seek the expediting of the completion of the proposed international covenant against torture. Of course this Bill is now putting into legislation that particular covenant.

SPEECH.PARA: We noted in the debate on that occasion some positive signs. In particular, we noted the fact that the United Nations had in recent times made a declaration on the protection of all persons from torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. We saw that as a small but positive step towards the reaching of a formal convention and we commended that convention, obviously, in the terms of the motion. The convention came into effect on 26 June 1987, which was 30 days after the twentieth country, Denmark, deposited its instrument of ratification. As I have said, this Bill will now enable the Australian Government to ratify the convention. In fact, the Australian Government signed the convention on 10 December 1985, so at the very least we can say that our Government-and I say it with regret-has been somewhat tardy in reaching this stage of putting down legislation so that our country can ratify it.

The development of this convention is just another step towards a regime that can counter this terrible practice of torture which is adopted by so many nations throughout the world. But we ought not believe that it will achieve too much. There was, I remind the Senate, a prohibition of torture in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which of course, was adopted in 1948. I remind honourable senators of Article 5 of that declaration, in particular. Again in the Geneva Convention of August 1949 torture was outlawed, as it is in Article 7 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. So declarations against torture by the world's community are nothing new. Unfortunately the practice of torture has not ceased with the declarations.

We recognised in that debate back in 1984 not only public declarations but also the work of numerous bodies throughout the world that were positively trying to do something about this scourge. In particular, we recognised the contribution of international bodies such as the Human Rights Committee, the Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly and the Commission on Human Rights, in Geneva, all of whom are at least bringing to the public's attention examples of torture. Hopefully that can lead to international pressure for such practices to cease. I particularly commend the work of the rapporteurs to the Human Rights Commission in Geneva who have gone into various countries, investigated allegations in depth and put down most worthwhile reports, bringing to our attention examples of these horrific practices. It is not surprising that nation states are somewhat reluctant to expose torture if it is taking place under their particular governments. I know of no countries that publicly acknowledge it as a practice.

Anyway, in that debate back in 1984 we referred to rapporteurs' reports, particularly in relation to South Africa and the territories occupied by Israel and Chile. Before someone jumps up and says that they seem to be all related to nation states with some similarities, let me say I also highly commend the report of the rapporteur on Afghanistan that was put down the year before last. It outlined horrendous examples of the torture that was taking place in Afghanistan, and directly attributed blame to the Soviet occupation. So it is not only criticisms of so-called right wing governments that we see being brought to public attention by these rapporteurs, but also of Communist regimes. As I said, I particularly commend their work. The exercise, of course, is then to attempt to shame these governments into better practices, and regrettably that is proving to be difficult.

In that previous debate we also acknowledged the role of regional organisations such as the Organisation of American States and the Council of Europe, examples of groupings of states that are attempting to bring pressure upon each other. Clearly they can work in a way that contributes to achieving the goal that we are seeking. Needless to say, because the debate was particularly on an Amnesty International report, a report most helpful in outlining these practices, we commended the work of that organisation. That is a commendation I am happy to make at any appropriate time. In addition, we stressed the importance of bilateral pressure. Successive governments in Australia have applied themselves to this task with quite reasonable diligence. It is the task of governments to gather information, to make recommendations and, in the case of Australia, to bring such information to organisations such as Amnesty International, and particularly to our parliamentary Amnesty International group to enable us in turn to try to apply pressure to the regimes and to the governments that are defaulting. I can remember when I represented this Parliament at the United Nations the year before last making representations on behalf of the Australian Government to the Ambassador from Cuba in relation to a number of poor souls who were being abused in Cuba. The efforts of individuals might not count for much but if there are enough individuals making this effort there is the chance that it can come to something.

One cannot discuss this subject without also commending the Red Cross organisation for its magnificent contribution, with its visits to prisoners and particularly its efforts to improve their conditions. Whenever we hear that the Red Cross is being excluded from a trouble spot, immediately loud alarm bells ring. It is clear, regrettably, that international norms of behaviour are insufficient in this area. Torture continues to be practised by many countries throughout the world. What is necessary is some form of enforcement mechanism, some mechanism that can force nation states to behave properly. Of course that is the theory behind this convention. That is what it was thought this convention could achieve. Regrettably, if one peruses the convention, one will find that it lacks mechanisms for implementing and enforcing the cessation of abuses. What it does is provide for a new committee, a Committee Against Torture, that will investigate and report.

As I have indicated, such efforts are always worthwhile, as far as they can go. But there is no power of enforcement. Although the world community becomes part of this exercise, through the convention, no powers of authority are given to any third party to enforce the provisions of the convention. What the convention rather seeks to do is oblige individual states to take action within their state to outlaw torture. But as much torture, as we know, is torture by the state, it does not take too long before one realises that that is a very major limitation on the likely effectiveness of this particular convention.

Some regional bodies have set an example that I think could be taken up by others. I refer, for example, to the convention adopted by the Council of Europe which has in it a provision that its body can go in and investigate torture within a national state without there even being any complaint. It seems to me that the existence of that body is a deterrent, and it is clearly has a convention that goes further than the UN convention. I regret that the UN convention has not been able to go that far.

If one looks further at the UN convention one will find that it can come into effect only in relation to an investigation by the Torture Committee if in fact the nation state that is a party to the convention agrees that the body should do so. Under Article 21 of the convention a nation state must first indicate that it is prepared to allow investigations before investigations can take place, and that relates to investigations of complaints by individuals or by third parties. I hope that Australia is going to set the example and indicate upon ratification that we would be prepared to allow such investigations, because I note that of the first 20 parties to ratify the convention only six have been prepared to do so. So, in effect, it seems to me to be somewhat of an example of double standards if a nation says that it will be party to the convention but will not allow investigations of complaints to take place. As I said, I hope that we will set a better example.

This Bill, in itself, does not do a great deal. It creates for us the offence of torture. It creates the offence of torture committed by public officials of Australia outside Australia. They will go to trial before an Australian court in this country. One would realise that there will be very few examples of that offence occurring, and very few trials of that nature in Australia. It does not allow for defence of exceptional circumstances or superior orders, and, that I commend. But our Government takes the view that acts committed within Australia are already adequately covered by existing State and Commonwealth legislation and therefore we need not go down the path in this country that we say other countries of the world should go down. It seems to me that by taking this particular stand we are not giving the example that we should; we are taking the position that so many countries have taken, and that is that the evil exists elsewhere; it cannot exist within our own system.

The danger in that, I would suggest, is that in this country we take our safeguards for granted. At first blush we would say that torture in this country does not exist, but perhaps it is something that we should reflect upon more carefully particularly when we look at the wide definition of torture that is included within the convention. If, for example, a drug addict has been placed in custody and a confession is taken from him at a time when he is coming out of the effects of his drug addiction and therefore is unable to properly comprehend what he is saying-such people are then often in a state of agony-that would clearly amount to torture under the convention. Perhaps we need to reflect upon that. Look at what is becoming apparent as a result of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. It may well be that much stress might be placed upon an Aboriginal who is put in a position with which culturally he cannot cope, and a confession taken in those circumstances could amount to torture under the convention.

It seems to me, without thinking long and hard about it, that there may well be circumstances in this country where the offence of torture may be committed within its wide definition. Rather than simply adopt the position that this Government has adopted, which is that it cannot occur in this country, we should face up to that responsibility. Eternal vigilance must be maintained if we are to maintain the standards that we believe it is important to maintain in this country. I regret the sense of complacency that one finds in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). Let me just quote from one sentence of that speech:
. . . Australia will never become a safe haven for those who preach fundamental human rights.

But when one looks at the War Crimes Amendment Bill, which is before the Parliament, one finds that this Government has been exclusive in relation to those who have breached that particular human right. So to come here and say that these things will never occur in this country, that we will never be a haven, I believe shows a sense of complacency that is undesirable.

I regret that we have not taken this responsibility more seriously, but before sitting down I want to put a few positive suggestions that Australia should adopt and mention a few areas in which I think it could be doing more to contribute to a world in which torture by the state is less widespread. In particular, we should be making a greater effort to develop a stable international legal system. I am on the record in this chamber as saying that I am concerned that we have made an insufficient contribution in that regard. I have spoken of our negligible contribution in that area in the United Nations, and I would like to see it upgraded. We must be prepared to support financially prisoners of conscience and their families and to assist the rehabilitation of torture victims. We have tended in this country to preach, but we are not prepared to dig deep in the areas where we can materially help these people who have suffered.

We must keep up our contribution to the Human Rights Commission, and I was most pleased that after the representations of Senator Bolkus and myself we upgraded our representation by one person on the Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, and I think that in itself made the contribution of the parliamentarians in our delegation worthwhile. We must encourage international mechanisms whereby international bodies are empowered to make their own inquiries on their own initiative and, as I said, I hope Australia is going to set the example by taking the action it needs to take under this Bill to allow investigations. We must continue all reasonable bilateral efforts and support of non-government organisations, as we have done, but I suggest we do so even more vigorously and resourcefully than we have done in the past.

I regret that torture by states continues to be widespread. I acknowledge the convention and this Bill as small steps in the right direction, but I would like this Government to be taking the subject much more seriously, setting an example and putting much greater resources behind them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I think the hour is such that it would be fairly silly of me to start on a second reading speech on what I believe is a very important Bill involving the ascribing of this country to the so-called torture convention of the United Nations. In fact I have expressed the view that this Crimes (Torture) Bill seems to me to be a totally inappropriate type of Bill to have a debate on at this particular time. It is a Bill which is fundamental to democratic institutions; it is fundamental to the way that Australia has developed in the past and the way its foreign affairs operations are likely to be conducted in the future. Like Senator Hill, I am very much of the view that there has been a fair amount of complacency about this matter in Australia. There are a number of factors that I certainly wish to rehearse in my second reading contribution on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed not to the Leader of the Government in the Senate but to the Minister for Home Affairs. Is it not a fact that the Government is putting forward the first referendum proposal on the basis that it will have no impact on the term of office of the current Government? If so, is it not also a fact that under the existing Constitution the last practical date on which the next half Senate and the current House of Representatives elections can be held together is 2 June 1990? Is it not also a fact that if the first referendum is carried, the last practical date of the next Senate and House of Representatives election to be held together will be extended to 17 November 1990? Does the Minister therefore deny that a practical consequence of this would be to enable the Government to stay in office almost six months longer than is now provided for under the current constitutional arrangements?
—This matter, of course, is not within my portfolio. It is a matter for the Attorney-General, who has carriage of referendums and like matters.
—Dates of elections are your specialty though.

—No. Even dates of elections, with all due respect, are within the Prime Minister's prerogative. I sometimes get asked these questions because I have made a study of these matters over the years. However, I am not inclined today to be erudite on these matters. It is a matter for the Attorney-General; he has carriage of the Bills in this chamber. I think my colleague Senator Tate, who represents him here, got down only the last half of the question. Perhaps the honourable senator should sent it across to Senator Tate very quickly while I am talking if he wishes him to respond.

—I am happy to accept the correction by Senator Ray to the effect that the question should have been addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It seems to me to be a quite important but relatively straightforward question relating to the constitutional amendments which the Minister for Justice is introducing this afternoon. I ask again: Is it not a fact that the Government is putting forward the first referendum proposal on the basis that it will have no impact on the term of office of the current Government? If so, is it not also a fact that under the existing Constitution the last practical date on which the next half Senate election and the current House of Representatives election can be held together is 2 June 1990? Is it not also a fact that if the first referendum is carried, the last practical date of the next Senate and House of Representatives election to be held together will be extended to 17 November 1990? Does the Minister therefore deny that a practical consequence of this would be to enable the Government to stay in office almost six months longer than is now provided for under the current constitutional arrangements?

—The fact is that the House of Representatives term is set under the present Constitution to run-I have not the terms in front of me-some three years from the date of the calling of the Parliament together after the last election. That sets the term for the House of Representatives, and it is in no way altered by the constitutional proposal.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. Is the Minister suggesting that the constitutional limitations on when a Senate election can be held are irrelevant to the Government's consideration of when an election can be held for the House of Representatives, because that would appear to be the basis of his answer? Or does he agree that, in general, the requirement or desirability of holding those two elections together means that the present term of the Senate is very relevant to the likely election date for the House of Representatives? In a practical sense, if the referendum is passed, does the Minister not agree that that extends by nearly six months the period whereby the Government can hold a House of Representatives and a Senate election together?

—I do not agree. The fact is that whatever is desirable about the holding of half Senate and Representatives elections together-that has been a matter of contention in Australian politics for many decades-the Constitution as presently framed sets the date for the necessary limit on the date on which the House of Representatives election must be held. That is the fundamental constitutional criterion governing the calling of that election.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's assessment of the current situation in El Salvador in the light of the Press reports such as that in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald outlining an apparently deteriorating political outlook in that country?

—A period of uncertainty and instability has followed the March elections in El Salvador. The National Assembly refuses to meet, the ruling Christian Democratic Party is divided and in disarray-rather like some other parties I can think of at the moment-and legal disputes over the election results continue. More seriously still, politically motivated violence by rightist death squads, the military and the FMLN-the armed opposition-is on the increase. In a recent incident a military court judge involved in politically sensitive cases was shot down and killed. FMLN guerillas, still a strong force with a membership estimated at between 4,000 and 7,000, have the potential to destabilise the situation severely as they react to military provocation. The continuing political chaos and instability in El Salvador are particularly regrettable in the light of the call for national reconciliation in the Central American peace process begun on 7 August 1987, a call which the Australian Government continues fully to support.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his answer yesterday to Senator Chaney's question in which the Minister conceded that claims lodged by unions for 6 per cent pay rises could be said to be technically in breach of the current wages guidelines. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive yesterday officially endorsed the campaign for a 6 per cent wage rise to be paid by instalments in July and December of this year? In view of this decision and today's Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which show earnings growth of 7.3 per cent for the year ending February 1988, and the consequent certainty that the Budget forecast growth of 6 per cent will be exceeded, does the Minister agree that such an across the board rise paid before the end of the year, plus second-tier increases likely to flow in that time, would have disastrous consequences for the inflation rate and Australia's international competitiveness? What does the Government propose to do in the face of this open defiance by the trade union movement of the existing guidelines and this obvious attempt to undermine the about-to- begin review of these principles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very long and detailed question which has a number of purported facts in it and a number of examples of conceptual confusion.
—Absolute rubbish! The question is as simple as anything.

—Why should I answer a question when Senator Lewis, the moment I start my reply, says that I am talking rubbish? Let me explain to Senator Lewis that the question Senator Chaney asked me yesterday related to no extra claims provisions in respect of the current wage fixing system. It is easy to confuse and blur the current wage fixing procedures and system with the sort of system which is likely to be in place following the review by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: I mentioned factual errors. It is true that the ACTU endorsed claims for a 6 per cent wage rise in the forthcoming year. That has been the subject of a lot of public discussion in terms of wages being consistent with the anticipated CPI increase during that period. I think that Senator Lewis will be aware that, according to the President of ACTU yesterday, it is conceded that those claims may have to be modified in the event of the CPI being less than the 6 per cent anticipated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six per cent CPI anticipated?

—No. Of course, we could play verbal tootsies all day, if that is what honourable senators opposite want, but that is not what I am doing; I am answering the question. When I referred to the CPI anticipated 6 per cent I was referring to the ACTU view that it would make an ambit claim and, if the CPI is 6 per cent, that would be the nature of its claim. However, if the CPI as it anticipates, and as the President of the ACTU said last night, is less than 6 per cent, the claim will be modified accordingly.
—What if it is 8 per cent?
—I do not know. What about the workers?
—It is a pretty important point.

—Senator Short says that it is an important point, but we will cross that bridge when we come to it. This is another in the type of questions that we normally hear from the Opposition about wages policy and anticipating what will happen, speculating what will happen before it ever does. This Government has administered the most successful wages policy in the history of this country. Senator Stone laughs, but when he was the Secretary to the Treasury 600,000 people were put out of work in one year, and there were 15 per cent wage claims simply because the Liberal Party's former leader, the former Prime Minister, had to go to the royal wedding instead of looking after the economy as this Government has done. Even though this mob of wimps opposite may not realise it the fact is that under this Government, with employment growing at twice the rate of the OECD average, we have been able to maintain a sensible and realistic wages system in this country, a system that is the envy of many other countries; and of course it is the envy of the Liberals because they know that they could never do it. The Liberals succeeded, as I said, in throwing 600,000 people out of work in one year, while at the same time--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—This answer seems to be working. The Liberals succeeded in doing both things at once. To return to Senator Lewis's question, because there were several other points, he asked me whether I think it would be disastrous for inflation and the competitiveness of Australian industry. My answer to both questions is no.
—Is the Minister for Justice aware of delays in the processing of some criminal cases in the Australian Capital Territory and, if so, what action is the Government taking to remedy this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been aware of the difficulties experienced, particularly in the magistrates courts here in the Australian Capital Territory, in dealing with serious crimes, the backlog and the difficulty in finding time to hear those cases. Of course, as the Chief Magistrate has pointed out, this is particularly serious in those instances where, for example, a defendant is in custody for some time awaiting trial. Given that increased workload, which tended to erupt particularly late last year and earlier this year due to the commission of some serious criminal offences, there has been cause for particular worry. Indeed, the Chief Magistrate has taken certain steps to deal with this matter, and I am aware that they are beginning to have some practical effect. For example, he has issued a practice direction requiring that from 2 May 1988 all criminal hearings will be subject to a case status inquiry no less than five weeks before the matter is due to come on for hearing. The aim of these inquiries is to ensure that criminal cases are ready for hearing and that there are no last minute requests for adjournments or a decision not to proceed with a case. That should go a long way towards ensuring that maximum use is made of available court time and reduce court delays.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also a question simply of providing sufficient personnel for the magistrates bench. In that respect the Government is pleased that a Mr John Murphy has been appointed as a special magistrate for the Australian Capital Territory. Mr Murphy, who is 43, practises as a barrister in Victoria and was formerly a magistrate in the Northern Territory so he brings considerable expertise and experience to this particular post. He will be available to sit in the court on a sessional basis and, whilst at the moment there is no very significant delay, I am informed, in those cases where defendants are in custody, the delay in other cases is obviously of much concern. I believe that Mr Murphy's appointment will go a long way towards allaying the concerns held in the community about those delays. In addition, together with those of the Chief Magistrate, a number of other initiatives have been taken. These include an examination, as a matter of priority, of the need for the appointment of additional permanent magistrates to the court, a study of the overall resource needs of the court and consideration by the Attorney-General's Department of a report prepared for it on the new computer system in the Victorian magistrates courts with a view to introducing a similar system in the Australian Capital Territory. Senator McMullan rightly raises concerns held in the community. I believe it is evident that both the Chief Magistrate and the Government are taking very useful steps in remedying what was a matter of great concern earlier in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and is in reference to a document which has come into my possession proposing the closure of a large number of community youth support scheme (CYSS) projects in Victoria. How does the Minister explain the existence of this document? Who is the author of the document, why was it prepared and have other States produced similar documents? Why is electoral information included in the assessment of CYSS projects? Was the Department under any direction to consider political issues? Why are most of the projects which are listed to be scrapped located in safe Opposition seats? Why are decisions being made about projects before submissions have even been called for? Finally, can the Minister give an assurance that this outrageous assessment will not result in a $3.4m cut to CYSS projects in Victoria?

—This tatty little collection of paper which is somewhat humorously described as a `document' was handed to a member of my staff a couple of hours ago by a member of the Australian Democrats' staff who said that it was purloined from a typing pool, or picked out of a waste paper basket, or something like that. All honourable senators can see that the document is 20 or 30 pages of handwritten scribbling. It could have been written by anyone. Even the fairy at the bottom of the garden could have written it and probably did before passing it on to the Democrats. I reject the fundamental assumption contained in the question that some collection of paper with scribbling on it by persons unknown should be regarded as a document. However, there were a couple of other points in the question as to why it identifies CYSS projects in particular electorates, or something like that. I believe it is the custom for the Department of Employment, Education and Training, as it was for the Department that previously performed this function, to inform members of parliament that offices are to be opened in their electorates or whatever, but I will check that out. In any event, I think that this document should be taken about as seriously as it deserves.

—I have a supplementary question. In light of the fact that the Minister has denied the departmental origin of this information, in spite of the appearance of the Department's fax number on the first page, can he give a commitment that the closures and amalgamations outlined in the information will not take place and, in particular, that cuts of this level to youth projects in Victoria are not destined to take place?

—I know that it is hard for the Australian Democrats to assimilate facts, but I did not deny that it had a departmental origin. In fact, I said that it was written by persons unknown, certainly persons unknown to me, and that it could have been written by the fairy at the bottom of the garden for all I knew. I do not think that I can say any more than that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to the report on the front page of Monday's Sydney Morning Herald about the transport of highly toxic nuclear fuel waste from Lucas Heights either to Port Botany or Port Sydney and also to the answer to a question I asked on the same subject of Senator Gareth Evans on 6 May 1986. I ask: Why is the waste being transported without the concerns of local councils, environment and resident groups being addressed, as well as without a response being given to the question of insurance raised by Australian Lawyers for Nuclear Disarmament? What will the overall cost of the contract be? The then Minister said two years ago that that cost would be made public after the contracts were finalised. Has the Government now made a decision on the final use of the highly enriched uranium which will be recovered from the spent fuel elements which includes a total of a quarter of a kilogram of plutonium? Finally, are the nuclear fuel rods going to the Hanford nuclear reservation in the State of Washington? If so, is the Minister aware of the article in the January-February edition of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists entitled `Hanford's bitter legacy' on the contamination record of the facilities there since 1943? If the fuel rods are not going to Hanford, where are they going?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the question was directed to the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, but as I have responsibility for the Lucas Heights research laboratories I will answer the question.
—Don't you trust him?

—Oh, really, Senator Walters! The article in the Sydney Morning Herald has been drawn to my attention. Unfortunately it contains allegations about secrecy and hazards which are specious and likely to create unnecessary confusion and concern. Of course, Senator Vallentine is a classic victim of any confusion and concern which might be created by specious articles. The details of timing and choice of route will not be decided until closer to the time of shipment. As is common practice with other sensitive cargo movements, such as payroll transfers or the transport of chemicals, these details will not be publicised. All relevant Commonwealth and State agencies have been notified. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) also wrote to all relevant local councils on 6 May to advise them of the forthcoming shipment. The relevant unions have also been informed and continue to be consulted to provide accurate information to the persons who will be involved in the shipment. Therefore allegations of secrecy are totally unfounded.

ANSWER.PARA: The spent fuel will be shipped in accordance with the Government decision announced on 17 December 1985 by the former Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. The spent fuel which is generated by the Hifar reactor at Lucas Heights contains valuable unused uranium which can be recovered from the reprocessing operation and credited to ANSTO as future fuel for Hifar. About 50 spent fuel elements accumulate each year. Apart from a shipment of 150 elements to the United Kingdom in 1963 all spent fuel has been stored at Lucas Heights. The storage capacity is full and the option of providing additional storage is not desirable as it would further defer the recovery of the valuable uranium contained within the spent fuel. Fission products from the reprocessing will be incorporated into the waste management system of the United States Department of Energy, as will the small amount of contained plutonium which is uneconomic to separate. Of course, all nuclear material will be subject to nuclear safeguards and will remain solely for peaceful use in accordance with the Australia-United States safeguards agreement.

The spent fuel will be transported to the United States in a specially designed cask which meets all the United States and Australian requirements for the safe transport of radioactive materials. These are based on the transport regulations of the International Atomic Energy Agency. I might add that in over 25 years of transporting high level radioactive materials in accordance with the International Atomic Energy Agency regulations there have been no deaths or injuries incurred as a result of the radioactive nature of the material.

Senator Vallentine's question also contained a section asking me the precise destination of the uranium and asking me something about safety measures at that destination. I am unable to answer that part of the question at this stage, but I will obtain an answer for her.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to information contained in a paper prepared for the Minister by Mr Roger Smith, First Assistant Secretary of the Broadcasting Policy Division of the Department of Transport and Communications. I ask: Is it a fact that the paper reveals that News Corporation Ltd held shares in television companies amounting to 17.16 per cent at the end of last year? Is it a fact that under the law the prescribed interest limit for newspaper proprietors having television interests is 5 per cent? Does such a holding breach the cross media and foreign ownership laws? Why has the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal or the Government not taken action to enforce the law when they have known of this apparent breach for some considerable time?

—I am not at all sure that there has been any breach as Senator Messner said, in the sense of any interest being retained in excess of a statutory amount for a longer period than the periods of grace that are allowed under the respective statutes. These things are quite complex. They are matters for the Broadcasting Tribunal, of course, rather than the Minister to administer. I cannot recall the particular internal departmental minute to which Senator Messner is referring. Many such pieces of paper are prepared, particularly in the context of the ongoing policy issues that arise about media ownership and control. I will seek some further information to clarify the situation, as far as I can. But I doubt whether I will be able to give him much more information than he has sought today.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HELSHAM COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE LEMONTHYME AND SOUTHERN FORESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whether he has heard of allegations that he is inciting people to oppose the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests recommendations. Does he accept the allegations as having any basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard of these claims.
—Were you drunk or mad?

—I will get to Senator Alston in just a moment. Of course, as usual, I was neither; nor was I lying on the front lawn. I would have to say to Senator Coates that no less a journal than the Tasmanian Examiner this morning had a headline claiming, `Minister incites Greenies'. I am not very big on inciting at the best of times, so I would never do such a thing, as I am sure all honourable senators would realise. However, I would like to quote just a few of the things I did say to put this matter in some context.
—The Sydney Morning Herald and the Age too?
—The Age was very wrong, but the Sydney Morning Herald was less so. It is all right though because I have to get to Senator Newman as well yet. I ask her to be patient. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: I will be saying nothing about the Helsham report until the Government has made a decision on what to do with it and I will make those recommendations to the Government in the coming weeks. When I have done so I will be more than happy to speak further. And that's all I wish to say on Helsham at the moment but on wilderness and on Tasmania there are some things that I would like to say.

In the context of a discussion about wilderness issues generally and about issues in Tasmania and the environment generally I went on to point out to those present that if they wished the Government to heed their point of view and to take action on it they would need to make sure that their voice was heard. I said that so far the roar of the crowd was not deafening.

I do not resile from those remarks. They were more than appropriate remarks. I think that they were in tune with the context in which they were put. I spoke about how Australia was fortunate in being perhaps the only land left that had large enough areas undisturbed by human contact and able to be called wilderness and how we had a duty to protect those areas. I was launching an inventory of wilderness in Tasmania. I might say that this is an inventory that covers areas much broader than those just covered by Helsham in his report. I went on to speak about how Australia might best live up to that duty. I certainly hope that we would all be wanting to live up to that duty. I am sure that we all are.

However, I did hear that Senator Newman had taken this line in the Examiner a step further. She apparently suggested that I was inciting people to violence and that I had forgotten Ravenshoe. It will be a long time before I forget Ravenshoe. I will not forget what happened before Ravenshoe and why it occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ravenshoe won't forget you, either.

—The people of Ravenshoe will not forget it because of the money the Government is prepared to spend to make sure that they stay in work and that the mill stays open, provided there is some cooperation from that Government run by Senator Boswell's mates. I will not forget what happened. A former Premier-Senator Boswell will remember him because he was a pretty close associate of his-whose name was Bjelke-Petersen--
—Bjelke-who?

—Bjelke-Petersen was his name. When he went to north Queensland, he attempted to stir up the people of Ravenshoe against me. He said, `It's war. We're in a warlike situation'. It is those sorts of comments that I would say incite violence, not my saying to a crowd of academics, people from the green movement, public servants and even representatives of the Australian Mining Industry Council, that I did not think the roar of the crowd was deafening. In a democracy, organising to make sure that one's point of view is heard is a basic right. No doubt over the next few weeks both sides of the argument on the Helsham report will want to make sure that that right is exercised. I support those people in the exercise of their rights. I repeat that I will be saying nothing about Helsham until the Government has made its decision on the matter.
—I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the Minister's statement.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I ask that the Minister table the document from which he was reading.
—If the Minister has a document, he may table it. If he was quoting from notes, he need not table them. It is up to the Minister.
—They are notes, Mr President, but I am happy to table them. I also have a transcript of what I said. I am happy to table that as well. Senator Newman needs some education; there it is.
—Order! The Minister has tabled the notes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE GOVERNMENT INSURANCE COMMISSION OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Justice agree that the Western Australian Government is an integral part of the operation of the national companies and securities scheme and a member of the ministerial council which controls that scheme? In those circumstances why does the Attorney-General, or indeed he himself as Minister for Justice, refuse to take any action to persuade the Western Australian Government to require its instrumentality, the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia, to cooperate fully with the National Companies and Securities Commission inquiry into the Bell matter?

—I agree that the Western Australian Government is an integral part of the machinery established to govern the companies and securities industry in Australia. Of course, the relevant Western Australian Minister is a member of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. As to whether the Federal Attorney or I should intervene and direct the Western Australian Government as to what direction it might give to one of its instrumentalities, I believe that that rests on an assumption explicit in the question that the instrumentality is not cooperating with the inquiries being undertaken by the Companies and Securities Commission. I have already indicated that, due to the fact that the Commission is undertaking certain inquiries and has sought counsel's opinion on various matters as to the steps that are open to it, I believe it would be quite premature and not required for either the Federal Attorney or me to intervene at this stage.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister agree that, as reported widely in the newspapers, but, apparently, not known yesterday to the Attorney or himself, that instrumentality has declined to provide information unless certain confidentiality is attached to it? It is in those circumstances that I ask whether this Attorney will do anything to try to persuade-not direct-his colleague to be more cooperative.

—This very matter was raised yesterday and I answered in the terms that I have repeated today. I believe that steps are being taken which are being properly pursued by the National Companies and Securities Commission. In that situation, I do not believe that it is appropriate that the Federal Attorney should intervene.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Given the recent escalation of fighting in the Gulf war between Iran and Iraq, can the Minister indicate to the Senate what will be the effects on Australia of developments in the Persian Gulf? Specifically, can the Minister advise the Senate whether the renewed heavy fighting in the Gulf will have any effect, first, on the level of exploration for oil in Australia and, secondly, on the price of oil to the Australian consumer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that over the weekend Iraq carried out air raids on two of Iran's major oil terminals, reportedly using Mirage fighters. The most serious raid occurred at the Larak terminal situated near the entrance to the Gulf. The world's largest ship, the Liberian flagged tanker Seawise Giant, which is of 550,000 tonnes, was set ablaze after being hit by parachute bombs. Other tankers hit and damaged in that raid were the Burmah Endeavour, a United Kingdom registered vessel of 457,841 tonnes; the Barcelona, a Spanish registered vessel of 235,000 tonnes; the Khark, an Iranian registered vessel of 231,712 tonnes; and the Argosy, a ship bearing a Cypriot flag, of 152,000 tonnes. The Barcelona is reported to be sinking while the latter two tankers were part of Iran's shuttle fleet between Kharg Island and Larak. A sixth tanker is reported to have been attacked at the Kharg Island terminal.

ANSWER.PARA: It is feared that these latest attacks on Iranian terminals could set off a new phase of retaliatory actions by Iran. Of course, the United States of America has announced that its warships would offer protection to neutral vessels under attack if they were serving states other than Iran or Iraq. The latest action by Iraq could also be a further move to encourage Iran towards a settlement of the war following Iraq's recapture of the strategic Faw peninsula in April. As to the impact of these attacks on Iran's oil production and export capacity, not a lot is known about that at this stage. There are no reports from the oil markets as to whether or not that will result in some form of reduced supply, but the increasing tension in the Gulf region causes short term fluctuations on the speculative spot market. My Department is monitoring those fluctuations and keeps me advised of them. I think most resource analysts would look forward to the price of a barrel of oil being $US14 to $US15 for a number of years to come. Although the fluctuations resulting from the war are in the spot market prices, by virtue of very high inventories kept around the world there is a good supply of oil to the world.

In terms of Senator Burns's question about the effect of the war on the level of exploration in Australia and the price at the bowser, one of the advantages that Australia has-this is highlighted particularly by the sad conflict in the Persian Gulf-is that we are a stable democracy. We offer a stable political climate in which oil search can go on. That in itself is a significant incentive for investment here. As well, under my predecessor, Senator Gareth Evans, and his predecessor, Senator Peter Walsh, the Australian Government has pursued a course of systematically reducing the risk for oil companies in an industry which is notably a high risk industry. In fact, the levels of risk on which the oil industry operates would not be tolerated in other industries. In order to reduce systematically the level of risk in Australia, we regularly release acreage for oil exploration and research, both onshore and offshore. We have introduced stability in the industry by the introduction of our tax regime.

In the last round we provided excise concessions in respect of the first 30 million barrels of oil which is, in itself, a significant incentive in marginal fields. We have a resource rental tax which in fact is a super profits tax-a tax calculated by the long term bond rate plus 15 per cent, beyond which point the tax then checks in. It is not a tax on production and that, in itself, is an incentive for exploration in Australia. Government assistance is given for exploration. At the moment the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics is conducting a $6m survey of the geology of the Canning Basin in Western Australia for both oil and mineralisation purposes. All of those measures combine to reduce the level of risk. I think that is one of the significant reasons why we are seeing a fairly good level of exploration in Australia at the moment.

The events in the Persian Gulf are in stark contrast to the stability that we offer. I do not believe consumers should be concerned about events in the Persian Gulf in terms of their effect on oil prices in this country. What the Persian Gulf events do is cause the price to oscillate a little in terms of spot market prices. But it is important to note that this does not and ought not compute through the system to affect bowser prices in any way at all.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Resources of his answer to me on 14 April confirming that there would be no tax imposed on gold in either the May statement or the August Budget. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's recent statement when he was asked about a tax on gold. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: When you are having a review of the business tax system, everything has got to be on the table. That is the honest answer.

I further refer Senator Cook to Senator Button's answer in the Senate yesterday in which he would neither confirm nor deny whether there would be a tax on gold. Of course, we all know Senator Button, like Brutus, to be an honourable man. So clearly a tax on gold is on the Cabinet agenda. I ask Senator Cook: On what basis did he give his original undertaking and will he now re-affirm it? If not, did he originally mislead the Senate or did he simply not know what he was talking about?

TALK.START.PARA: —I really think that that is a very nice try but a very poor effort by the honourable senator. He ought to go back and read the Hansard. What the honourable senator has said in his question to me now is, from my recollection, an embellishment of his previous question. I said then that the Prime Minister had, of course, given an undertaking before the election. We all know what that is. We have seen it reproduced in a number of newspapers. Certainly, what he has said in the public arena recently is quite understandable. There has been a review of corporate tax and that review will go to the Government for consideration. The missing part of Senator Button's answer yesterday that the honourable senator failed to quote is that Senator Button said, as I recall, `Just you sit and wait. If you sit and wait until next week-in fact on the twenty-fifth-you will get the full answer'.

—I ask a supplementary question. I remind Senator Cook of his original answer in which he referred to the Prime Minister's letter and said that there was no reason to depart from that unequivocal commitment. I ask Senator Cook again: Has the question of a tax on gold been under review? Is it under review? If not, will he give an unequivocal commitment, as he did on 14 April, that there will be no tax on gold?

—I said that I had no reason to depart from anything that the Prime Minister has said, including all of the things that he has said on the record in the last couple of weeks, or anything that Senator Button has said. I have nothing further to add to the answer. If the honourable senator will just show a modicum of patience, he will find out.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of claims that income associated with the retained earnings of companies is subject to `double taxation' under the present tax arrangements? Is this claim valid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of a claim that income associated with retained earnings is subject to double taxation. It is one of the claims made in the National Priorities Project's Spending and Taxing mark 2. I will just quote briefly from a document. It is asserted:

ANSWER.PARA: Undistributed corporate income is subject to double taxation, once as corporate income at the maximum personal rate and then again when a capital gains tax is levied on share sales.
Later the document asserts:
In the case of shares, there is also some double taxation of retained earnings, corporate tax and capital gains tax.

The claim is not valid. It is disappointing to see that two years in a row this so-called right wing think-tank, which appears to be the most intellectual group that the people on the other side of politics can assemble, has produced another shoddy document which is loaded with factual and conceptual errors.

The situation is that if a company has paid tax on company income which it then retains, it will be in a position to issue franked bonus shares. The issue of franked bonus shares will then prevent shareholders from being taxed on capital gains which represent no more than the build-up of retained earnings within a company. If the company sits on a rising franking account, which is a possibility, and does not issue bonus shares, that is not a question of tax but of company management policy. It is something the shareholders ought to take up with the company concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Resources by saying that, notwithstanding the stupidity of a three-mine uranium policy which, according to Senator Bob Collins and Messrs Gordon Bilney and Graeme Campbell, has cost Australia billions of dollars, it is a fact that the Government supports the export of uranium for peaceful purposes. In the absence of a sensible mining policy, when does the Government intend to take the next step of supporting value added uranium enrichment which would not only give Australia more control over the end use of this great energy source but also add around a billion dollars a year to our export earnings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this question was asked so that Senator Parer could launch into an analysis of our uranium policy. We thank Senator Parer for his fairly predictable analysis which was contained in the preface to this question. I guess this has given him his day in the sun. In so doing, the purpose of his question has been achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go to the first of the two questions that the honourable senator actually did ask-namely, whether it is a fact that we support the export of uranium for peaceful purposes. Of course it is a fact. But the question does not go far enough. We insist that we obtain an agreement with the countries to which we export under the terms of the nuclear non-proliferation agreement so that there are full safeguards to guarantee that Australian origin nuclear materials are not diverted for weapons use and that the handling, transport and safety concerns about Australian uranium are properly met to the highest level in terms of the entire world trade in uranium. The honourable senator may not have asked that question, but I think in terms of understanding our policy position on the export of Australian uranium that that addition has to be spelt out because it happens to be integral and vital in our approach to the export of Australian uranium.

The honourable senator then asked me, in his next foray into policy, whether we will embrace a value added path in terms of enrichment in Australia. The answer to that is the same as an answer I gave in this chamber, I think last month.

TALK.START.PARA: —`I don't know'.
—It was not, `I don't know'. It was that that is not our policy. That is not our policy.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said in reply that it is not the policy, but the question I asked was: Does the Government intend to move to the next step of value-added, for the reasons I gave, which would give more control over the end use of this great energy source? I also asked whether this would add around $1 billion a year to our export earnings. If the Government does not intend to go that way, is it simply because of ideological reasons from the left wing of the Labor Party?
—I said that it is not our policy and the rest of that question is hypothetical. I decline to answer it.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Local Government been drawn to editorial comment which suggests that constitutional recognition of local government would be in breach of States rights? Is it not a fact that the wording of the proposed amendment refers quite clearly to State governments providing for a system of local government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is certainly true that there has been some misleading editorial comment about constitutional recognition of local government. It has even been suggested that the issue relates to States rights. I find that very difficult to understand when the full wording of the proposed amendment is detailed in terms of State legislation.
—It does not give the local authority any independence at all; is that what you are saying?

—I can understand the looks of discomfort on the faces of members of the Opposition because many of them have approached me, privately of course, indicating that they have some support for local government recognition in the Constitution.
—What will they get out of it?
—Local government will get long overdue recognition.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to let the people of Australia, and particularly local government, listen to the calls of derision from members of the Opposition. We all know that a news poll that was released on Tuesday indicated that 66 per cent of people support the recognition of local government in the Constitution. We also know that there are great divisions on the benches opposite. We know, for instance, that the shadow Cabinet recommended that local government be recognised in the Constitution. I am not surprised that a number of honourable members on the opposite side of the chamber and in the other place are very embarrassed and disturbed by the very partisan decision that has been taken. I have had various exchanges with Senator Vanstone about bipartisan approaches to issues of great importance. I ask again, as I have in a number of statements in recent days, that the Opposition think again about the recognition of local government in the Constitution.

ANSWER.PARA: We know that many honourable senators opposite are not happy with the No vote and that they would really like to support it. So why do they not take a leaf out of the book of Mr Spender and Mr Ian Wilson, have another think about this and talk to some local government representatives such as the Australian Local Government Association, the Municipal Association of Victoria and associations all over Australia that are very disappointed with the stand those opposite have taken. I suppose the comments I make are made more in sorrow than in anger that those opposite could not have adopted a sensible, common-sense approach to this issue. Deep down they would like to support it and they know they have nothing to lose but everything to gain by supporting constitutional recognition of local government. I predict that when the issue is debated in this place next week we will find a number of honourable senators who do not want to contribute because--

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll be there.
—Senator Boswell will be there. I am sure that local government in Queensland will be very interested in the fact that he does not support it.

—Has the Minister for Transport and Communications or the Government been considering a proposal to set up a new organisation to oversee Telecom Australia? Is it the intention of the Government to remove from itself or the Minister responsibility for the running of Telecom by setting up such an organisation? Will this new body, which I understand is to be called Austel, also deal with consumer complaints regarding Telecom, rather than these complaints being referred to and handled by the office of the Federal Ombudsman? If so, why? If this body or a similar body is planned, what will be its structure, how much will it cost to establish and run, to whom will it be responsible, will its establishment require legislation and when is it anticipated that it will become operative?
—I will be making a very detailed statement next Wednesday night on this whole matter and all Senator Haines's questions will be answered then.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I can understand the Minister's reluctance to give the Senate any information. But when a journalist in the Age today refers to Austel as if it is a fait accompli and when a Labor Caucus committee is, I understand, planning on referring a matter to Austel, the Senate is entitled to get more information than simply a brushing aside and a request that we sit back and wait until next Wednesday. So I repeat: Is this body or a similar body planned? What will be its structure? How much will it cost to establish and run? To whom will it be responsible? Is legislation required for its establishment? When is it anticipated that this body will become operative?
—I repeat my earlier reply.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the proposed liberalisation of meat exports to Japanese markets following the expected relaxation of Japan's strict meat import laws? Is the Minister also aware that Japanese interests have now purchased 4 per cent of Australia's meat processing works and that Japanese companies are seeking to purchase further meat processing plants, not only to protect their interests in Japan but also to extend their control of the purchase and production spheres in Australia? What guarantee can the Minister give the Australian cattle producer that export cattle sold to Japan will not be limited to animals processed in Japanese controlled meatworks? Will the Government give an assurance that during future discussions with Japan it will argue the case that if the Japanese are allowed to own Australian meatworks, Australian interests should be allowed to actively distribute and sell their product to retailers and consumers within Japan so that true market competition may be maintained at all levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McGauran for the question of which Senator Boswell gave me notice several days ago. Accordingly, I am able to give him-I hope-a reasoned and full reply. Australia, along with the United States, has fundamental concerns about the highly restrictive Japanese beef import regime. We are both pressing the Japanese to liberalise access for imported beef. From Australia's point of view, the existing Japanese beef regime also discriminates against the entry of our product. We believe that liberalisation is the only way to address our concerns. Because of the price competitiveness of Australian beef, we would expect to benefit from any liberalisation of the Japanese beef market. It is true that in recent times Japanese interests have made investments in Australian meatworks which now account for some 4 per cent of the total livestock slaughtered at export works. While we understand that there is some concern within industry about this, these investments do not pose a threat to the Australian industry since the present and projected levels of demand for Australian beef by Japan far exceed the production capacity of these plants.

ANSWER.PARA: Moreover, the positive aspects need to be recognised, not the least that it is a sign of the Japanese confidence in the Australian beef industry that it does create an incentive for Japanese interests to source supplies from Australia. The key objective of the negotiating stance of Australia and the United States of America is to bring about the free interplay of market forces in Japan and a much more direct relationship between buyer and seller. As such, any concern about the distribution and selling system in Japan is being covered by our overall approach to the negotiations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time yesterday Senator Vanstone asked me a question concerning invitations to the Tasmanian launch of the National Agenda for Women on Monday, 16 May. I understand that Senator Vanstone has since put out a Press release reiterating her charge that no Tasmanian Liberal senators were invited to that launch. I have since learnt that, contrary to Senator Vanstone's claims, both Senator Walters and Senator Newman were in fact invited to that function-as they should have been, as I said. In fact, Senator Walters courteously apologised, I understand, for her inability to attend. Invitations were extended, as is always the case, to all women and women's organisations.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the Tasmanian function, the mailing list was drawn up by the Tasmanian Women's Information Service, and both Senator Walters and Senator Newman are on that mailing list. Invitees and attendances at the launch covered the entire political spectrum. Women from the Tasmanian Premier's Department were invited and they attended. Women in the Tasmanian Parliament were also invited, and the fact that there were no women members from the Tasmanian Government was because, of course, there are no Liberal women members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 May I was asked a series of questions by Senator Coulter concerning radiation and I now have an answer. The dose limits for exposure to radiation are based on effects observed in humans who have been exposed to high doses from different sources. Studies on survivors from the atomic bomb explosions at Hiroshima and Nagasaki increased the knowledge of dose-effect relationships and form part of the base used for deriving the limits. The International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) considers that activities which lead to doses about the limits are unacceptable and recommends that all doses be kept as low as readily achievable. It has noted that in large occupational groups, the mean dose is one-tenth of the limit. This means that, in practice, the risks associated with occupational exposures are very much lower than in the construction industry.

ANSWER.PARA: A complete review of the implications of the new Hiroshima and Nagasaki data is being undertaken by the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR) this year. Whilst there is a suggestion of a 5-15 times risk for some types of cancer, this does not apply to all types. The ICRP will be making new recommendations in 1990, based on the UNSCEAR review. The National Radiological Protection Board in Great Britain has only made recommendations in regard to radiation exposure; they are not mandatory. In these, the ICRP dose limits have been retained but it is recommended that a level of three-tenths of the limits should not be exceeded when averaged over a few years.

The National Health and Medical Research Council is keeping the position under review and will give further advice in line with the UNSCEAR review and the new ICRP recommendations. It has been shown that, in Australia, the average dose for radiation workers is less than one-fiftieth of the annual dose limits.
