TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I referred to Estimates Committee A and information that had been gained during questioning of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and government officials during the Committee's hearings. I was in the process of addressing the question of Austrade and had identified the problem we have with our sixth largest trading partner-namely, Taipei-where we have no Austrade office. I had itemised the sort of assistance that may be available to a business person who wished to go to Taipei to conduct business and, hopefully, increase our exports. I had made the point that many other countries have managed to accommodate the sensitivity that may exist between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan and have been able to effectively service in a better manner than we have people who wish to conduct trade negotiations in Taipei. I suggest that that matter needs to be addressed seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise two other important items that came out of the hearings of Estimates Committee A. One relates to the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA). I asked whether or not fees were charged by TUTA and whether there was a comparison between fees collected and the cost of maintaining students. The answer, which has been given in writing, is that the only `fee' which is payable is a fee to cover the cost of air fares of a student going to the Trade Union Training Authority, from wherever he or she comes. That is a fixed amount. It is the same no matter what distance a student travels. Thus, in the financial year to 31 March 1988, $216,055 had been collected; whereas the cost of students travelling to Wodonga over the same period was $253,161. The Authority charges no fees for attendance or for the courses provided, but it says it costs $160 per student per day. In view of the discussion that is going on regarding a tax surcharge on graduates of universities and colleges of advanced education, I point out that such a tax will not apply to students who attend TUTA because it is not a relevantly prescribed institution. Therefore, it would be possible to conclude that people who seek and gain education are to be taxed, but people who get propaganda, are not to be so taxed; they are to remain free of tax.

The other matter of some significance that arose from the hearings concerned the Australian Customs Service. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that when I asked the Minister whether he was satisfied that the barrier at airports and ports was adequate and met the requirements of Customs, quarantine and immigration, particularly in respect of the smuggling of illicit drugs, Senator Button answered that he was not so satisfied. As we went through various questions as to the operation of the Customs Service, we ascertained that officers work a minimum shift of 7 hours 21 minutes. This means that, although there is a peak period for inbound passengers between 6 a.m. and 9 a.m. and a further peak period for people leaving Australia, there is no way at the moment that the shifts can be split so as to make a more efficient use of staff who are expensive to train. In fact, there was evidence that an investigation had been undertaken into this matter. However, it was decided finally that the industrial relations problems were too difficult and therefore this matter has been put into the too-hard basket.

In previous debates I have said that this Government continually takes the soft option. It continually looks for the easy way out and never tackles the difficult industrial relations questions. The Government acts in this way in relation to protection given to certain industries. There is always debate about slashing tariffs, but there is never any Government initiated debate about the reduction of restrictive work practices, which is the other half of the equation. Equally, it is quite clear that, by splitting shifts worked by officers of the Australian Customs Service and by a better use of manpower, we could make the entry of tourists into this country much easier. Tourism is a money earner for this country and is one of the ways in which we can reduce our national debt. If we took these measures it would be possible to make a far more effective use of the manpower available, but this is not being done because such a move would promote industrial problems. It is time that this Government addressed the difficult option and did not just take the soft option.

For the remainder of my time I want to discuss a most important question relating to Telecom Australia. I have spoken at some length in this chamber on two occasions concerning Telecom and the manner in which it conducts itself and its monopoly. Often in this chamber when we ask questions about Telecom of the Minister responsible, we get an attempt to say that he is somehow at arm's length from Telecom and that the actions of Telecom really cannot be dealt with by him. During Question Time earlier today Senator Haines asked a very specific question about the proposed Austel body. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) replied that he would be making a statement next Wednesday. He gave a most arrogant answer to Senator Haines when she pointed out that she had read newspaper reports about what was planned and said that it was only proper that the Senate be at least as informed as the newspapers to which information obviously had been leaked. The Minister refused to give any further information and merely said that he would talk about the matter next Wednesday. I can only say that the arrogance of the Minister is truly matched by the arrogance of Telecom itself.

This morning Senator Collins tabled correspondence relating to several matters that had been dealt with by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I moved that the Senate take note of the correspondence. I did so in my capacity as a senator and not as a member of that Committee. The Committee has at all times acted in a proper and bipartisan manner and it has done all it can in this matter. But I am concerned about the arrogance that has been displayed by Telecom Australia. Mr R. W. Brack, Chairman of Telecom Australia, says continually in a letter, of which he is the author, that the review of Telecom is a political matter rather than a legal matter. This letter is a result of the questioning by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee of by-laws which were purported to have been made pursuant to the Telecommunications Act 1975. The Committee took a fairly serious view of the proposed by-laws. It wrote a letter to Telecom, which has similarly been tabled, in which it said:

. . . the Committee remains somewhat concerned whether the proposals in the By-laws go far enough to protect adequately the expectations of the community to enjoy a high degree of service and administrative justice from a statutory body . . .

The particular by-laws related to the exercise of power which the letter continually describes as an `arbitrary' exercise of power, for which it in no way apologises. In fact, Telecom describes itself in several places in the letter as `a statutory monopolist with authority to authorise third parties to engage in activities in a monopoly sphere when that is considered to be appropriate'. The letter goes on to say that, as it has a conferred monopoly, there are no private rights and that decisions it makes which permit members of the public to obtain certain rights are strictly the conferring of privileges. In other words, Telecom regards all the decisions it makes as the conferring of privileges. Telecom goes on in another part of the letter to say:
. . . long-term enjoyment of a permit privilege creates expectations which transform the privilege into a right . . . privileges do not become rights in that manner.
In other words, Telecom believes that there is no right to continue a usage even though a business enterprise may have enjoyed that particular usage for, say, 20 years.

Telecom describes its discretion as `unfettered'. It takes issue with the Committee's assertion that by-laws, in order to be good by-laws, ought to be consistent and predictable. Telecom says that the conferral can vary due to changes in circumstances and that it is not bound by the consistent and predictable criteria by which other pieces of delegated legislation are bound. Telecom goes on to tell the Committee how, in its view, it ought to conduct its business. Telecom says that it can decide not to bestow a privilege on people who are subject to a determination and that they are not entitled to know the reasons why Telecom has made that decision. It says in its letter that there is no entitlement to criteria, that it will not be necessary to publish them and that the reasons for the denial or the granting will not remain static. It goes on to say that its power is not totally arbitrary. It is, however, bound only by standards of administration propriety. The letter says:
Within those limits Telecom is authorised by its Act to be arbitrary . . . and may consequently refuse, in its absolute discretion, to confer privilege exceptions to that monopoly.
The letter continues:
. . . review of its conduct is to be political, not legal.

I have raised this matter today because I think it is important that people should be aware of the arrogant nature of the responses of Telecom. I think this letter will go down in the annals of history as a statement of the way in which Telecom conducts itself and its business.

On a previous occasion in this chamber I asked whether anybody knew anyone who had ever won a fight with Telecom. I think the answer is no, because one never has a leg to stand on when one deals with Telecom. Telecom is secretive and, as I said, it considers itself to be above the people. The Committee said:

In a situation where there are no public criteria to guide and inform the exercise of administrative discretions then all the greater is the need for some independent avenue of appeal to underwrite the quality of primary decision-making and provide the means of dealing with genuine grievance.
Telecom answers that point by saying at the moment that it reserves the right to address decision-making. It says:

. . . any refusal to accept a building complex as being eligible for a shared-tenant exchange can be considered to be genuine only in the context that people will often be aggrieved by the failure of a monopolist to confer privilege.

Telecom says at every point that the people have no rights and that they are at the mercy of Telecom to confer privilege. Telecom is perpetually engaged, as it states in its letter, in arbitrary decision-making, which it defends. I have said that Telecom wished to tell the Committee how to do its job. The Committee is there to protect the rights of individuals and enterprises. The letter says:
In Telecom's view . . . the present case is not one in respect of which the Committee's general philosophy is applicable.

In other words, Telecom says it is above ordinary mortals in the rest of the land. It acknowledges graciously that the Committee has a right to scrutinise delegated legislation but says Telecom is exempt from that scrutiny. I am pleased to say that the arrogant nature of this letter has subsequently been drawn to people's attention and a more happy result will follow in that there will be some sort of internal mechanism for appeals. A further statement in the letter that I have mentioned and that has been tabled in this place says that a conferral on the Commission of a review function would mean that it would be `swamped by individual cases to the detriment of policy formation'. It is virtually saying that its decision-making is so bad that many citizens will spend their time appealing against these bad decisions. What a self-indictment! Telecom says, finally, on page 10 of its letter-and it is a 10-page letter-that it would:

. . . have preferred not to engage in a semi-public debate on the basis of implications of its charter during the current period of review of its functions and it would have been easy for it to propose some cosmetic modification of the amendment which might satisfy the Committee's concerns without providing applicants with any real increase in their rights.

In other words, the letter has insulted the Committee, and the Parliament by implication, by implying that cosmetic alterations would have satisfied the Regulations and Ordinances Committee which, in fact, is determined to ensure real rights and never will be satisfied by cosmetic modifications. That arrogant assertion is not to be allowed to stand. It shows a contempt for the Parliament and for the committees of the Parliament. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee is a watchdog. It is answerable to this Parliament. It does its job, as I have said before, in a bipartisan manner. The concern for rights of individuals is real-and in no way could the statement in that letter be allowed to stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating cognately three Appropriation Bills and three Supply Bills. I would like to concentrate on what I believe is a gross discrimination against young people in Queensland in terms of the lack of tertiary education places. For some years now I have been drawing to the attention of the former Minister for Education, ex-Senator Susan Ryan, this blatant discrimination against Queenslanders, compared with people in every other State. Students in Queensland particularly school leavers, are grossly disadvantaged in opportunities for tertiary education. The Federal Government must be forced into action to correct this inequity. It is probably easy to say that, but what are the facts? Once I have described the facts, that recognition will come through.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland has the lowest participation rate in Australia in tertiary education. For example, on a population basis, 10.3 per cent of people in Queensland in the 17 to 64-year-old age grouping are in tertiary education, compared with 13.1 per cent in New South Wales, 13.2 per cent in Western Australia, 15.1 per cent in South Australia and 23.9 per cent in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Just as an aside, when collecting and collating these figures, one of my staff discussed this matter with someone in Canberra who made the point that everyone knows that children of parents in the ACT are twice as smart as the children of parents in Queensland. That is a trite remark but the thing is that the person meant it. That is the sort of thing we have to put up with. What concerns us most is the 20-year-old and under age group. Those people are particularly disadvantaged in my State. In 1987, 37.2 per cent of people in that age bracket missed out on a tertiary education place in Queensland. The State coming closest to that was New South Wales with 28.2 per cent. The least affected State was Tasmania with 8.3 per cent.

The funding position has improved slightly over recent years. I can recall former Senator Ryan quite correctly saying that with the additional places Queensland would get some benefit-and so it did. But it was a drop in the bucket, a couple of hundred extra places. Shades of Marie Antoinette-if the people do not have bread, let them eat cake. Just to give honourable senators an idea about this, let me say that even with that increase-and the Government has defended its position on a couple of occasions, although I do not believe that it should defend it; it should come out and say what the position is and what it will do to fix it-in 1986 approximately 6,660 young Queensland school leavers missed out on a tertiary place in that State. These 6,660 people qualified and if they had lived in any other State they would have had access to tertiary institutions. In 1987, that figure had grown to 6,970 and this year, 1988, approximately 7,860 people missed out. I repeat that these people, had they lived in another State, could have had access to a tertiary institution.

I point out that these figures do not include technical and further education, which would have made the situation even worse. As can be seen, the position is getting worse, year in year out, and must be corrected. This year, as an example, 43,400 people applied through the Queensland tertiary admission centre for a place at a university or college of advanced education in Queensland. About 29,000 people completed grade 12 and, of them, 19,000 were accepted. It should be pointed out that that figure is inflated because, for the first time, nurses were included and there were 1,122 of them. The interesting point is that of that number accepted, around 19,000-only 8,300 or 48 per cent-came from the 1987 grade 12 group. That is a drop of 3 per cent from last year. A comparative figure is that in Victoria, 65 per cent of people going into the first year at a tertiary institution come from grade 12.

The question is: Why the difference? Is it something peculiar to Queensland? What is the reason? The reason is that the other 52 per cent came from varying groups. A large number, approximately 2,000, were upgraded from grade 12. That figure included deferred students. The reason they upgraded is that they could not get into a tertiary institution the year before or did not get sufficient points to get into the course of their choice. Another 2,242 students partially completed their degrees. This is what is commonly known as course jumping. The reasons students do that are twofold. The main one is that they get into a course they really do not want but use it to upgrade their tertiary education scores so that they can get into the course they would like. The other part of that group contains students who got into a course that they found did not appeal to them and hence moved to the one that did. A growing number of students are now completing a first degree. The present figure is 1,639. A common habit of students is to do a degree that they do not really want to do and then use it to get into the course that they really wanted to do in the first place. I am not in any way criticising students for doing that. In fact, I admire them for going to those great lengths to complete a course that they wish to do.

However, this is having a compounding effect on those students from grade 11 coming into grade 12, because that same number of students will have to go through exactly the same exercise in order either to get into a tertiary institution or to do the course of their choice. There is a misallocation of resources here because of the basic lack of places and the efforts that enthusiastic students have to go through. One can do a bit of a calculation in relation to, say, the Queensland Institute of Technology, which is probably the cheapest and most efficient tertiary institution in Queensland. Its average cost of educating a student is about $6,500. The wastage due to students doing courses that they do not want to do or repeating grade 12 is costing some $30m a year. That misallocation of resources of $30m each year would in fact pay for the additional places required by those who presently miss out attending a tertiary institution in Queensland.

The Federal Government, quite correctly, has encouraged young people to remain at school longer. Queensland students, however, did not need that encouragement because already 58 per cent of young people in Queensland go on to grade 12, whereas the national average is less than 50 per cent. The Minister has said that by 1995, or perhaps 1992, he wants to see 65 per cent going on to grade 12. In Queensland we are nearly there and yet what happens when those students complete grade 12? Because of the discrimination that occurs in Queensland, compared with the other States, those students have nowhere to go at the end. I would not complain if, due to the dire economic circumstances that we are in after five years of the Hawke Government, any restrictions that needed to be put on this were equitable across Australia. However, they are not equitable across Australia and there is discrimination in Queensland.

I now refer to some interesting figures. A student seeking acceptance to study physiotherapy at the University of Queensland must be in the top 2 per cent of the State; for occupational therapy a student must be in the top 5 per cent of the State; and for speech therapy, the top 4.5 per cent of the State. To do law at the Queensland Institute of Technology, a student must be in the top 4 per cent; for optometry, the top 3.5 per cent; and for electronics computing, the top 4 per cent. In this day and age when we want more and more young people to get into so-called high-tech areas it is an absolute disgrace that a student wanting to do electronics computing at an institute such as the Queensland Institute of Technology must be in the top 4 per cent of the State.

Of course, the root of all the problems is the lack of funding from the Federal Government. I believe that State governments have a role to play in the absence of the Federal Government doing its job-the job that it took on in 1973, when the then Whitlam Government said that it would take over tertiary institutions and that students would not pay fees.

It is interesting to look at Queensland's share of the total Commonwealth higher education grants and to propose what the figure should be. Queensland received 14.5 per cent of grants for universities, 15.7 per cent for colleges of advanced education, and 14.3 per cent for technical and further education. However, Queensland has 16.6 per cent of the population of Australia. Also, this does not take into account the higher retention rate that I mentioned earlier of students going on to grade 12, that is the 58 per cent retention rate, as against the Australian average of less than 50 per cent.

On a funding basis, if Queensland were to be brought into line with the other States it would require an extra $35m, which would provide places for another 5,500 or 6,000 students. As I indicated earlier-and I am not one of those people who go around asking for governments to cut expenditure while at the same time demanding an increase in spending-I believe that there is a gross misallocation of resources. The money needed could be made up if the extra places were provided and paid for by students who are taking up places by repeating grade 12; who are doing courses that they do not want to do in the first place; or who, for the purpose of course jumping, are using first degrees as a stepping stone to get into the course that they really want to do.

What can be done about this matter? A number of things can be done, but one of them is not the Wran plan for tertiary institutions. First of all, Queensland must be given equity. That is the first priority. As I have said, in the absence of that, there are avenues that a State can use. One of them is to apportion part of the State's payroll tax into tertiary institutions. I know that that is not the role of the State governments because the Federal Government decided that it would take over the funding responsibility. However, a State may be forced into that position. Victoria found itself in that position some years ago, and that is the plan that Victoria used. The Wran plan has been described by Professor Bird, a Melbourne academic, as follows:
It seems to have been designed with the intent of fooling the `anti-fee' elements within the ALP rather than the allocative effects it will have on an already very inefficient system.
That was put very well by Professor Bird. As pointed out in an article in today's Brisbane Courier-Mail by Professor Lauchlan Chipman:

The protesting students have a point when they say the same logic which dictates a tax surcharge for those who have undertaken higher education also dictates that those who have been on the dole should pay a tax surcharge if and when their income reaches average weekly earnings.
That is good logic. The article continues:

Then, of course, there are all those supporting mothers who get assistance in raising their children. Why should they not have to pay back at least part of it through a tax surcharge, if and when they reach average weekly earnings, or have the good fortune to marry someone whose earning power is above the magic line?

Or perhaps we should wait until their children reach average weekly earnings, and then hit them with a special tax for the benefits that they have derived for the special support provided for their upbringing.

Those are a few examples of the stupidity of this approach. The Liberal Party of Australia went to the last election with a very honest approach to education. The Australian Labor Party has gone around for ages saying that it would not have fees-and yet a fee was introduced, although it was called something else. It was a Clayton's fee, the $250, which has now gone up to $263 or something like that, 95 per cent of which of course went back into Consolidated Revenue and not into tertiary education. Of course, it could well have gone to Queensland to fix up the gross inequity that exists.

Incentive must be given for students to complete courses in the minimum time, otherwise they are doing a disservice to those who cannot get places. I have no disagreement with that. However, as I have said, the Liberal Party went to the election with an honest approach. That was that we would reintroduce the scholarship system; in other words, tertiary institutions would be able to set a fee that they would decide. It would not be decided by government. Scholarships would be provided on merit, on an equitable basis. As I have pointed out, currently the basis used is most inequitable. Under what we propose, the students who did not make the quota would be able to attend a tertiary institution under conditions set by that institution-again not by government. Students who passed under those conditions would be able to pick up a dropped scholarship. What effect would this system have? According to fairly conservative estimates that have been given and to discussions that I have had with tertiary institutions, the incentive to which I have referred would increase throughput in our tertiary institutions by about 20 per cent without it costing the taxpayer one more cent.

In addition, we should also allow to Australian students the same facility as we allow to overseas students. Overseas students who want to go to a tertiary institution in Australia may come here and pay a fee to attend. That option is not available to Australian students. Such an option, however, would fit hand in glove with the scholarship system that we would promote. Although I will not go into detail, there is a need for more autonomy and flexibility in tertiary institutions. That is a vital requirement, but it relates to a whole host of issues, such as tenure and so on.

I want to conclude by quoting from an article in the University News of the University of Queensland of 9 March 1988. Written by Professor Brian Wilson, the Vice-Chancellor of the university, the article states:

Queensland, demonstrably, is a disadvantaged State; Queenslanders have less chance of gaining entry to a higher education institution than other Australians. A national survey of unmet demand for entry to universities and colleges in 1987-
and I point out that the situation in 1988 is worse-

showed that of those who graduated in the top half of year 12 and who did not receive a place, 40 per cent were Queenslanders. From another perspective, this year only 40.6 per cent of Queensland higher education applicants (excluding nursing) could be offered a place, a reduction from 41.3 per cent in 1987-despite an increase in total places of more than 1,000.
He goes on to say:

As the Liberal Party pointed out recently, Queensland has 16.6 per cent of Australia's population but receives only 14.5 per cent of university funding and 15.7 per cent of college funding. It is ironic that, at the same time, Queensland had the highest retention rate (58 per cent) of people staying on to year 12, but the lowest tertiary participation rate (10.4 per cent compared with 23.9 per cent in the ACT).

One of the roles that a senator plays is to represent his State. I believe that by tackling this problem in the way I have tackled it, I am doing just that. This role of senator is often forgotten. This matter of places for tertiary education should be approached in a totally bipartisan manner. I have said the same thing at a number of public meetings that I have attended on this matter. It may be of interest to the Senate to know that I have addressed about 15 to 20 concerned groups of parents and friends, parents and citizens and teachers. At one school-not a very large school-about 700 parents and concerned students showed up at the meeting.

The situation I have described as it affects tertiary education in Queensland is totally untenable, but it could be fixed without too much expense. I will add one further comment about a situation that would not apply anywhere else in Australia but, if it did, the parents would take to the streets. The James Cook University of North Queensland is the next closest university to Brisbane but it is about as far away from Brisbane as Sydney is from Brisbane, and it serves an area from Mackay through to Cairns. It is doing its best in very difficult circumstances, and I believe it is leading the way in the direction in which I think we should go. It has a campus in Cairns, where it is using the technical and further education college as the place in which to educate young people. What is being done by the university is only in phase one so far.

However, what I want to say is this: Cairns is the fastest growing city in Queensland and probably in Australia with a present population of 80,000, yet the campus at James Cook University was funded by this Government for 55 places. How many other areas in Australia would accept that? It is a disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Parer, the previous speaker, on the way in which he put his case for Queensland, his home State. He did so with great feeling and he spoke with great feeling for Queensland people. At present, we do not have a government that is putting things on the right track. In this debate on the Appropriation and Supply Bills we have a chance to try to give our opinion of how things can be improved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a variety of feelings in speaking in this debate. In August of 1984 I made my maiden speech in this chamber in a debate on the Appropriation Bills. It is quite possible that this will be the last major speech I will make in this chamber before we move up the hill. Although four years does not sound a great deal of time, nevertheless on occasions the past four years seem to have been an eternity, while at other times they seem to have flown. When I first spoke here I spoke with the enthusiasm and, perhaps, naivety of a new boy in school. I believed then that anything was possible and that all one needed to do to change things was point out the errors and they would be corrected. However, after four years of telling the Federal Labor Government that what it is doing is wrong, I believe my pleas are falling on the same deaf ears as they fell on four years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, they do not listen.
—What Senator Vanstone says is correct: the Government does not listen.
—We do listen.

—It is good to hear that the Minister for Justice is listening. I spoke four years ago of many matters-of a worsening economic climate, of money not being spent fairly in rural areas, and on such necessities as roads, schools and health. I spoke on the vital importance of trade to an exporting country such as Australia. I spoke about militant trade unionism crippling the productive sectors of this nation. Now, four years later, I want to return to those themes because, after four years of Labor Government, four years of such debate, things have not really improved. Indeed, in many areas things are worse-indeed, much worse.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator based in rural New South Wales, my interest in this place has always tended to be centred on the rural sector. Of course, what affects rural Australia affects all of Australia. Rural Australians have always played a vital role in our economic well-being, and rural Australia is basically the economic barometer for the whole of the nation. If things are okay in the bush, they are generally okay in the rest of the country. Repeatedly this Government regards the rural sector as nothing more than a great milch cow. If money is short, the Government squeezes the cow a bit harder. That is fine when there is still something left, but for too many years I believe the Government has been trying to milk a dry cow. While the farmers are providing nearly $20 billion in export income, they are having to fight to get basic education for their children, they are forced to travel on roads better suited to Third World countries and they are slugged with taxes and charges such as export inspection costs and chemical residue testing. When they do not earn any money from the farm they have to battle for unemployment benefits and when they have a good year they pay through the nose in taxes.

A study of Labor's record in office reveals a litany of confusion and untruths because those years are littered with examples of saying one thing about the economy and doing another. This indicates that the Government either does not know what it is doing or is deliberately and continuously misleading the electorate. Let me give a few examples. In February 1983 the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that there would be no devaluation of the dollar. Yet the dollar was devalued in March. In April 1983 the Prime Minister said that there would be no increase in tax on lump sum superannuation; a tax on lump sum superannuation was introduced in July of that year. In November 1984 the Prime Minister claimed that inflation would be less than 5 per cent in 1985 and that interest rates would fall. Inflation was 8.5 per cent in 1985-86 and in the next year it was about 15 per cent. But it is not just the Prime Minister. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been caught out in the same way. In March 1986 Mr Keating said he remained confident that a downward trend in the current account deficit would emerge during 1986 but by October that year the current account deficit had soared to $1.45 billion-the sixth consecutive month it had exceeded $1 billion. By the end of 1986 Australia had the second largest current account deficit in the Western world. Australia was beginning to doubt the ability of the Treasurer, and even the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, was quoted as saying:
I don't know who invented the bloody J curve, but I tell you it wasn't an Australian who learnt about the Australian economy.
The rest of the world followed suit. First Moody's and then Standard and Poor's downgraded us from a AAA credit rating. That is just a little bit of history.

In the five years that the Government has been in office we have had 12 Budgets, mini-Budgets and special aid packages-that is more than two per year. We have not had one three-year term of parliament and yet this Government is now going to the people saying that it needs to change the Constitution because three-year terms are not long enough and four-year parliamentary terms are necessary. I, for one, could understand the request a little better if the Government had at least stuck with the three-year terms but it has not even been able to do that. Why is it now asking for a longer term? The best we can say about this Government is that it has been a record breaking one for some of the reasons I have given. While it makes much of the fact that it is the first Labor government to run four years, it has a few other records for the history books. It has achieved the highest interest rates ever, record bankruptcy rates, the highest current account deficits, and it is the biggest spending government. It also has the biggest tax take of any government and it has overseen the biggest fall in the Australian dollar. This Government has produced the longest public housing lists and achieved record levels of home loan repayments. That is an impressive list for this Government. Of course, over all this-I am glad that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) is sitting up now--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am listening intently.

—As I have said, the result has been a fall in the living standards of Mr and Mrs Average Australian. Cars today cost what houses did 10 years ago; the price of fuel for those cars has doubled in four years. Economic policies have created deeper and deeper divisions. The old adage about the rich getting richer while the poor get poorer is applicable in Australia today. While the Australian Labor Party has been looking after its rich mates, the number of Australians living in poverty has increased. The Weekend Australian of last weekend highlighted this dilemma with the headline, `Gold: PM's dilemma-to tax or not to tax'. A question was asked about this in the chamber today and Senator Cook, with all his guile, tried to avoid answering it. As the article's author, Paul Kelly, summed it up:

SPEECH.PARA: Rich mates, restraint with equity and a fair tax system-all are bound up with the nasty gold tax option . . . Gold today spells Alan Bond.

The dilemma for the Government is that by not taxing the gold industry it is missing out on between $100m and $600m. While the Government wrestles with this problem, it wastes $40m on a referendum which the Minister for Justice spoke about earlier today. His Government agonised over spending $4m on a Picasso and yet it allowed an extra 700,000 people to fall below the poverty line. I do not know who is doing the economics on those figures. This Government is obviously causing that. Its priorities are wrong and Mr and Mrs Average Australian are suffering because of it. One in every eight households lives in proverty. Nowhere is the Government more misguided than in its tax arrangements. Senator Cook, who I have just said was pretty clever in avoiding answering a question today, summed it up correctly when he said:
The Labor Party is a high-taxing Party. It has to be to carry out its reforms.

I do not know about reforms in the Labor Party, but we all know the reforms it has made to the tax system: additional capital gains taxes, a fringe benefits tax, a wine tax, petrol taxes, Medicare levies, assets testing, departure and arrival taxes, a resource rent tax, a tertiary education tax and perhaps now a gold tax. The result of all these is a massive increase in the tax take from $44 billion in 1982-83 to an estimated $78 billion in 1987-88.

As I said earlier, our trade performance must improve. After all, it is the key to our economic salvation. The Government talks about trade but does not actually do much. Again I refer to the same article in the Weekend Australian dated May 14-15 1988 which quoted the Director of the Australian Goldmining Industry Council, Mr Duncan Bell. It said:

. . . Mr Duncan Bell, said last night: ``The Prime Minister has given an undertaking in writing that there would not be a tax (on gold) for the life of the Parliament so members of the industry could invest in confidence over the next three years based on that undertaking.''

How can we expect to increase and help trade if we have a government making a commitment to something and then changing it half way through. A business or an industry making a decision would then have to change and base its investments and its program on the changed circumstances. If the Government decides to tax gold next week, I think it will find that this will be another impost on the people contributing to the export industries of Australia. About $2.5 billion is earned in gold exports. Another export industry will be slugged. The Government claims that it cannot do much about all these things because of the overseas influences, low world economic growth and rising protectionism, but that has nothing to do with the article I have just quoted from the Weekend Australian. But that is only part of the story.

The other half of the situation is our macro-economic policies, wages and productivity policies, tax and industry policies. These have all impaired our competitive position. Many current economic policies are anti-trade. While we have enormous overseas debt problems, I insist that trade is vital. But the extent of our debt is too much just for increased exports to bail us out. Australia is already paying over $2 billion a day in interest alone on that debt. Just to hold the debt at the present level, our trade balance would need to improve by some $10 billion. Considering the fact that this year rural exports, our largest export sector, will bring in some $19 billion to double that figure would be totally unrealistic. Other measures must also be taken.

I have mentioned the other half of the equation-wages, productivity, tax and industrial relations policies, all of which play a part. A study commissioned by the National Farmers Federation from the Centre for International Economics is compulsory reading for anyone genuinely interested in improving our trade, and therefore Australia's economy. One hopes that it has been studied by the Government. It is the Government that taxes incentive out of the work force when it ought to be creating inducements for greater productivity. Increased productivity in the work force and an improved trade performance would turn this country around. A recent Australian Financial Review article summed the situation up well when it said:
Productivity is like love-a many splendoured thing.

A recent Economic Planning Advisory Council paper demonstrated Australia's dilemma when it said that gross domestic product per employee had fallen in 1986-87. It showed that Australian manufacturing was only about 80 per cent productive and the building and construction industry about 60 per cent. That is an appalling indictment of the malaise spreading across this nation. We seem to have an increasing number of people without a job and wanting to work, and an equal number of people with a job not wanting to work. We need fewer militant unions-it is nice to see Senator McKiernan in the chamber-dictating unaffordable terms to industry. We need fewer restrictive work practices. We need better industrial relations, less regulation and unnecessary bureaucracy and we need the ability to stand on our own feet in our industries. In short, we need to put commonsense back into the workplace.

The last area on which I wish to comment, and one which is relevant to present legislative discussions, is the role and function of local government. The Labor Government's record on local government is not good. Over the years it has frozen Commonwealth road funding, which in real terms means a cut of about 25 per cent, or $300m, in the past five years. General purpose assistance to local government has not increased in that time. Local government itself claims that in recent times it has spent more time and effort in arguing with other levels of government either to win back or to retain what it believes to be its rightful property. Local government authorities are understandably concerned at the prospect of yet another mini-Budget which chops their funding and allows them no avenue for complaint or appeal.

Of course, the referendum proposals will do nothing to improve this relationship and will not guarantee them a thing. Local government knows that it was the Labor Government that disbanded the only forum available to it, the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. Local authorities feel, with a fair deal of justification, that it is always other tiers of government that decide what is best for them. It is always another tier of government that controls how much they get from taxation. They also know that while the Federal Government is spending $6m to set up a Constitutional Commission and another $40m to run a referendum, it claims that money is not available for much needed roadworks in shires throughout Australia, particularly in my State of New South Wales.

It is these sorts of misguided priorities which have sent and are sending this country and its inhabitants broke. It is time that the Government took stock. Mini-Budgets provide only mini- solutions. We need bigger thinking and more permanent answers. This Government has to do something now-something it has neglected to do over the past four years-to make this country a better place for us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88. I direct attention to the Government's comments, particularly in referring to the economic miracle which, to use the expression of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), has allowed the Australian economy to turn the corner.
—Hear, hear! The J-curve.

—It has turned the corner, but it has turned the wrong way: it has turned downwards. It is quite clear that there never was going to be an economic miracle, and there never will be. With the exception of people such as the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, this Government has no right to claim a miracle from our God. Certainly Mr Hawke and Mr Keating are trying to convince the Australian public-and obviously have already seduced a significant part of the media into believing it-that the economy is now on the yellow brick road as opposed to the Argentinean road, but the truth is to be found elsewhere. In fact, on present indications the stark reality is that this is a delusion which can no longer continue.

SPEECH.PARA: One has only to look at the December quarter national account figures to see the exact state of our economy. The figures show that the total final domestic demand had increased by 2.5 per cent compared to the Budget estimate of 1.5 per cent, that private final consumption expenditure had risen by 2.6 per cent compared with a Budget estimate of 1.5 per cent and that private final domestic demand was up 3.3 per cent compared with the Budget estimate of 2.25 per cent. Clearly, the figures demonstrate that the economy is over-heated, in large part due to the fact that there has been substantial easing in monetary policy, instigated by the Government from 1987 onwards. That has inevitably led to a significant reduction in interest rates from the artificially high level at which they had previously been pitched due to the economic climate and circumstances in which we found ourselves and the Government's attempt to tighten up the economy.

Once we had an easing off in interest rates, this flowed through the economy, particularly in terms of consumer demand. That in itself was reflected in the February and March balance of payments result. The deficit on current account in March had deteriorated to $1,094m from the February figure of $764m and the January deficit of $389m. As expected, both figures showed a substantial blow-out in imports, the March figure being $3,733m-the worst import bill for more than a year. The April figure was substantially better, but in many respects this was due to seasonal circumstances. There was some reduction in imports of plant and equipment which shows that during that period there was a turndown in productive investment.

The current account figures were followed quickly by the release of the March quarter consumer price index figure which indicated a rise of 1.8 per cent-well above the estimated Government figure of 1.5 per cent. This has meant that Mr Keating's anticipated inflation rate of 6 per cent just cannot be achieved. Notwithstanding that 1.8 per cent quarter increase, the Treasurer has the audacity to stand before Australian people and declare that that figure indicates that there is a downward trend in Australia's inflation rate for the 1988-89 period and that it is likely to be as low as 5 per cent. That flies totally in the face of logic, for crude political reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what a miracle does.

—There is always a very logical reason for miracles, and Senator Tate would know that. The fact that the Treasurer is still prepared to defy gravity to persuade the people that the Government is doing a good job is, in my view, a cruel joke on the Australian community. I mentioned the recent fall in interest rates which has caused a real surge in domestic demand over the past year or so but, despite this, the Hawke Government has been blessed with strong world commodity prices since May 1986. In fact, it has been well blessed in the period that it has been in office. The sad thing is that it has squandered the blessings granted to it.

SPEECH.PARA: We had the breaking of the drought in 1983-84, and that was worth several million dollars to our economy, but what did the Government do with that extra revenue? Of course, it avariciously devoured it. If we look at the increase in world commodity prices, which is the underpinning structure for the apparent improvement in our economy, it can be seen that in November 1987, for example, international monetary funds indexed for non-oil commodity prices were 25 per cent higher than the first quarter of 1987.

The Westpac Banking Corporation estimates that if 1988 commodity prices maintain their recent high levels, in Australian dollar terms, a further 16 per cent increase can be expected. Accordingly, of course, with the excellent improvement, our terms of trade position rose last year by 7.5 per cent, and that has significantly improved the rising imports bill. However, it is significant that, excluding this term of trade result, our balance of payments position is still actually deteriorating and in fact did deteriorate over that same period. The reality is that there will be a slump in commodity prices, although I cannot be certain whether it will occur during the latter part of this year or in 1989. Without structural adjustment at a pace greater than that sought by this Government our current account deficit will again deteriorate dramatically on the back of the present excessive domestic demand. It is clear that there will be a significant decline in commodity prices and, as I have said, the question is when that will occur.

The commodities will be undermined owing to the predicted slowing of world economic growth in the medium term. The Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) expects that the slowing down in growth in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) area as a whole will show up in the latter half of this year and into the 1989 period. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, without my reading it, a table which summarises the projections for growth in gross national product for the major economies.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the slowing down in world growth, commodity prices will come under downward pressure. One of the most significant primary countries from Australia's point of view is the United States of America (USA), which consumes almost 12 per cent of our exports at something like $4 billion, and the other country is Japan which takes over 25 per cent of our exports at a figure of something like $9 billion. For the time being we are seeing the American domestic economy appearing to have strength.
—There must be an election coming up.

—Senator Tate is absolutely right; the fact that an election is coming up has meant that the hard issues, the hard decisions that should be addressed by the Democrats, the Republicans, the President, the Congress or the Senate have been ignored. In fact, they have all been shelved. As a result, there has been a move towards greater protectionism in the United States.
—They should have longer terms, shouldn't they?

—I think there is a great deal to be said for senators having six-year terms, and preferably eight years, so that there is continuity, certainty and stability. You would also have decision-makers prepared to make courageous decisions without being intimidated and threatened at the prospect of being turned out by the public because of short term pain.
—Making the place a rubber stamp for the House of Representatives.
—Absolutely-something that will never happen in this country.
—And therefore the Executive.

—And therefore the Executive, which would wish to put its tentacles through the House of Representatives, grasp the Senate and strangle its power, strangle its contribution and strangle its right to represent the people of the States. While the production sector of the United States' economy remains relatively strong, as I have said, there has been unchecked domestic spending and there have been significant fiscal imbalances in that country. As I have said, for the time being there has also been a suspension of macro-economic adjustments but, of course, they will have to be made in the near future, whether it be by George Bush or the successful Democrat candidate. Accordingly, Australia will be required to tighten its belt as the Americans come to grips with the enormous deficit that it is running. In September 1987 its balance of payments deficit was a `lazy' $156.8 billion. The US gross foreign debt in March 1987 was a `laid back' $601.96 billion. Therefore, the US Government will have to struggle with those problems and it will have to cool down the economy and reduce imports. The moment it does that it will significantly reduce demand for metal and mineral commodities, and that will spark off an incapacity for the Japanese to export into the American market at the present rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Once the Japanese market starts to slow down, it will promptly shunt into the Australian economy. Putting that aside for the moment, this country has for too long depended on commodities-farm and non-farm commodity resources-for its very financial existence and perhaps in the past its affluence. Perhaps we have ignored the fundamental signs which can be seen by anyone who lifts his head, and by the rest of the world. In terms of our wheat exports we have contemporary dumping by the United States and the European Economic Community (EEC). In relation to China, by the year 2000 that country, which has been one of our largest buyers of wheat, will be self-sufficient in food. India, another major buyer of our wheat, is now a gross exporter. In fact, 15 years ago 20 per cent of the Indian wheat harvest was retained and the rest was lost primarily because of poor storage facilities. That has now been corrected and the vast majority of Indian stocks are intact.

One has only to look at the minerals and metals area. Brazil and a number of South American countries are now opening mines and exporting to attract American dollars and foreign currency, and they are prepared to do it without significant profit. That will affect our market and the demand for our commodities. As we see, particularly in respect of high technology, there is a move away from the base metals. If we look at the metal components of a motor car now compared to those of a motor car 20 years ago we will see a dramatic reduction in metal but a great increase in the use of plastics, rubbers and fibres. It is now possible to put more telephone calls through a pound of plastic than a ton of copper. However, we still think that we have no need to keep up with the rest of the world in terms of the transfer of high technology, that we can keep dumping out our commodities into ships and that we will continue to survive. Of course we will not; of course we cannot. Of course, it is plain that in the face of a slowing world economy we cannot rely on improving our terms of trade or continue to allow our current account deficit to be the way it is.

As a result of the predicament into which the Labor Government has uniquely plunged us, it is highly likely that the current account deficit will, at best, persist at around $11 billion for the next financial year. That is about what we can anticipate for 1987-88. Accordingly, Australia's external debt and debt servicing burdens will continue to grow despite Mr Keating's insistence that the debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio can be stabilised at around 40 per cent by the early 1990s. Clearly our Treasurer has a secret that nobody else in this country knows about. He has a panacea. He himself has a formula for ensuring that there will be a dramatic change in our balance of payments and that there will be a roll-back in our debt and interest repayments. I wish he would let us all into the secret. I wish he would save us all the anxiety. He might tell us how he is going to do it. Perhaps in part he is going to retire some of our debt-retire it by Budget surpluses; Budget surpluses which flow from excess taxation. I remind honourable senators that at December 1987 Australia's gross external debt stood at $111.6 billion, with a net figure coming in at around $86.8 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much of that was private and how much of it was public?

—Two-thirds of it was private and one-third public. I inform Senator Tate that as long as it involves money owed overseas by Australia and there is not a corresponding inflow in assets this will still represent a debt for all Australians. Of course, the difference is not too subtle and the Minister is quite right. The interest payments alone on this debt amount to almost $8.8 billion, or 20 per cent of our total receipts from the export of all Australian goods and services. Perhaps even more staggering is the fact that interest and principal repayments represent 64 per cent of export receipts. That means that for every $10 earned from exports, $6 goes towards paying our foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: As we are all aware, Mr Hawke blames our critical, foreign debt position on the fall in our terms of trade over the 1985-86 period associated with a fall off in commodity prices. Of course, he does not blame it on his indolent indulgence with the public purse. He does not blame it on his own economic mismanagement. He blames it on circumstances beyond his control. Of course now that economic indicators relatively are marginally better this is his doing; this is his handiwork. Of course, this is cynicism of the highest order. Perhaps that is the reality of modern politics, but it is cynical by any measure. The truth of the matter is that the ordinary Australian is now paying for it through unprecedented levels of taxation. I ask honourable senators to consider the position that applied at the end of financial year 1983. At that time gross external debt stood at around $35.5 billion or about 21 per cent of GDP. Gross debt currently is operating at levels in excess of 40 per cent of GDP. The Prime Minister has just doubled the level of debt as a ratio of GDP. Further, the servicing requirements on interest in 1983 amounted to less than 12 per cent of export receipts. They are now running at levels of around 20 per cent. Of course, it is the extravagance of this Government, particularly in its earlier years, that has caused the problem.

Perhaps that extravagance is no better reflected than in the massive increases in the Government's own purpose general government outlays. Of course, the figures for own purpose general government outlays can be obtained by netting off from total outlays payments to or on behalf of other governments and public trading enterprises. I seek leave with the indulgence of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard tables showing the own purpose general outlays of both the Commonwealth and the States over the last seven years.
