TALK.START.PARA: —It can be seen from these figures that in 1982-83 Commonwealth own purpose outlays increased nominally by a massive 19.1 per cent. This was followed in 1983-84 by a rise of 18 per cent, a 15.4 per cent increase in 1984-85 and an 11.8 per cent increase in 1985-86. It can be seen that only in the last two years has the penny slowly dropped for this Government. It is only in the last two years that it has realised that there has to be restraint, a reining in of public sector expenditure. Of course, in spite of this, it is still significant that the amount spent in monetary terms by the Federal Government for its own purposes has in fact not decreased as a proportion of total outlays. It has not decreased in real terms. In fact, as a percentage of total outlays, the Hawke Government's own purpose outlays have increased from 60.6 per cent in 1982-83 to 65.7 per cent in 1987-88. Of course, this reflects the fact that the Hawke Government has the unique distinction-as have those members of the Government-of being the least caring, least compassionate, highest taxing, highest spending government in Australian peacetime history. That is how this Government will be remembered. For this Government to claim that Australia's recent better economic performance, as I say, relative as it might be, has been due to its better fiscal management is cynical in the extreme. The facts of the matter are that revenues received by this Government have increased at a far greater rate than inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the five years of the Hawke Government total revenue received has increased by about $34 billion. That is $34 billion extra that this Government gets which Malcolm Fraser's Government did not get when it was defeated. That represents an increase of 60 per cent. If we look at inflation over the same period we see that it has risen by about 39 per cent. Therefore, in real terms this Government has had the benefit of a 20 per cent increase in revenue. When one compares the increase in receipts to Government spending over the same period-that is an increase in receipts of $29.4 billion-it will be very obvious to the most elementary of economics students that the present expected Budget surplus will not be due to fiscal restraint but due to excesses in taxation. The excess in taxation receipts over the level of expenditure is the equation that gives the surplus. In fact, if revenue increases in real terms over 1988-89 by the projected figure of about 2.5 per cent, the Budget surplus for the next financial year will be $3 billion. It is very simple to have a Budget surplus if a government just keeps screwing people-that is, taxing the poor voters out there. Anybody can get a surplus. The trick is to reduce expenditure and maintain taxation at its present level. That is the answer, but this Government is not prepared to try it. This massive burden is not falling on the rich; it is falling on the average income earner.

Over the life of the Hawke Government, personal income tax has risen by about 40 per cent. For example, when the Hawke Government came to power, the proportion of average weekly earnings payable before deductions was 22.9 per cent. By 1986-87, the figure and jumped to 25 per cent. In the case of a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children, the proportion of total earnings paid in tax has risen from 14.1 per cent in 1982-83 to almost 18 per cent in 1986-87. The fact that these figures exist should come as no surprise when one considers the higher marginal rates of taxation now paid by the ordinary wage earner.

In June 1983, the effective marginal rate on the last dollar earned by a person on average weekly earnings was 30.67c. In 1986-87, a worker on average weekly earnings had taken from his pay packet, 45.395c on the last dollar he earned. A worker spends half of the last day of his working week working for the Government. He virtually goes to lunch before he starts to make any money for himself. Of course, the reason for that is obvious; it is the insidious bracket creep which is due, as we all know, to the effects of inflation.

By the financial year 1989-90, over 2.15 million Australian taxpayers will have crossed over into a higher tax bracket. In 1987-88 alone, 660,000 Australians will pay more tax than they did in the previous year. In the coming financial year, 760,000 people will pay more tax under this Government than they paid last year. And this Government talks about tax reductions, tax cuts! Try telling that to the poor soul out there who finds, every time he collects his pay packet, there is less in it. Where has the money gone? It has gone to the Government.

The tragedy is that this Government has taken money from taxpayers by stealth, through the insidious effects of inflation. The inflation rate will not fall to 5 per cent, as this Government predicts and pretends. Without doubt, by the end of the next financial year it will be 7 per cent. There is no economic miracle on the horizon. There is no economic miracle that the Australian people can expect. It is part of the Hawke Government's hypocrisy, deception and dishonesty in seeking to have people believe that under this Government, somewhere down the road there will be some form of relief. The truth of the matter can be found elsewhere. My guess is that the Australian public will no longer be deceived. The fact that we have witnessed two by-elections and seen the government ignominiously defeated is a clear indication that the Australian people are aware of the Government they elected. I am sure they are compelled to the view that only a Liberal-National coalition will promise them a genuine tax package and give them genuine relief and reform and a capacity to save and work for reward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise matters of concern to me which arose when Estimates Committee C examined the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Estimates Committee C met on Tuesday, 19 April and the Hansard record of that hearing is available to honourable senators. For some 20 minutes of that hearing I asked questions on a couple of matters to which I wish to refer this evening. Most of the answers were given by Mr J. Mullarvey, Assistant Secretary, Tertiary Statistics and Operations Branch, in the presence of the Minister attending the hearing of Estimates Committee C, Senator Walsh, and other senators on that Committee. I am very troubled by the answers I was given in two areas. By setting out these concerns now, I alert the Department and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that I wish to have more satisfactory, complete and truthful answers to the matters which I raised.

SPEECH.PARA: The first broad area concerns higher education statistics collection. I have been concerned for some months, indeed, since late last year, at the new level of data being required by the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training on every student in higher education-more than 40,000 students-and now on every staff member in higher education. In fact, I estimate that the unit records affect about half a million Australians. There are towards 20 elements of data on each of these half a million Australians. It is my understanding that next year the elements of data on these individuals will rise to more than 30 items.

I have two concerns. The first is that the original data was given by enrolling students and employed staff in our higher education institutions on a confidential basis to the institution of which they were a part, but, by statutory provision, the Minister and the Department are requiring up to 30 items of information on these half a million Australians and, if they are not received, the institution will not receive its grant. This leads to two quite massive problems. One is the insecurity of the data coming from 65 higher education institutions to one databank in Canberra. Who has access to that databank and what safeguards are in place to guarantee that the information is used even for the purposes for which it was given?

It is my knowledge, and I was told this in the Estimates Committee, that there are no statutory safeguards to guard that information. There is nothing to stop the Minister, for example, asking for data on any individual student or staff member. Let me hasten to add that the names of students and staff members are not filed at the same point as the items of data of each individual student and each individual staff member. But, as I will go on to describe in a moment, the date of birth, the home postcode, the course being undertaken, whether a student or staff member is male or female, the individual's qualifications, the course enrolled in and the course taught, are all set out. If even three or four of these items are known, one could very quickly guess with the aid of a general list or some background information which individual the data entry concerns.

I note that earlier this year there was a furore when the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) was accused of breaking the law in releasing to a backbencher in the House of Representatives some health information concerning doctors and patients. It was subsequently found, after inquiry, that the Minister had not strictly broken the law, but certainly he regretted that he had given this information, which was improperly released. There is a statutory bar in the area of health. There is a law that prohibits the misuse of such information. However, I was told in the Estimates Committee that there is no such law with regard to the databank on half a million Australians to which I am referring. There is no statutory provision under which one could deal with any abuse that may arise.

I believe that the assurances and solemn guarantees that are being given to students and staff by the 65 registrars of the higher education institutions concerned that the material they are gathering will be confidential are not now worth the paper they are written on. All of the data about students who enrol for higher education in this country or staff members in higher education institutions is open to abuse. This information will be listed in a databank and the confidentiality of that material is now directly under threat.

The second major concern is that there has been a massive increase in the amount of data transferred to Canberra. Up until 1977 no information was sent to Canberra about individual students, and certainly not about individual staff members. However, over the last decade some unit record level data has been recorded for university students only. A few items are involved. But last year, for the first time, data on students attending colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology was also transferred. This year, for the first time, data concerning all staff in the advanced education sector and the university sector is being transferred.

There has been a threefold increase in the number of individuals concerned. Also, there has been a massive increase in the number of people involved and in the amount of information collected about each individual. The number of items on which data is collected has grown from six to 15, with 30 items in prospect for next year. This massive increase in data will serve directly the present Labor Government's intention to manage higher education from Canberra through the Minister and through the Department of Employment, Education and Training. This is being done in spite of a century of an accepted tradition of autonomy in our higher education institutions and against the assumptions of staff and students alike in those institutions. I believe that not only is confidentiality under threat but also this development is becoming an instrument of the Labor Government's corporatist management of higher education in Australia.
A departmental letter dated 5 February 1988 claimed:
By collecting information at the unit record level (i.e. a record for each staff member and each student) the Department will in theory be able to collect whatever information it chooses.

The Commonwealth has recently amended the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act so that it provides that the Department can withhold the payment to an Institution of normal periodic grant payments `where an institution fails to provide to the Minister, by the due date validated statistical data'.

The data currently sought by the Department, under that compulsion, in relation to staff members-and this is happening this year for the first time-includes: an institution code; a person identification code, which is a unique number; sex of the staff member; date of birth; length of tenure; substantive classification type; level and increment; whether the staff member is full time or fractional; length of term in current duties; current classification type, level and increment; classification group; organisational unit of staff member; work sector; function-for example, teaching, research or some combination; the full time equivalence of the staff appointment; the full time equivalence in the year preceding; the citizenship of that staff member; the substantive salary for the position occupied; and the actual salary paid. I understand that additional elements are to be added next year.

The data being sought for each student, including some items proposed for next year, includes: the institution code; the course; the course type; the field of study; the student identification code, which is a unique number for each of the 400,000 students of Australia; the date of birth of the student; sex; whether the student is Aboriginal or a Torres Strait Islander; whether the student is an overseas student; the semester residence-I do not know whether that means the precise address; the home postcode of the student; the highest qualification the student has reached; the year the student completed secondary schooling; previous courses attempted; the basis of admission; the date the student commenced his course; attendance mode and type-that is, whether the student is full time or falls into some other category; course specialisation; academic organisational unit; the discipline group of course; the equivalent full time student unit value-that is, the degree of part time or full time enrolment; the country of birth of the student; the year of arrival in Australia; and the language spoken by the student at home.

The Department also seeks a fee paying indicator. It wants an indication of the fee that has been determined. As honourable senators opposite know, fees are already established with regard to an administration charge and some post-graduate courses. A pay later fee at least has been proposed by the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding. Overseas students pay fees of two quite different types. This fee paying indicator will, therefore, apply to every student. Data will also be sought on the minimum completion time of the course for which a student has enrolled, as will completion rate information. A great number of elements are required, especially next year, to measure the degree of progress that a student is making through a course.

Why does Canberra need to have all of this information, which otherwise would be confined to the education institution in which a student is enrolled or to which a staff member is appointed? The need for the information to be collected at the unit record level is explained by the Department as allowing it to maximise the `ability to generate reports that will meet the requirements of users'. Departmental officers have explained that the unit record information was needed since they could not foresee all the needs for information but could meet them as they eventuated if they had the base data. In other words, aggregate information about students and staff of a general or summary kind is not good enough if Canberra wants to manage 65 higher education institutions or to look up any precise matter with regard to an individual staff member or an individual student. This Labor Government is wanting to gather individual files on half a million Australians, on all those leaders and potential leaders of the future who are going to be involved with higher education. This creeping Big Brother state, I think, takes even honourable senators opposite somewhat by surprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —You forgot the sisters.

—Is Senator Reynolds happy with the situation? She does not answer. Her husband happens to be one of those people who, as a staff member in a higher education institution, has a file in the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I am convinced that the majority of students and staff members do not know that this is the situation and would be horrified that information is being transferred for the management purposes of this Government-or at least its aspirations, for we do not know what the outcome will be until the White Paper comes down and there are some decisions in the Budget period. Those people ought to be horrified not only at the management style that is going to take autonomy from institutions but also at the totally inadequate security set up to maintain confidentiality of that information.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it, maybe somewhat hypothetically, that if the Minister for Employment, Education and Training wants to know the background of all the student representative council members in an institution, with a little information he could match up information he may have with files available in his Department-and there is nothing to stop him. Let me outline the questions I put. They are set out on page c41 of Estimates Committee C Hansard of 19 April. I had introduced this area of my concern, as is clear from the preceding pages. Then I asked:
The Minister does not have access to it?-
meaning the data that is accumulated. Mr Mullarvey replied:
The Minister does not . . .

That was his first answer. However, because I was not satisfied, I asked the question a second time and I got an evasion. I asked the question a third time and got an evasion. I asked it a fourth time and was distracted again. I asked the question a fifth time and-honourable senators could not guess the result-the answer was 100 per cent different; it was totally different from the first answer I got. I will read my question and then the answer:

TALK.START.PARA: —You said, Mr Mullarvey, that no officer of the Department has the ability to look up the individual data on any one unit file. What is there to stop the Minister from looking it up?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mullarvey-There is nothing to stop the Minister looking it up.

Yet, a matter of minutes earlier, on the first time of my asking he said the opposite. It is just not good enough for a departmental official-and there are 3,500 departmental officials in that Department-or the Minister to be able to look up individual files on students and staff. I am not satisfied with the administrative arrangements that are alluded to from time to time with regard to access to this material. I am not satisfied that, although there is only an identifier number, the identity of the student or staff member concerned cannot relatively easily be determined. I seek leave to have incorporated in my speech a series of 21 questions. That will save reading these pages that flow on from this matter.
Leave granted.
The questions read as follows-
1. What information is currently obtained by the Federal Government from universities and colleges of advanced education relating to students and staff?
2. What are the exact questions being asked of universities and colleges relating to students and staff?
3. What questions were asked of universities and colleges relating to students and staff in:
4. Are extra questions to be asked of institutions of higher education regarding students and staff in 1989?
5. If so, what extra information is to be gathered?
6. Do institutions of higher education have any choice in supplying information regarding staff and students?
7. How is the information stored by the Department?
8. Are identifier numbers tagged on to individual student and staff records?
9. What use is currently made of the statistics on students and staff gathered by the Department?
10. What safeguards exist to protect data collected on students and staff?
11. Are any extra safeguards planned?
12. Is it true that extra information is being gathered in anticipation of proposals outlined in the Government's `Higher Education Green Paper'?
13. If this is true, what use is to be made of the information gathered?
14. What provisions in the Green Paper make it necessary for the Department to gather increased information?

15. Is it now possible for officers of the Australian Taxation Office or the Department of Finance to gain access to any information on students or staff held by the Department of Employment, Education and Training?
16. If so, what information are they able to gain access to?
17. What officers in the Department of Employment, Education and Training can gain access to information on students and staff gathered from institutions of higher education?
18. How many officers does this represent?
19. What safeguards prevent officers of other Commonwealth departments or bodies from accessing this information?
20. Is it technically possible for files on individual students and staff to be linked to their actual names?
21. Is it technically possible to match information on individual students and staff with other records held by the Commonwealth, so as to identify the name of the individuals?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The 21 questions that I have set out are urgent and need to be answered. I am looking for answers from the Minister and the Department. Later today I will put these questions to the Minister on the Notice Paper. I also seek leave to have incorporated that short section of Hansard on page C41 to which I have already referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister does not have access to it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mullarvey-The Minister does not neither do--

TALK.START.PARA: —What would stop the Minister? Is there a statutory bar?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mullarvey-I make the point that giving people access to record 2,000 is going to tell them nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am asking a question. What would stop the Minister asking for the precise item as recorded--
—He would have more useful things to do, I would expect, for one.

—I agree with you, Minister, but I am asking because people are concerned. I would just remind the Estimates Committee about the Australia Card debate. I am not drawing an exact parallel here. I take your request to me to withdraw any prejudice that this is like the Australia Card.
—You are making the inference.
—No. It is a new area of massive data collection. What is to stop the Minister from reading an individual's data?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mullarvey-It is not a new area of data collection. The Commonwealth has been collecting this data since 1977 for universities which comprise approximately half of our total enrolments. It was extended to the advanced education sector in 1987 so that the Commonwealth would have comparable data across the area into which it puts considerable funds. It is not a new area which the Commonwealth has gone into.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said, Mr Mullarvey, that no officer of the Department has the ability to look up the individual data on any one unit file. What is there to stop the Minister from looking it up?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Mullarvey-There is nothing to stop the Minister looking it up. But I come back to the point that you made that this is a new area of collection of data. I reiterate that it is not. The Commonwealth has been there since 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again thank the Senate. I now come to my concern at the answer I was given by this responsible public servant. It gives me no pleasure to doubt a servant of the Commonwealth, a senior member of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. But I have already indicated that it was with a great deal of reluctance, and after I had asked the question five times, that I got an answer to the question I had put about the Minister's access to the information. On another matter, which was answered by the same officer, I gained a similarly quite unsatisfactory response. I wish to refer to it. On page C47 of the same Hansard I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Could I put a question on notice? How many persons who were employed by CTEC at any point during 1987 have now resigned from not only CTEC but the Department? What level of employment did those persons hold before they resigned?
I was just putting that question on notice. Senator Walsh said:
We will take that on notice.
Just to gain an approximate answer I then said:
There is a substantial number I understand, Minister, of such officers who no longer work for the Commonwealth.
Mr Mullarvey then answered:
I am not sure that there are substantial numbers; I think there were two, but, as we have said, it needs to be taken on notice.

I put a number of questions on notice during that hearing of Estimates Committee C and I received answers in writing more than a week ago but I have not received an answer on this matter. I remind the Senate that I have just said that the officer said, `I think there were two'. My response to that was, `That surprises me'. Because it surprised me I made some inquiries. I make the point that I have not yet got any detailed further information from the Department. I am certainly looking for it before we have a Committee of the Whole debate on these Bills. Much to the contrary to there being only two people who have left, all have left save one, who happens to be Mr Mullarvey.

Is it credible that the senior officers of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission that is about to be disbanded-the House of Representatives is debating right at this moment that the CTEC legislation be abolished in favour of the new legislation for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET)-have all gone? Those senior officers had a 15-year period of operation and contributed a great deal to this country. We used to receive CTEC reports every year, including many reports on particular matters. Let me list some of the officers. They include Professor Don McNicol, Commissioner for Universities, who became Vice-Chancellor of the University of New England after completing little more than one year of a seven-year term. Mr Chris Burgess, Secretary to the Universities Council, became business manager at Griffith University after some 15 years public service. Mr Bob Arthur, former Assistant Commissioner, recurrent programs of CTEC, has transferred to the Canberra School of Art. Mr Hunter Grahame, former Assistant Commissioner, Executive Branch of CTEC, has been retired. Ms Margaret Groube, head of the CTEC Equity Section has resigned from the Commonwealth Public Service. Dr Gregor Ramsey, Acting Chairman of the Higher Education Council and formerly Chairman of the Advanced Education Council, departed for an appointment in New South Wales, but it was not proceeded with and he has returned to an acting position in the Department.

So, in effect, the former senior echelon of CTEC, both statutory and non-statutory, has been disbanded. Mr Lance Hennessy is another officer who has departed to be a Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the University of Newcastle. It should also be taken into consideration that from the senior ranks of the former Commonwealth Department of Education, which had a major involvement in this area, Mr Charles Beltz, First Assistant Secretary, is no longer in the Department; John Wilson, First Assistant Secretary, at the age of 53 has retired early; Peter Bowler, another First Assistant Secretary aged 53, has retired early; Bob Allen, a First Assistant Secretary, is no longer there; John Burnett, an Assistant Secretary, has left at age 49; as has Ian Ward; and that is by no means all.

I put to the Senate: how is it credible for the particular public servant involved, who was so evasive on the matter that I put seriously to him over a considerable period of the Estimates Committee proceedings, to then say to me in the clear light of day that he thought that two of his immediate colleagues-because he himself worked in CTEC-had left that organisation. However, there was a wide range; in fact, the whole of CTEC has blown apart and all the officers to whom I have referred have gone off to work in various institutions away form the Commonwealth Department of Education, Employment and Training. That expertise has been lost to the Commonwealth and to Australia, and we have a completely clean slate for the Department and for its apparent successor to CTEC, namely, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training.

It gives me no cheer to question the veracity, or credibility at least, of a senior public servant who ought to know better and who ought to have given a clear, comprehensive and truthful answer during that Estimates Committee. As a senator attending an Estimates Committee I do not appreciate being misled, and I ask that a comprehensive written answer be provided by the time we consider this matter in committee. That same officer gave me inadequate answers with regard to the statistical collections of the Department. That officer is in fact in charge of the statistical collections of the Department. Does it give us here in the Senate any great sense of comfort that these serious matters are being so off-handedly described as being in safe custody, under good management, that confidentiality will not be breached and that the statistics are all being collected for good purposes? It certainly does not give me any comfort, and I will not be comforted until there is a law that describes the kind of information that can be gathered and the statutory or legal basis on which confidentiality of the material is kept.

I also believe that there should be an advisory committee, made up of representatives of higher education institutions-registrars, vice-chancellors, and the like-whose advice would be given in regard to the type of information to be collected, how it would be used, and how it would be safeguarded. I am not convinced that the rather informal consultations with the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education have been of any substance at all, and I continue to be concerned about that matter. In conclusion, I directly criticise the Government for its lax approach to these sensitive and important matters and for the fact that in a period of massive information gathering it has not seen fit to put in place the kinds of guarantees that I am calling for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in the cognate debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89, I want to raise a matter that is of great concern to the Australian Democrats. I refer to the $240 administrative fee which is charged to potential migrants who ask for a review of status. This new fee was included in the Budget last year, which was brought down on 15 September. The fee has been collected since 17 September, despite the fact that the relevant clause in the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 failed to pass through this place. The explanatory memorandum indicates:

SPEECH.PARA: Subclause 9 (a) provides that a fee will be able to be prescribed for appeals against certain prescribed decisions taken under the Migration Act . . . The provision, and the first regulations made under the provision, are expressed (by clause 2) to come into effect on 16 September 1987.

During my speech on the second reading of the Bill, which I made on 9 December, I distributed my amendment to that clause which, in fact, sought to delete the clause. The Democrats are against this fee for a number of reasons. For the most part, migration decisions are reviewed by panels, which are known as immigration review panels. These are, one might say, a disaster area. A recent report by the Administrative Review Council, the Review of Migration Decisions August 1986, has drawn attention to the many deficiencies and has proposed many changes to immigration review panels and the way that they operate.

I shall briefly list some of the problems. Appellants have no right to appear before an immigration review panel and no right to be heard. Members of the immigration review panels are appointed by the Minister. They work to guidelines laid down by the Minister. They are only advisory; the Minister need pay no attention to their recommendations. There is an enormous backlog of appeals. In short, the international review panels are very poorly regarded by the ethnic communities and the social workers and the other professionals who work in the immigration area. By comparison, appeal procedures in respect of social security and veterans' entitlement decisions are regarded as being fair and efficient. They are undertaken by panels which are independent of the Minister and of the department involved, and appellants do not have to pay a fee to have their appeal heard.

There are also problems with the migrant fee on equity grounds. For example, it will apply to residents seeking to nominate a relative whose application has been rejected and who wants to appeal against the decision. Because we are now accepting a lower number of refugees many refugee families now in Australia are seeking to sponsor relatives from refugee camps in South East Asia under family reunion provisions. Because they are recent arrivals themselves, many of these people are among the poorest of the poor. To sponsor the refugees they have to be ready to pay air fares and to put up maintenance guarantees and, inevitably, they are involved in other costs. For these people a fee of $240 is an enormous sum of money, and the effect is discriminatory. Well-off families will be able to lodge appeals while the poor will not. They are some of the reasons why the Australian Democrats sought to reject that fee.

When the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 went through this chamber, the Opposition also opposed the $240 fee, but for different reasons-reasons related to the way in which the accompanying regulations had been drawn up. In fact, at the time the Opposition gave an undertaking that, when the Government reintroduced this provision with the accompanying regulations drawn up to the Opposition's satisfaction, the Opposition would vote for it. I have twice asked questions in this place about the collection of the $240 fee for review of migration decisions. I asked the first question on 15 December 1987 and another question on 24 April 1988. Thus, I asked the first question before the legislation had passed through this place and the second question after it had passed.

In December I was told by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, as Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that about $400,000 had already been collected. Just a few weeks ago I was told that the sum collected is now $1m, despite the fact that the fee is regarded in some legal quarters as lacking legality. In answer to my most recent question, I was told by the Minister that the Government has in fact received the advice of Queen's Counsel. Nonetheless, there are legal opinions that say the fee is not legal. In effect, the situation is that since 17 September the Government has been collecting a fee for which there is no legislative justification. If legislation was not required, why did the Government include such a clause in the Migration Amendment Bill? If it is required, then surely the Government is showing contempt for the parliamentary process.

I briefly refer to the fact that also included in the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 was another clause related to government funding. I refer to the $5 arrival fee. My amendment to reject that clause was opposed by both the Government and the Opposition, as was my second amendment to delay the implementation of the arrival fee until 1 March. I remind the Senate that this debate took place towards mid-December.

Thus there are two fees as a result of the Migrant Amendment Bill. One is being collected, although the legislation has not been passed. In the other case, legislation did pass, but some people pay the $5 on arrival and some people do not. I believe that both these matters require urgent attention and I am pleased to have been able to bring them before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the major items of expenditure in the Budget is the amount we spend on defence. This year it amounts to a little under 10 per cent of the total Budget, or about 2.8 per cent of the gross national product. I want to take this opportunity to speak about a very small component of the Budget which may or may not come out of the defence allocation but which has to come from somewhere. It concerns Australia's contribution to the verification of disarmament agreements and the potential for further developing our input as a middle ranking world power.

SPEECH.PARA: Verification is topical at the moment, as the United States of America Senate debates ratification of the intermediate-range nuclear force agreement, and I am hoping that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, will speak further on the subject of verification when he addresses the United Nations special session on disarmament in New York on 31 May. Verification is absolutely vital towards the success of any disarmament agreement, and Australia has worked hard in two areas where I feel the Government should be commended. I refer to work towards a chemical weapons ban and on the seismic monitoring of nuclear testing.

Our commitment to a comprehensive test ban is well known in the international community, but it has been totally blocked by the refusal of our great friend and ally the United States, which says that such a test ban is a long way off and can only follow deep cuts in strategic weapons, confidence building measures, a balance in conventional forces and improved verification procedures. So a lot of the good work done by our diligent Australian team at the conference on disarmament in Geneva is undermined by the United States Government, which clearly does not support a comprehensive test ban despite opposition to its policy from millions of its own citizens. In fact, more than 75 per cent of United States citizens support a comprehensive test ban.

I am also critical of the totally inadequate safeguards attached to the export of Australian uranium, and I refer in particular to a recent article in the Weekend Australian on 7 May about a United States television documentary entitled `The Terror Trade-Buying the Bomb'. This program dealt with the blackmarket nuclear weapons trade that goes on in Khartoum, the capital of the Sudan, where sales of millions of dollars worth of nuclear weapons materials have occurred since 1980.

Libya, South Africa, Argentina, Brazil, Iraq, Iran, Syria, Pakistan, India and the Palestine Liberation Organisation reportedly were involved in the auction-style deals, with uranium and plutonium apparently filched from nuclear processing plants in Western Europe. One of the people interviewed in the program was former Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Admiral Stansfield Turner, who confirmed that the source of the material for the black market is civilian nuclear power plants. Given that Australian uranium is sold to a number of countries in Western Europe, I must admit that I have even further doubts about our safeguards and the ability of the relevant agencies actually to trace nuclear materials around the total nuclear fuel cycle.

The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) spoke of the importance of verification when he opened the conference on Checking the Arms Race: Australia's Role in International Verification, which was held in Sydney from 13 to 15 May and which was organised by Scientists Against Nuclear Arms and People for Nuclear Disarmament in New South Wales. Mr Beazley pointed out that more verification would be needed for future agreements, for example, the strategic arms reduction talks agreement which is now a prospect on the horizon if the talks between the United States and the Soviet Union are successful.

The lead speaker, Dr Jeremy Leggett, Director of the Verification Technology Information Centre in London, pointed out that the relentless march of nuclear weapons technology makes verification of warhead reduction treaties increasingly difficult. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 17 May, Dr Leggett wrote:

Events surrounding the ratification of December's treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces are making it increasingly clear that not enough effort is being put into verification strategies to back up the proposals which are being tabled in the negotiations. For these reasons, there has never been a more opportune moment for non-nuclear-weapon states, like Australia, to carve a larger stake in arms control verification.

In a paper given to the conference, Dr Leggett pointed out that three of the last six directors of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency have complained about the inadequacy of verification technology development. The select committee on intelligence report concluded that a verification agency should be set up and several hundred million dollars of extra funding should be diverted to the test ban verification research effort. At present some $US70m is directed to test ban verification research annually, of which up to $US40m is dedicated to seismology. Given that the total United States defence budget is well over $US300 billion, that is actually a very small amount.

In both the United States and the United Kingdom little or no work is going into the non-seismological aspects of verifying a test ban. In the Soviet Union it is difficult to judge its preparedness on verification technology because of past obsessive secrecy, but we can hope that the situation will improve under the leadership of Mikhail Gorbachev. Who would have foreseen even three years ago that the Soviet Union would allow American inspectors to wander around its nuclear test sites and missile plants? The improved position of the Soviet Union concerning on-site verification is indeed welcome.

So we return to the question posed by Dr Leggett concerning the contribution that non-nuclear weapon states can make to this situation, bearing in mind the statement of the Minister for Defence on the vital necessity of verification for future agreements. Dr Leggett suggested that by ending the superpower monopoly on systematic surveillance from space, non-nuclear weapon states can begin to break down the secrecy which underpins competition between the superpowers and so constipates their efforts to achieve bilateral treaties. Further, he suggested that, by becoming more involved in basic verification research, such nations can encourage the superpowers to move more rapidly towards multilateral negotiations.

One major proposal floated at the conference and discussed by a number of Australian and overseas speakers was for a multilateral satellite monitoring agency. Such an agency could use existing satellites or its own custom built system in a number of areas. None would allow the independent verification of an entire treaty but all would foster the prospects of current treaties being adhered to, or of future treaties being signed, and of their being verified satisfactorily after coming into force.

The conference heard a number of proposals from Japan and Canada, as well as Australia, about satellite programs and also from Ken Muirhead of the Australian Seismological Centre in Canberra about Australia's work on seismological monitoring. Dr Peter Dunn, Superintendent of the Material Research Laboratories in the Department of Defence in Melbourne, also spoke of Australia's work on a chemical weapons ban and the possibilities and difficulties of verification in this area. We must bear in mind his warning of the likely proliferation of chemical weapons by poorer countries in the next 10 years. In fact, the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, referred to chemical weapons as the poor man's nuclear weapon.

Money spent on verification that could lead to an agreement in this area would be well spent if it prevents casualties such as those in the Iran-Iraq war recently. I commend the Government on Australia's contribution to a chemical weapons ban. I am talking about the imbalance in the amount of money spent on preparing for war and the amount spend on preparing for peace and disarmament or, more specifically, preparing technologies for destruction of warheads that already exist and for developing technologies for the prevention of war.

Given the amount that we are spending in Australia on defence and the little we seem to be spending on conflict resolution, training in negotiating skills, peace research and so on, I hope that we will see fit to follow up some of the proposals arising from the conference. I hope that Australia will choose to spend less on lethal hardware, which only seems to make us less secure. I certainly would welcome more work on disarmament verification, to which Australia could contribute, rather than heeding the calls for nuclear submarines and aircraft carriers, for example, which are regularly trotted out by the Liberal-National Party spokespersons on defence. Having such extravagant military hardware will simply trigger off a regional arms race rather than reducing tension in the area.

This conference, which brought together scientists from six middle ranking countries plus experts on international law and peace activists and so was very useful in that respect, had one overwhelming message. It was this: there is enormous potential for international verification to occur. In fact, there are few scientific impediments to thorough verification of any international disarmament treaty, particularly in the nuclear field. What is missing is the political will to ensure that the brain power of scientists internationally is directed towards devising such technically feasible verification measures. It was generally agreed that it is a continuing responsibility of participants in the conference to sell verification as a very important disarmament issue.

From Australia's point of view, we are engaged in helping the United States with not only its national means of verification but also its tracking and targeting of Soviet military installations, warships and submarines and Soviet cities with nuclear weapons. When the suggestion of the internationalisation of the facilities at Pine Gap was raised-that is, the use of that technology to benefit the world community rather than just the United States-the Minister said quite clearly that the United States would not like it; the United States would feel insecure. That is a pathetic position for an Australian Minister for Defence-the United States would not like it, so Australia would not even bother suggesting it. In answer to another question, the Minister declined to answer on the grounds of national security-not our national security, of course, but United States national security. On alliance questions, the Australian Defence Minister time and again seems to put the needs of the United States Government ahead of the security needs of Australian people.

The Australian people-indeed, the world's people-would be much better served by Australia participating in the verification of nuclear disarmament treaties from an international perspective rather than our country being used by one superpower to spy on the other. It is my hope that the Australian Government will not only continue its good work on a chemical weapons ban and nuclear testing verification, but also make available increased funding towards international nuclear disarmament verification measures.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANBERRA INSTITUTE OF THE ARTS ORDINANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 17 standing in my name for the disallowance of the Canberra Institute of the Arts Ordinance 1988, as contained in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 1 of 1988, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. The Canberra Institute of the Arts Ordinance 1988 is intended to establish the Canberra Institute of the Arts as an independent educational institution to foster the achievement of excellence in the study at tertiary and other levels of music, visual arts and crafts and other fields of the arts. The creation of the institute involves the amalgamation of two long-established schools, the Canberra School of Music and the Canberra School of Arts. In the explanatory statement for the ordinance, the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) expressly states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Institute of the Arts is expected to be a more independent body similar to a university and is invested with greater freedom of action and powers of self-government.

The institute is to award degrees, diplomas and certificates. The institute conducts courses at post-graduate level also. The institute attracts students from every State of Australia and from overseas. In the School of Music 40 per cent of the full-time undergraduate students and 80 per cent of the post-graduate students are from outside the Australian Capital Territory. All the people with whom I have discussed the new institute over the last several months agree that the establishment of the new institute is a sound move. These people-they include students, elected staff representatives of both schools, the executive chairperson and the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation-are also agreed that the mode of governance proposed for the new institute is totally unsatisfactory, and indeed some claim that it will be a disaster.

Tertiary institutions throughout Australia, and indeed throughout the world, are normally governed by governing councils with wide representation. All those who have a stake in the institution have at least some say in its affairs. Meetings are essentially public so that those affected have some opportunity to know how, and on what grounds, decisions come to be made. However, the Canberra Institute of the Arts is to be governed by a tiny board of three persons, an executive chairperson and the directors of its two schools. This triumvirate is at once the governing body and the body for the hearing of appeals, and the management body also, and is to be supported by an advisory committee composed mainly of ministerial appointees. The beginnings of discontent are already in evidence at the institute in relation to the decisions of the board. Recently, for example, a dispute arose over the first combined graduation of the new institute-resulting in ill feeling between the schools and complaints by staff and students.

Honourable senators may wonder how it has come about that we are discussing an ordinance to establish an institute, and I am talking as though that institute already exists. It must appear confusing to the Senate. In fact, it is the Government and the ACT Administration that are confused, for the institute has indeed already been set up without the authority of this Parliament, and the three-person board is already operating. If the Senate has the power to allow or disallow the making of ordinances, the Government must be condemned for implementing its decisions as if the decisions of the Senate were a foregone conclusion. I look forward to hearing what the Liberals have to say about the contemptuous way in which the Government is treating this chamber in regard to this ordinance and other ordinances.

The situation that we confront today owes a great deal to a pattern set by the former Minister, Mr John Brown. His intention was to follow corporate models and to streamline and centralise power in educational institutions. This institute has been set up in such a way that will be easy for the ACT Administration to manipulate its affairs and to deny it the sort of independence, coordination and unity which would enable it to stand up for its independence when John Dawkins's vultures of amalgamation, rationalisation and economic realism gather. This impression is greatly heightened by events over the last 24 hours. Since it became clear that the Australian Democrats were prepared to stand up for the institute and press hard for a sensible and workable set of governance arrangements which would allow the institute to establish itself properly, the people concerned have been quite simply pressured into accepting the will of the Government. They have been told that, if this ordinance is disallowed, the arrangements will lapse altogether and the schools will revert to being managed by the ACT Administration, or that they may be amalgamated very shortly with the Canberra College of Advanced Education. The institute is therefore faced with a choice between an unworkable form of independence and no independence at all.

Over the past several days I have discussed the governance arrangements with the Minister and have sought improvements. In these discussions I have done my best to represent the views and wishes of the people involved. The Minister agreed to expand the advisory committee and to provide for staff and student representation. This was a significant improvement. In an exchange of letters today he has made further undertakings which, while they leave us far short of a truly satisfactory outcome, nevertheless offer a few crumbs of comfort to the staff and students. The Minister has undertaken that if self-government does not supervene, he will ensure that a proper and thorough review of the governance arrangements will be made before 31 May 1989 and that careful consideration will be given to the recommendations which result from that review. In these circumstances I am prepared to withdraw my motion of disallowance. During the coming months I will carefully monitor developments at the institute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This discussion in so far as it relates to the arrangements for governance of the Canberra Institute of the Arts is not really about democracy in the institute or efficiency in its management. I regret to say that it is essentially about cheer-chasing. It is about the pursuit of every little interest group that might have the capacity to deliver one or more votes to the Australian Democrats. There are two very good reasons why this is the wrong time to be making a major review of the management arrangements for the Canberra Institute of the Arts. First is the impending, we hope, onset of self-government. It seems to me that what is taking place now proves exactly why this Senate and the Federal Government are inappropriate bodies to be making decisions about governance of Canberra-based tertiary institutions, as they were for making decisions about the structure of the Schools Authority or institutes of technical and further education. It is entirely inappropriate that we should be having this debate in this chamber at this time, but there is no other forum pending self-government.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing to do is to say that we should not be making such major institutional changes on what should be, with a reasonable level of cooperation, the eve of self-government. Secondly, we have the Green Paper on the structure of tertiary education in Australia, which at the moment is undergoing serious and important discussion, and that discussion should go ahead in a context in which the Canberra Institute of the Arts can properly be examined. I wish in a moment to come back to say something specific about the Institute of the Arts and its future. The Government and the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch)-I acknowledge that Senator Jenkins also referred quite properly to this-are not inflexible on the subject of governance. There are the changes to which Senator Jenkins correctly referred, in particular the undertaking that a review will take place within 12 months. I am happy to say also that the Minister, in response to approaches by other senators including me, is prepared to give a guarantee that he will ensure that the advisory council will include at least one member with qualifications and interest in music and one member with qualifications and interest in arts and crafts. I regard that as an appropriate guarantee. I suspect that without the guarantee that would have taken place anyway, but it is appropriate to make that clear.

I have been to look at the institute. I have visited and spoken with the staff and the students. I value the institute. I think that it will make an outstanding contribution and will develop as a centre of excellence, but the point I want to make in addition to the general points I have made about its governance, is that at the moment it needs stability. It has just gone through the amalgamation process. The last thing we need is constant discussion about the process of review and change in the organisation. We do not want a discussion about it being amalgamated with the Australian National University or the Canberra College of Advanced Education or about changing its governing body every week, every month or every few months. I think it needs a bit of stability, and it does not need cheer chasing or a cast of thousands. It needs appropriate interim arrangements. In my view, in the long term the current management arrangements will not last and they will need to be changed. I have some views in relation to those long term modifications and I have expressed them to the Minister. At the moment the institute needs a period of stability and it is entirely appropriate that these interim arrangements should persist either until there is self-government or at least for a period of 12 months to provide the badly needed stability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The coalition is pleased with the development of the Canberra Institute of the Arts combining the Schools of Music and Arts and acknowledges that there were some problems. As a consequence of negotiations that we, I suppose like the Australian Democrats, have had with the Government, the Government has now given certain undertakings as mentioned by Senator McMullan, namely, that the matter will be reviewed within an acceptable period and, of the five members to be appointed to the Council by the Minister, at least one will have specific qualifications in the visual arts and crafts and at least one will have specific qualifications and/or expertise in the music area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. The Senate will have noticed that I have taken some interest in the matter of Kirribilli House, where over the last two years large amounts of money have been spent. This was discussed at some length at the Estimates Committee A meeting. Of course, the matter has been raised in the Senate on some occasions. However, as a result of a question by Senator Bishop supplementary information has been provided by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet relating to the very serious matter of who actually has been using Kirribilli House and what has been the purpose of spending $750,000 on it. The Senate will recall that $500,000 of that expenditure related to structural changes. That took place in the last financial year. This resulted from reports on the need for structural changes dating back, I think, to 1978 but which were eventually undertaken by the Hawke Government when, in fact, Mr Hawke as I understand it declared the work to be a matter of urgency. Despite the belt tightening that everyone else was undertaking the work had to be done on Kirribilli House. Coincidentally as I recall, this corresponded with the cost for work that was being done on the Lodge. Everyone else's belt got tightened except the Prime Minister's. We were told originally that $250,000 to be spent on refurbishing Kirribilli House in the current financial year was because it would be needed for use by guests of government during the bicentennial celebrations.
—They have Caucus meetings there.

—The point has been made very well by the distinguished senator from Queensland that Caucus meetings are held there. The response that Kirribilli House was needed for the use of guests of government during the bicentennial year was total bunkum. No guests of government at all have stayed there.
—You are just upset because you don't get invited there any more.
—That is a nice point by the honourable senator from the Northern Territory. I hope that he enjoys the comfort of visiting Kirribilli House.
—We did.

—He says that he did, which appears to put the lie to the proposition that it is not capable of being occupied because it is under reconstruction. Maybe it is the visits by the honourable senator from the Northern Territory that have rendered the place uninhabitable. That may be so. The reality that disturbs me is this: the $250,000 worth of refurbishing that has gone on in Kirribilli House, we discovered, related to only five rooms; five downstairs rooms were redecorated in Kirribilli House. That represents about $50,000 a room which is about as much as most Australians would spend on building a house.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple proposition that emerges, apart from the self-indulgence involved, is this: Let us examine the uses to which Kirribilli House has been put under the Hawke Government. This is the essential point: under the previous Government, Kirribilli House was used substantially as a place of accommodation for visiting guests of government. In the last five years of the Fraser Government, 54 visiting guests of government occupied Kirribilli House at one stage or another. Those guests included President Karamanlis of Greece; Mr Gerald Ford, a former President of the United States, the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester; Mr Muldoon; Princess Anne; the Governor-General of Fiji and Mr Gundelach of the European Communities-a whole host of very impressive foreign visitors. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of those who have been guests of government in Kirribilli House over the last 10 years. I am sorry that I did not have an opportunity to clear this with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is at the table, beforehand because of the confusion that seemed to emerge about what was happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and the Committee. The list has been submitted by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in response to a question by Senator Bronwyn Bishop. While I have said that there were 54 such visitors during the time of the Fraser Government, in the five years of the present Government there have been just six visitors. That is an average of 1.2 visiting guests of government per year as against an average of 11 in the last five years of the Fraser Government. We have a clear indication then of what this is all about, do we not? We have a clear indication that, under the Hawke empire, Kirribilli House is reserved for the near-exclusive use of the Prime Minister when he is in Sydney, as he has given up his place of residence in Melbourne.
—You are only jealous that you don't get invited.

—I thank the honourable senator for the interjection about my jealousy on this point, but I assure him that if this kind of self-indulgence proceeds, which it has for five years, and becomes more and more drawn to the attention of the Australian people, it will assist in the removal of the present Prime Minister and his cohorts who look on these places as something like the fruits of office to be rorted and misused for their own benefit. The figures on usage dramatise that at no stage was it the Government's genuine intention to spend three-quarters of a million dollars on Kirribilli House for the benefit of visiting guests of government during the Bicentennial. That was a fraud. This chamber was misled. The Parliament was treated with the usual contempt that the Government shows. The people of Australia were ripped off so that a comfortable and nicely decorated place of residence could be provided for the Prime Minister in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this is an absolute disgrace. I will be interested to see whether the Government has any plans for any visiting guests of government, during what remains of the bicentennial year, to spend any time whatsoever at Kirribilli House. I would be surprised if it did. I ask the Government, if it does have such plans, whether it would be prepared to share them with us, to let us know, to let the people of Australia know, whether or not the three-quarters of a million dollars spent on it will have any benefits or returns to anyone except the Prime Minister and his cronies, his rich mates who visit him when they are not doing deals like coming to extraordinary arrangements in Western Australia involving the State Government Insurance Corporation.

I think that the people of Australia are sick and tired of this kind of self-indulgence. They certainly will not tolerate it at a time when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is insisting that everyone pulls in his belt and that sacrifices should be made. Sacrifices have to be made by everyone except the Prime Minister with Kirribilli House and the Treasurer with his travelling allowance. What an incredible double we have. I draw this matter, once again, to the attention of this chamber simply because in the past we have had an unsatisfactory round of explanations. I believe that we have been deceived about the purpose of this expenditure. I am grateful that Senator Bishop asked the appropriate question that received a very appropriate reply, and that was the list of those who actually stayed at Kirribilli House. I believe that that list demonstrates the utter hypocrisy of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it appropriate for me to respond to some of Senator Michael Baume's remarks. We have to look at this on a number of fronts. First off, there are pretty obvious obligations, indeed statutory obligations, on the part of the Government to look after buildings as significant as Kirribilli House. It is a building in which much of this nation's history is contained. I would have thought that any government that walked away from its duty to preserve it would be doing a grave disservice to the people of Australia. More importantly, one must look at what the building's role really is. In the past, great use has been made of Kirribilli House by former Prime Ministers--
—And visiting guests of government.

—That is quite true. However, once the conclusion is reached that a building is no longer safe, that parts of it are quite literally falling down, the days of having visiting guests of the government there are gone. One would hope that the days of having the Prime Minister there all the time are gone too. I would not like the roof falling on him either. The building had reached a pretty deplorable state. When that happens, it is the duty of the government of the day to take action.

SPEECH.PARA: As for all of the figures about how many guests of government used to go to Kirribilli House and how many use it today, all that Senator Baume has to realise is that once one comes to the conclusion that a building is unsafe, one does not keep inviting important guests-one brings the Caucus. One has to make sure that the renovations are completed. Once they are completed-and I think July is still the date for that completion-we will again be in a position, where appropriate, again to have visiting guests of government at Kirribilli House and the Prime Minister and, hopefully, a great many more of us will again be able to enjoy the attributes of this very fine building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting during the hearings of Estimates Committee A to see how reluctant the departmental people were to give the facts about how Kirribilli House was being treated. They went through a long rigmarole in answer to questions of trying to say that it was really all structural work that was being done and that just the odd bit of wallpaper was being hung. It took an enormous amount of close questioning to ascertain finally the name of the interior decorator and the fact that the $250,000 that was additional to the $500,000 was meant for interior decoration.

SPEECH.PARA: The average Australian who thinks about decorating his or her home and purchasing curtains, furnishings or carpet does not have that sort of money to spend to live in an opulent manner. It is one thing if one is spending a lot of money on decorating formal reception rooms which are used for visiting heads of state or which are needed for formal functions. All along, the purpose of the departmental evidence was to try to persuade the Committee that that was indeed what was being done.

The departmental officers were asked who was responsible for appointing Mr Spode, the interior decorator who was commissioned on the basis of a fixed contract of $8,800 for the period of 9 June 1987 to 2 September 1987. The scope of the work for interior design and decoration, report and estimate of cost was for the following: the refurbishment and decoration of the state areas, which include the drawing room, the dining room, the study hall and the entrance foyer on the ground floor, all of which are formal rooms of state and would be designed in the ordinary context for receptions for visiting heads of government or the like-certainly not as a rumpus room, as it were, for the Prime Minister and perhaps his family; secondly, bedrooms 1 and 2 and the powder room on the ground floor, including bathrooms; and, thirdly, bedrooms 3, 4 and 5, the sitting rooms and the stair hall on the first floor.

We learned from evidence that, with the exception of the ground floor apartments, none of these areas have been completed. The excuse was that it was impossible for visitors to stay at Kirribilli House during the period of renovation and redecoration. The fact of the matter is that for the last two years there have been no guests there at all. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his family have been there on many occasions, including the magical spectacle of the bicentennial celebration on Australia Day. What a superb view that must have been, to be envied by many, I would have thought. Yet, we were told that these vast amounts of money were being spent for the sole reason that visiting guests of the government could stay there. As I said earlier today when I addressed this question, it is one thing to say that we are spending public moneys for diplomatic reasons; it is quite another to tart up the building as a second residence for the Prime Minister.

It is interesting to note that whereas Mr Spode was appointed on the recommendation, without tender, of the Heritage Committee, it is actually the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet which has been responsible for engaging the workmen and tradesmen to carry out the work under the direction of Mr Spode. As I said, the top floors have not been completed. I will be interested to see whether or not in the next round of Estimates we will see a further allocation of funds.

Some people might say that this is a trivial matter. Kirribilli House is a building of importance that graces the shores of Sydney Harbour. It has a prominence and a pre-eminence in the city landscape. For several decades it has traditionally been a place where we could honour people who visit our country shores instead of putting them up in a hotel where enormous amounts of money must be spent on accommodation. I would imagine that a head of government would require a hotel suite at least. With the sorts of rentals that are paid in the downtown Sydney area where there is competition for space and a tourist boom, it is not hard to realise that that would be an excessive demand upon the public purse.

The point of raising this matter is that there was an aura of subterfuge around what was going on. Interior decoration was being disguised as renovation and work to make the building safe. Nobody has ever suffered from falling wallpaper. Nobody has ever been in danger because the curtains were not quite up to scratch. Nobody has ever been in danger because the furniture might not have been to the taste of the then incumbent. The point is that we need to be told the facts. The Estimates committees are designed to find out just that. If we do not take cognisance of the facts and we do not bring them to the attention of the Senate and the people as a whole, one extravagance can simply lead to another.

We already have a punitive tax in place for fringe benefits. The Government has the holier-than-thou attitude that people who hitherto had fringe benefits somehow have to be penalised. It seems that that is fine for the goose but not for the gander. It seems that we are penalising private citizens but not the most eminent citizen of the day-the Prime Minister. I think this is a serious matter which requires addressing in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say that that was an extraordinary outburst from Senator Bishop. There is no validity whatsoever in a claim that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in any way tried to conceal anything about renovations at Kirribilli House. Every question put to the Estimates Committee was answered. Those that could not be answered on the spot were answered later in correspondence, as is the case with every other department. Senator Bishop is no Perry Mason, neither were any of the public servants from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet on trial. They all behaved with honour. They did their job and they did it well. The reality is that Senator Bishop came up, as usual, with nothing. Senator Bishop is accustomed to that, and we are accustomed to hearing her bleating about it later. Nothing was done in relation to Kirribilli House of which this Government is ashamed. Nothing was done there that we tried to hide. There is the reality that if a major residence to be used by heads of government from all over the world as well as our own Prime Minister is to remain the sort of building that it is, it needs renovations. If they get put off for years and years, it is not going to be cheap to do it up. We cannot do up a residence by doing up one or two rooms. We have to try to do up all of those rooms where there is a problem if the building is ever again to be used by guests of government. That is what we undertook to do. That is exactly what the Government is doing. We will continue to do that, because that is the responsible way to behave.
