TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to make a couple of comments about what I see as some very significant difficulties in the Government's administration of its Aboriginal affairs programs. I want to say something about what I see as being the enormous gap between the Government's rhetoric and its performance. The Government claims to believe in consultation with Aboriginal people, it claims to be responsive to Aboriginal people, and yet we have just seen the quite extraordinary circumstance of the Government either dismissing or purporting to dismiss eight of the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I will be very careful in what I say about this because I think the court is still mulling over some of the final details of that, although I gather that the court has already held today that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) was entitled to issue the first ever direction to the Aboriginal Development Commission-that which was issued in April and which was one of the forerunners of the subsequent dismissal or purported dismissal of the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: This does warrant comment when one recalls the acres of rhetoric that have been expended in this chamber from Labor spokesmen such as the late Jim Keefe, whose passing we all mourned a few days ago, through to Susan Ryan, and many people who have taken an interest in this area. It is hard to try to match that rhetoric against this reality. The fact of the matter is that the Minister has found it necessary-whether legally or not is irrelevant in terms of the comments that I want to make-to dismiss those people because they are putting views which he does not find satisfactory.

In an earlier debate in this place, I indicated that my own brief attempt at consultation in the Kimberley region, where I visited a number of Aboriginal communities, had left me very concerned about the actual understanding of the Aboriginal people as to what the Government was proposing. For that reason I have a great deal of sympathy for the sort of position which was adopted by the Aboriginal Development Commission and which was represented by the statement that was put out recently by Shirley McPherson, the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission. I shall quote from that statement. She was commenting on the fact that the Minister had announced on 27 April his intention to proceed with the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in a form somewhat modified from that announced on 10 December 1987. Mrs McPherson went on to say:

These modifications do not adequately address the major concerns expressed by the Commission and a significant number of Aboriginal communities and organisations. These concerns have been drawn to the attention of the Minister and are included in the Commission's Alternative Strategy Discussion paper. They can be summarised as follows.
Inadequacy of consultation with Aboriginal bodies and communities, in terms of:
the time given for consultation
failure to offer any alternatives
complexity of issues to be addressed
absence of a complete proposal
lack of adequate replies to questions.

If I could comment on that first series of objections that have been made by Mrs McPherson, the fact of the matter is that each of the Aboriginal communities that I met-and I had discussions with representatives of those communities-in the week before Easter certainly reflected some or all of these deficiencies raised by Mrs McPherson.

The one thing that I would say in favour of what the Minister was doing is that there was among many of those Aboriginal people a view that they wanted change. That view flowed from their dissatisfaction with the status quo, the fact that they felt that what they were getting at the moment was not adequate, was not working properly, or was being delivered in a confused manner. Mostly, I think their complaints flowed from the fact that they thought that they were not getting sufficient assistance. However, it was quite clear that none of them had a very definite idea of what it was that the Minister was proposing, other than that he held out some hope to them that there might be greater grassroots or local control of programs. That was something that they certainly favoured.

The second objection made by Mrs McPherson in her statement on behalf of the ADC is that there was an extension of ministerial authority at the expense of genuine Aboriginal control over their own affairs. Nothing could more clearly have demonstrated the correctness of that statement by the ADC than the actions of the Minister himself over recent weeks. The fact is that this Government has shown itself incapable of working with those Aboriginals who wish to put a strongly contrary view.

Senators such as Senator Gietzelt have been in the chamber for a long time during which they have witnessed the conduct of Aboriginal affairs, sometimes in the hands of their colleagues, such as Senator Cavanagh. I ask Senator Gietzelt to look back at the difficult times we had, for example, with the National Aboriginal Conference and other Aboriginal bodies established by the previous Government or indeed by the Whitlam Government, which the honourable senator supported. I ask him to try to remember any occasion on which a government has responded as the Government he now supports has responded by sacking Aboriginal spokesmen who have dared to put a view seen by the Minister as obstructive.

I must say that had I taken that attitude to the National Aboriginal Conference I would have been chased out of this chamber by irate members of the Australian Labor Party. I believe that there are gross double standards operating in this chamber, because I do not believe that honourable senators opposite impose the same tests on their own Government as they were prepared to impose so fully and freely on the Government of which I was a part. I say that without any real fear of contradiction.

The reality is that this Government has deprived the Aboriginal people of any genuine national voice except to the extent that the Aboriginal Development Commission can make that claim. What the Government has done is expose the Aboriginal people to being spoken for by the Michael Mansells of this world. At least, when we were in government and we had the National Aboriginal Conference, there was a group of Aboriginal people, ranging from the most tribalised to the least tribalised. We had everything from the Fitzroy push and the Sydney push to the Arnhem Landers. Those people came together-not always a comfortable experience for them or for us-and a representative opinion was hammered out. Government could talk with that diverse group in a way that enabled it at last to achieve some sort of understanding of the broad Aboriginal viewpoint.

Now we have people who are largely self-appointed. Michael Mansell is the high profile example of someone who is causing so many people to react against the Aboriginal people. Representatives of land councils are fulfilling their statutory function in their little bit of Australia, whether it is the Northern Land Council, the Tiwis, the Central Land Council or whatever. In Western Australia and Queensland there are self-appointed land councils, but there is no voice that can truly be said to represent the broad range of Aboriginal opinion. The Government has cost us that voice. It is all very well for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to talk about consultation, but in fact who does speak for the Aboriginal people?

All I can say is that my recent visits to the Northern Territory and the north of my State of Western Australia have satisfied me that there is vast dissatisfaction with this Government's administration of Aboriginal affairs. That dissatisfaction falls broadly into two areas, and I am sorry to have to divide it on a racial basis. The white, non-Aboriginal community is thoroughly disgusted with what it sees as waste and ineffective delivery of services and as the negatives that have flowed from what it sees as throwing money at problems.

I have already said in the Senate that all senators should be deeply concerned about the depth of feeling on this issue in the community. In a sense, the communities that are the closest to the concentration of Aboriginals feel it most strongly. That situation applies in the north but also, for example, in suburban Perth, in those suburbs where substantial Aboriginal minorities live cheek by jowl, often with relatively disadvantaged Australians. In such cases there is quite enormous resentment and ill feeling. In no sense do I say that that resentment and ill feeling are appropriate. However, I believe that we need to understand that a great deal of what is being done by governments has had a negative effect. I do not suggest that this trend started only when the Labor Party took office. There has been a cumulative effect, but the situation is far worse today than it was five years ago, as almost any Aboriginal or white person involved in this field will confirm. I suggest that honourable senators opposite ask a few people involved, because I am sure they will find almost universal confirmation of what I have said.

In the non-Aboriginal community, I find an extraordinary number of people who are totally fed up with what is going on. There is therefore a great lack of sympathy with the efforts of so many good Aboriginal people to do something for themselves. There is tremendous dissatisfaction with government in general. Among Aboriginal people-and of course there is an enormous variety of views-I can only say that many of the Aboriginal people whom I know to be close supporters of the Labor Party and active in the Labor Party are greatly dissatisfied with the Government and its approach.

I want to comment on the general reputation of the Minister's office. Minister Hand is properly and widely perceived as a decent and humane person. However, he is also widely perceived as living in a castle, not literally a castle but with walls around him that mean that he is not really accessible. I know that he has spent a lot of time on the road and in consulting. We have heard details of that and I thought that, in a recent debate in this chamber, Senator Collins put a very good case for the Minister in terms of the consultation there had been in relation to ATSIC.

I simply want to put on the public record that the uniform reaction I get wherever I go around Australia-and sometimes it is from people who approach me and sometimes from people whom I approach-is to categorise the Minister's office as not reaching out or being responsive to the community and not being realistic. Thus I believe the Government has a real problem in this area. I am not sure what is the source of the problem. However, the Government should not ignore the growing community disenchantment that often spills over into resentment, and the widespread lack of confidence in the Government's administration of Aboriginal affairs, an attitude that I believe reaches deeply into the Department.

I have reached the point at which I almost wish not to speak to a member of the Department because I am told that under this Government to be seen talking to me is regarded very suspiciously. I despise that attitude. I have never obtained any illicit information from a public servant from a department that I previously administered. I have a healthy respect for the professional approach of the bulk of the Aboriginal Affairs officers of my acquaintance. However, in passing I point out that I choose not to indulge that acquaintance, as I am told that contact with me is not seen positively by people in the Government. That indicates a pathetic siege mentality and lack of comprehension of what these problems are really all about.

On the necessarily anecdotal and incidental evidence that I have been able to pick up, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is in a mess. Its morale is low, and that is an indictment of the Minister and his office. He is responsible for that; no-one else can be responsible for it. If there is a combination of a lack of realism at the Government level, a lack of involvement and of any positive sense in the Department, and an unrealistic approach to programs that leads to the white reaction I have described and to the black disillusionment I have described, then there is a formula for further disaster in this area.
I turn now to the complaints of the Aboriginal Development Commission. The third complaint made by Mrs McPherson is:
The proposed amalgamation of welfare and commercial business promoting functions, the latter to be administered in a public service environment.

I have mixed feelings about that objection because I believe that one of the significant problems for Aboriginal communities is the diversity of administrations with which they have to deal. Earlier in debate in the Senate I made the point that, for example, at Red Hill outside Hall's Creek, I found contractors who had been retained from somewhere in the Northern Territory. They were carrying out quite expensive plumbing work on roofs, installing hot water systems. The taps to which the hot water systems were connected were broken. It was not part of the contract to fix them. That is a tiny example of the sort of thing that flows from divided administrations. That is why I simply put a question mark next to that element of Mrs McPherson's complaint. I think that in the main she is right to be concerned about mixing up welfare and commercial and business promoting functions. I can understand the Government's motivation in trying to find some more common administration which might ease some of the confusion which afflicts many Aboriginal communities because of the variety of agencies with which they have to deal.

Within her summary of objections, she then points to the failure to demonstrate anywhere that ATSIC will better serve Aboriginal interests and needs. Again I can only say that, on the discussions I had with Aboriginal people, that failure seems to be borne out. The uncertainty that I found was in the fact that none of the Aboriginals to whom I spoke really seemed to know what these different bodies would actually have responsibility for and the power to make decisions about. Simple questions about just what authority would be given to the different levels of activity that have been described seemed to elicit no sensible response. The people freely confessed that they did not know the answers.

Mrs McPherson goes on to put as another objection the dissipation of the ADC asset base and the destruction of the only portfolio organisation that has been able to meet its recurrent costs from internally generated revenue. If there are elements of the ADC that are working well, if from an economic point of view it is able to meet its recurrent costs from internally generated revenue, I would suggest that that is a sign of some progress at which the Government should look very carefully. It is always easy to look as if one is doing something in the area of Aboriginal Affairs by chucking out what is there and starting something new. That is a terrific thing to do because everyone is always dissatisfied with what is there, so the theory is that one will probably make some progress. But the reality is that, if one has something that is working, it is a pretty good idea to hang on to it. I believe that messing around with ATSIC and the absorption of the ADC is certainly unwise if it picks up operating, functioning bodies that are performing a useful role and doing so reasonably efficiently. That is an objection which the Government should be examining very carefully.

The sixth objection is that the imposition of taxation of dividend payments to the Commonwealth on profits generated by the ADC will adversely affect the level of revenue funds returned to Aboriginal programs, as with the ADC at present. That is really just a double accounting matter and I will pass on beyond it. Mrs McPherson says:
The more difficult and expensive administration of ATSIC compared to the ADC Alternative which is expected to be far more cost-effective with savings estimated at $5m.

I have read from Mrs McPherson's Press release and her objections do not sound like ravings; they do not sound like ratbag comments and they certainly do not sound the sort of comments which should lead to the dismissal of the person who has made them and the group that put them forward. They seem to me to be quite challenging points which I would have thought that a government that was genuinely committed to consultation with Aboriginal people would be prepared to meet. I can only say that I wish that the National Aboriginal Conference had been quite as polite in the way in which it put its objections to me from time to time. I found the NAC fairly rude, tough and rough at times. But I never actually got to the point where I thought I should find out how to sack the members of it.

I want to touch on another area which is up for grabs. I may be out of date-perhaps the Government has decided to back off on this-but the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies was one of the bodies to be absorbed. I suppose to most people the Government would say, `Well, why not bundle all these things up together; it should be neater'. It always seemed to me that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies was a fairly good unit. The legislation was passed back in 1964-it is not exactly novel. It was passed back in the days when we were first trying to come to grips with this area and it authorised the Institute to promote Aboriginal studies, publish or support publication of the results of research, encourage and assist cooperation among universities, museums and other institutions concerned with Aboriginal studies, and assist these organisations to train research workers in Aboriginal studies. I merely wish to say that when I was Minister-some 14 years after the foundation of the Institute-I found it an absolute goldmine of information, of access to people. It was a superb resource. It had a detachment from government; it was essentially an academic institution although it would be fair to say that whilst Dr Peter Ucko was principal it was under the control of an extremely political man who certainly had an agenda of his own. I say that with respect, but I always regarded him as a person with very strong political-but not party political-inclinations. But the important thing was that there was a huge body of knowledge gathered together. It was a meeting place for scholars from the university and other institutes.

Some of the work was intensely practical. Let me give a very quick example. I always remember believing that Aboriginal studies were probably the key to promoting better community attitudes-that all one had to do was better explain to the people of Australia what the Aboriginal people were like and all these difficult attitudes would disappear. That was my optimistic assessment in 1978. One might say that a 37-year-old who had that view showed a certain lack of sense, but it was my view. It was the institute which exposed me to some lines of thought which are important in determining how we get to this problem of adverse attitudes to Aboriginal people. Part of it is a problem of inefficiency, of promoting unreal expectations and of unreal demands by Aboriginals. We understand all that. But I think there are more difficult questions. I recall the work of Barbara Chambers, who had worked with student teachers and researched the impact of Aboriginal studies programs on trainee teachers. I probably do her research less than justice, but I sum it up by saying that it is suggested that some courses of Aboriginal studies actually increase negative attitudes.

Max Kamien, who wrote The Dark People of Bourke, is now the Professor of Community Medicine in Perth. He draws a very similar conclusion. This is the sort of thing which I think well-meaning politicians from the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia are unlikely to access through their own unguided efforts. I just quote that as a simple example. In terms of access to Aboriginal people and people who gave one a chance to communicate with remote communities such as Aurukun, Mornington Island and others, the Institute was a really superb resource. Why muck it up? Why not leave it alone? I cannot understand why that body has to be interfered with at all. It should be left alone and under the chairmanship of Ken Colbung or whoever is selected under its constitution. It should be left as an independent body. It should continue to promote the studies of a people who are unique in their cultures and something which is a marvellous part of Australia. I really think that to mess it up and to involve it in these quite difficult and disparate problems of administration programs and so on is just nonsense. It may be that it can be shoved off in a corner of its own, but I make a plea for leaving the Institute of Aboriginal Studies as a free-standing institution.

I ask honourable senators opposite to think of the contribution of people such as the late Jim Keeffe, who for many years served on that institute, as did people such as Senator Peter Baume, I for a very brief period and Senator Teague for a long period. There has been involvement at that level by a whole series of us and it is absurd that that body should be caught up in this sort of reorganisation. It is the triumph of some airy-fairy theory over any long term consideration of what we have been trying to achieve for 20 years.

I wanted to talk on these matters because I do not, for a moment, suggest that there is any lack of goodwill on the part of the Government; I think there is a lack of sense. I believe that there are within the Government resources which, if utilised, could ensure that the Government approached this matter with greater sense. On the part of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs there needs to be a far greater preparedness to look over the walls, outside his office. He needs to listen in the sense of being prepared to comprehend that a view contrary to his own may indeed be right. He has to be prepared to listen to a great range of people, even if he starts off within his own Party and with members of his Party who, in the Northern Territory, have had simple and direct experience. In the last week I was able to have a brief conversation with Stan Tipiloura from Bathurst and Wesley Lanhupuy from Milingimbi. I would suggest that an honest listening to those two would be an advantage. I suggest that, if the Minister were to talk to his Labor Party colleagues who have so messed up Aboriginal affairs in Western Australia, he might learn something.

The fact is that the Labor Party in Western Australia made a whole series of silly promises which were beyond its capacity to keep and which my Party fiercely fought and tried to prevent it from keeping, in terms of land rights, for example. If the Minister were to talk to people within the Western Australian Labor Party who have had constant contact with the Aboriginal people over the last five or more years and who have been active in the promotion of policies in that area, I suspect-and I can say no more than that I suspect it-that he would get some pretty conservative views about the approach that should be adopted. He would get careful views about concentrating on the practical needs that exist and on the desire of Aboriginal people to see the practical problems they have in their lives tackled-not with a lot of rhetoric, not with a whole lot of reorganisation, but simply with a devotion to detail on the ground and putting in place accountable administrations of the sorts that have been established in the Northern Territory. What is being done in the Northern Territory in the local government model is a real step forward. I am glad to see Senator Collins nodding in agreement. It is a transfer of power in a sensible and realistic way, with accountability both to the taxpayer and to the community that is being served.

I conclude by saying to the Labor senators opposite that, in the apparent conflict between the role of community councils and the role of traditional land owners in the Northern Territory, they should stop to think about whether they believe in the feudal system. I think some Labor people are supporting what is essentially the feudal system. They are supporting the rights of land owners over the rights of the community. I am trying to put this in terms which will enable those opposite to see how ridiculous it is to support some of the things they do. They are denying people the right to run their communities in a sensible way in the interests of all. In my view, they are denying basic democracy. Labor members are hung up on arguments about theory which they do not relate to their general political beliefs in the rights of man. I think we waste a great deal of time, cause a great deal of misery and serve the Aboriginal people ill.

I asked Wesley Lanhupuy a question on the way to Darwin. I said, `Twenty years ago there was a really good group of young Aboriginal people coming forward to do the job-people like you, Galarrwuy and Gagil. Where is the next generation?'. I am talking about the period in which I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I take my share of the blame, but I say that this Government is going backwards. I am sick of it, the Australian people are sick of it and Labor members should wake up to themselves and stop messing around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Chaney, I am angry about the administration of Aboriginal affairs and the Government's ballsing up of what should be a very decent area of administration. The estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs were quite penetrating and revealing in the areas which Senator Chaney has just highlighted and as to some of the aspects he has brought into the debate today. The fact is that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) since his elevation to office has chosen basically to ignore the Aboriginal Development Commission. The document he presented to the Parliament last December entitled Foundations for the Future, comprising his initial proposals to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, is nothing but a document that seeks to nobble, to constrain and to put away the functions and role of the Aboriginal Development Commission, particularly in the areas of commerce, enterprise and participation in the general run of life by Aboriginals.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed new Commission raises as many problems as it will seek to solve. There have already been other debates on this subject in this place, but the fact that the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is to embrace not only all the present functions of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs but also all the functions of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and many of the education functions of the other government departments does not augur well for the future development of Aboriginal policies throughout Australia. As Senator Chaney outlined, it seemed to be almost totally unnecessary that in the last week or so a body as eminently successful as the Aboriginal Development Commission had to take the Minister to court to seek to establish several things. Although a judgment has been handed down today relating to the Minister's direction to the Commission and whether or not that is lawful, it should not have been necessary.

We know that before the court tomorrow will be addressed the issue of the Minister's sacking of eight out of 10 commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission and a proposal for him to appoint additional new temporary members. It smacks of blackmail and intimidation by a Minister who could not face up to decent, genuine and thorough criticism and the presentation of alternative policies in his own area of administration. Last December, at the time the Minister put forward the proposals, he invited everyone in the community-black, white, departmental representatives and so on-to participate in that debate. The fact that 10 commissioners, all Aboriginal, chose to put forward views that were contrary to some of those in the Minister's own document shows him in that instance to have been nothing but gutless.

Let us look at the people sacked by the Minister. I wonder whether anyone in the Labor Party would dare to suggest in this place that the Reverend Ossie Cruse, John Atkinson, Andrew Thomas, Helen Williams, Ben Ward, Lena Passi, Marie Thompson and Phillip Yanner would have been other than competent and proper Aboriginal people to represent the communities in which they have an interest throughout Australia. I do not believe that any one of them would have been called into question either on this side of the Parliament or on the Government side. I believe that two members of the Commission from the Northern Territory were nominated by my colleague Senator Collins. His friend the Minister, Mr Hand, has sacked them.

With whom does the Minister propose to replace these people? Let me read the new list of the proposed appointments which are up before the courts to see whether it can proceed: Mr Patrick Dodson, Director of the Central Land Council and Co-ordinator of the Federation of Land Councils; Lois O'Donoghue, Chairman of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, one of the bodies proposed to be gobbled up; Terence O'Shane, Secretary of the Njiku Jowan Legal Service and Chairman of the Woobera Muralug Housing Co-operative in Cairns; Mr Getano Lui Jr, Chairman of the Island Co-ordinating Council of Torres Strait Islands; Charles Perkins, Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; Peter Yu, Executive Director of Bunubba Productions, Broome; Esther Carroll, Director of Murrawina, Sydney; and Mr Robert Lee, Town Clerk, Barunga Wugulara Community, Barunga, Northern Territory. Every one of the proposed new appointments is in some way indebted to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for financial support for the organisations he or she represents-eight new stooges who will do nothing but the Minister's bidding in this new situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they don't represent the Aboriginal community.

—Some may not and probably would not. Let us look carefully at what the Chairperson of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Mrs Shirley McPherson, said with regard to the new proposals for the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission when she appeared before the Senate Estimates Committee on 14 April. In response to questions about how she and the ADC were perceiving the Aboriginal reaction to that policy she said:

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of the responses that we have received have indicated that people would like more time-
I stress the words `more time'-
to be made fully aware of the Government's option and for more time to put any other options that they would like included in the proposal.
Later in her response Mrs McPherson said:
They are indicating that they would like to have time to review the draft legislation. At this stage they are being given no indication that they will be able to view that before it is presented.

The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who represents the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this place, last week presented a table on the likely scenario of the proposals for the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and he said that it would now be implemented not on 1 July, as was envisaged, but on 1 January 1989. He also said on that occasion that the next elections throughout the Aboriginal communities would take place in September, October and November 1988. How in heaven's name is Mr Hand going to get that legislation through this Parliament and operating before September 1988? Parliament does not even reconvene until 22 August, which would be the first opportunity he will have to present the legislation. Through Mrs McPherson, the Aboriginal people are asking for more time to consider the legislation when it is presented. It is not only an insult to this Parliament if the legislation is rammed through in about a week to enable the subsequent general elections to be held in September. It will also, quite coincidentally, be given consideration after the general constitutional referendum of 3 September. So I wonder why this issue has been withheld and considered in this way. I am particularly angry at the manner in which this has been presented.

In our examination of the estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in the past few weeks, I asked several questions about the use of consultants by the Department, including a number relating to the formation of the proposed new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. This included the payment of $30,000 to Coopers and Lybrand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We are dealing with the second reading debate of Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88. Senator Tambling seems to be getting into what might be called the committee debate of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, which will be considered shortly.
—I take your direction, sir, but you gave considerable licence to Senator Chaney in the previous debate.
—There were special circumstances which gave Senator Chaney some licence.

—I will abide by your ruling, sir. I will raise the matter again when the Committee of the Whole considers the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I might be able to extend my time limit quite considerably.
—Senator Tambling is entitled to speak in the committee stage as much as he likes.

—I conclude at this stage by saying that the issue of Aboriginal affairs certainly needs very close attention because the interests of Aborigines throughout Australia are certainly not being represented by this Government in the way that they should be considered addressed in the estimates for the coming year.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) proposed:
That the debate be now adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I am sorry. I thought I had risen to speak.
—I called Senator Walsh because the call was on the Government side. Senator Walsh has moved that the debate be adjourned.
—Senator Walsh, I imagine that you now want to move that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.
—No, we will not do it today. Senator Short will have an opportunity later on. It will come up in the committee stage.

—Order! The situation is that the Minister for Finance has adjourned debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 under sessional order, which means that it is adjourned until the next day of sitting, but I imagine that he wants it adjourned until a later hour this day.
—I had assumed that we would be going ahead with the committee stage. I am happy enough to oblige, but if Senator Short wants to say something he will have an opportunity later on.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I seek your guidance. Is the debate being adjourned until a later hour today?

—No, debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 has been adjourned by agreement of the Senate. The subsequent motion would be to adjourn debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1987-88 to the next day of sitting. If that motion is passed, which it has been, we will deal with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88 in committee.

—That will come up again. The debate has already been adjourned.

—I have not moved to call on the next Bill, Mr Deputy President. I am quite happy to move that the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) be adjourned until a later hour this day. PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs
Department of Primary Industries and Energy
Department of Community Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister say whether his advisers from the Department of Community Services and Health are available?
—I believe they are.
—At what locations will the Health Insurance Commission open branches to replace agency services provided by local health funds?
—I understand that the officials will be able to provide a response in a few minutes. They are looking up the details.

—Is someone available to answer a question I asked earlier? Are any agencies receiving funding under the disability services program experiencing a delay in receiving subsidies for the 1986-87 financial year, prior to the introduction of the Disability Services Act? Are there delays in subsidy funding for projects in the 1988-89 financial year?

—My advice from the officers is that they are not aware that that has occurred, but I will have that checked as soon as possible and will ask the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to reply by correspondence, if that is satisfactory.

—I am prepared to advise the Minister of one such agency that claims that its subsidy for 1986-87 has been delayed and that it has not received an adequate explanation for this. I would be prepared to advise on which agency that is.

—The officers of the Department of Community Services and Health do not have from their records information the names of new agencies. They will have to obtain the information from the Health Insurance Commission. I am quite happy to take that question on notice in the same way that I have taken Senator Patterson's question on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister's advisers could take on notice a few other questions along the same line. I would like to know whether any of these locations have changed as a result of representations from members of parliament or the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). If so, which locations have changed? What are the costs generated from these changes? Have the costs been higher as a result of the representation by those members of parliament or the Minister? What is the total cost to the Health Insurance Commission of operating the new branches? How will the costs be shared between Medibank Private and Medicare in the new branches? What commission is the Health Insurance Commission paying post office agencies in Tasmania for handling Medicare claims? Why did the Commission reject proposals that agency funds be placed on line and in dumb computer terminals?

SPEECH.PARA: Is the real reason for the termination of agencies a result of a desire by the Government to force doctors to bulk bill? Do the senior management of the HIC move from Medibank Private activities to Medicare responsibilities and the reverse? If so, what safeguards are in place to ensure that the confidential information obtained from the administration of Medicare is not used for the commercial activities of Medibank Private? What instructions are provided to Medicare and Medibank Private staff to ensure members of parliament do not access Medicare information? What physical barriers are in place to guarantee that such exchanges cannot possibly take place? Which market research firms have been used by HIC in the last 12 months? What tasks were commissioned and what work was done for members of parliament, as well as Medicare? How much was paid? How was it allocated between the two organisations? Did the Health Insurance Commission ask Price Waterhouse to prepare a response to a paper prepared by Touche Ross Services Pty Ltd dealing with the Commission's cost structures? Finally, what was the cost of the public works report? How much was charged to Medicare and Medibank Private?

TALK.START.PARA: —Those questions will be taken on notice. Senator Walters cannot expect to get answers now to 25 questions like that, or whatever the number was.

—I have some other questions that are not as detailed as those which I have just asked which I am sure the Minister or his officers could answer for me. In a news release of 27 January last year, doctors and pharmacists were advised to monitor closely patients using any of the 33 generic prescription drugs available on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and to cease prescribing them for new patients until the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) approved such use. Two companies manufacturing the drugs, Protea Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd and Alphapharm Pty Ltd, were given 12 months to submit additional data on providing bio equivalents to the original drugs and if satisfactory data were not provided to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee by that time the products were to be withdrawn. In April 1988 doctors were advised in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme book that 12 of these 33 products were still to be restricted to patients stabilised on them prior to January 1987. I ask: Will the Minister advise the chamber why these drugs have not been withdrawn following expiry in January this year of the 12-month grace period? Will the Minister also advise status of the other generic products originally restricted in order that doctors and patients can be satisfied as to the quality of the drugs they are using.

—I must say I am not surprised that with no notice whatsoever the departmental advisers cannot provide answers to such fine detailed questions as those. I am quite happy to take those questions on notice too.
—I am sorry, but those questions do not involve answers of fine detail. I have asked about the 33 generic prescription drugs which in January last year were set aside.
—If you wanted an answer, you should have given me notice before.

—They are questions that if the senior officers of the Department of Community Services and Health cannot answer then I believe they are not being fully informed of the relevant activities. I inform the Minister that the system is one which his Government introduced in order to cut costs in the pharmaceutical area. There are 33 generic prescription drugs involved. Doctors were told that these drugs were restricted to patients who were presently using them and that they could not be prescribed for any new patients. Now in April 1988 doctors have been told in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme book that 12 of these 33 products are still restricted to patients who were stabilised on them prior to January 1987. I ask why those particular drugs have not been withdrawn following expiry in January this year of the 12-month grace period. Will the Minister also advise the status of the other generic products originally restricted in order that doctors and patients can be satisfied as to the quality of drugs they are using. That is not detailed. That is a very broad question. I would be most surprised if the officers could not supply the answer now.

—I do have some information. I am advised that it was decided that the drugs in question would be re-evaluated because questions had been cast on the validity or accuracy of the initial tests that had been done by a laboratory overseas. However, they were left on the list for an interim period to give the supplying companies an opportunity to have a re-evaluation done. The officers do not know what the result of that re-evaluation is. I presume that it has not yet been completed.

—Can the officers now please tell me of the status of the other generic products that were originally restricted so that the doctors and patients can know what was the quality of the drugs they were using? It seems to me that the officers must have been too lazy to answer the original question and just asked for it to be put on notice, because when the question was repeated they came up with an answer.

—The officers do not know about the other drugs in question. These drugs have been submitted for re-evaluation too. They do not know whether the re-evaluations have been completed. I must say that I am not surprised that they do now know off the top of their heads whether 33 re-evaluations have been completed or not and what the results are for all 33.

—I did not ask for a detailed description of 33 drugs. I divided them into two groupings-one with 12 and the other with the remainder. I think my not asking for a detailed description was probably a very wise move.

—The answer to that question is the same as the one to the question asked earlier. The officers will undertake to find out the information that Senator Walters has requested tonight. It may shorten the proceedings if she is able to give us all her questions in one batch so we can address them as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Department can tell me whether the drug androcur is one of those 33. I have a constituent who has been on that drug for a considerable time. It has now been taken off the list and the Department has told her that a new and cheaper alternative is currently on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) list and she should be satisfied with that drug. My main objection to that concerns the wording in a letter which she received from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. I will read only that paragraph which I find pretty objectionable:

SPEECH.PARA: In making recommendations on which drugs should be available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, the Committee looks at the medical needs of the community as a whole. It is not possible to list drugs to satisfy special needs of individual patients.

I find it unacceptable that the PBAC says that it is not interested in the special needs of an individual patient and that it looks only at the health needs of the community as a whole. That is treating patients as numbers and not as individuals. The letter could have been worded in a far better fashion. That patient was told that she is not entitled, as a pensioner, to a tablet which she has been prescribed for quite some time, that she should get a cheaper alternative and that the Committee is not interested in her special needs. Can the Minister comment on that type of letter being sent out by the Advisory Committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, the advice is that what the Government puts on the list as being available to people such as the person whom Senator Walters mentioned is put on on the basis of expert advice. We presume, given the circumstances and the lack of identification, that that policy has been applied in this case.

—That was not the question I asked. I asked the Minister whether he thought it was a well-worded letter. Does he think that that type of letter ought to be sent out by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee-a letter telling a pensioner that it is not interested in that patient's special needs, that it looks at the health care of the community as a whole and that the special needs of the individual are not taken into account?

—Since the matter has been raised by Senator Walters, I think that we can have another look at it to see whether there is a way of changing the correspondence. It should be stressed at this stage that the Government's priority is very much to the needs of the individual. If that has not been met in this case, we will reconsider it.

—I thank the Minister. I will give him a copy of the letter that the patient received. I think that that patient's individual needs should not be shoved aside by the Advisory Committee in such an arbitrary fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators, the public and particularly the Department of Community Services and Health to the comments made by Estimates Committee D in its report to the Senate of April 1988. They are comments which I think the Committee must have arrived at after a good deal of frustration which, presumably, had been experienced by members of the Committee-certainly by me-after I had asked questions of the Department of Community Services and Health. I shall read the Committee's general comments:

SPEECH.PARA: Following the recent hearings the Committee makes the following general comment concerning the evidence brought before it by the various departments.

The Committee is concerned that the level and extent of information available during these hearings did not sometimes meet the standard expected of departments when appearing before Estimates Committees.

While it is accepted that it is not always possible for departmental officers to have detailed knowledge about every matter in the Estimates, the Committee was concerned that in a number of specific instances the answer to the questions posed was `only the officer involved knows'. This response was too frequently accepted by departmental officials as a reasonable excuse for an inability to answer questions.

The Committee does not accept this situation as satisfactory. It puts departments on notice that in future such an excuse will not be accepted when dealing with matters that specifically relate to items in the appropriations sought and that, if necessary, additional hearings will be held to ensure that the relevant information is provided.

They are general comments about the departments which appeared before the Committee. The Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health indicated to one member of the Committee that an answer to the particular question posed by that Committee member could not be given as the specific matter about which the question was asked was not the subject of an additional estimate.

There was one subject about which there was an additional estimate and that was the international agreement-the Australia-Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) agreement on cooperation. An amount of money was set aside for that item. I asked a question about that item, as it is a very important matter. International treaties are quite important, given the possibility of the use of the external affairs power to implement them. I acknowledge that in this case the treaty said certain things which may not be mandatory on the parties. Article 1 of the treaty states:
The parties shall develop and broaden mutually beneficial cooperation in the fields of medical science and public health.
It then says:

The parties shall direct their joint efforts to combat those diseases that pose the greatest threat to human health and in particular cardiovascular disease, cancer and AIDS. The parties also consider it appropriate to develop mutual co-operation in such fields of medical science and public health as maternal and child care, medical biotechnology and immunology.

I was interested to know what the term `medical biotechnology' meant. I thought it would be appropriate for the Department to be able to provide that information because a specific amount of money was sought by it in respect of that agreement. There was no officer available at that hearing to give such an indication. I was particularly interested to know whether the term involved, for example, the consideration of human embryo experimentation. There is no law in the Commonwealth sphere about that subject. It is most important for the Parliament and the public to know precisely what is involved in the term `medical biotechnology'.

As I said, there was no officer available. It was suggested that the relevant officer, Dr Cumming, was either overseas or going overseas and was not available. We have subsequently received a response which in itself is not adequate. I do not wish, and I do not think it is appropriate, for me to delay the Committee of the Whole in dealing with that response. But, so far as I am concerned, the question of medical biotechnology will need to be addressed when the Estimates Committee next meets. I expect that a senior official, if not the Chairman or the Secretary of the National Health and Medical Research Council, will be able to give some clear, unequivocal and full answers to questions on that very important matter. I simply wish to place on record what the Committee said:
During the Committee's examination of the Department's-
that is, the Department of Community Service and Health-

additional estimates, members of the Committee asked questions concerning sub-program 1.4 `International Health'. The Department was requesting an additional $58,000 for the implementation of the Australian-USSR Agreement on Cooperation in the health and medical sciences fields.

The Committee was concerned that the Department could not provide adequate information concerning the Agreement, the implementation of which was the cause of the additional funds being sought. In particular, the Department was unable to explain what was intended by the term `medical biotechnology', referred to in the Agreement.
The Committee, once again, was concerned that only a single officer, who was unable to attend the Committee's hearing, was considered able to answer the question.
The Committee recommended as follows:

The Committee recommends and re-affirms previous resolutions of Estimates Committees that Departments ensure that officers are present who can explain to the Committee the full background to any item for which additional estimates are sought. The Committee further recommends that the Department re-examine its administrative procedures to ensure that it is able to explain the intent of important Agreements even when the officer directly involved may be unable to attend the Estimates Committee hearing.

It has been my practice, as I recall-and my recollection is not always very good-to give the areas of interest about which questions would be asked. On this occasion I did not do that because the estimates of the Department included in one line a specific item for an international agreement with a particular amount of money. I assumed that there would be somebody at the Estimates hearing to answer my question, but there was not. The subsequent response is not satisfactory and does not go to the essence of the question in the fullest sense.

I know that some comment has been made by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) in another place that Senate committees are not now adequately carrying out their functions to check the actions of the Executive. That is his view. That may well be the case if committees of this Parliament allow a situation where officers of departments do not answer questions, are not able to answer questions or send committee members off fishing in other pools. I certainly will not accept that. I intend in future to make it perfectly clear to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) which officers attempt to make honourable senators fish in other pools. I happen to know that the information that has been given to the Minister by the Department of Community Services and Health on a very important issue is certainly not correct. The Department is on notice that I intend to pursue that matter in the next Estimates hearings.

I commend the Committee. It is obvious that it is concerned to ensure that it carries out a proper function on behalf of the Senate to elicit full information at Committee hearings for the Senate and the public. This is not an easy task. It is not a task that any of us relish, and I suppose it is not a task that any of the officials relish. But that is our job in this sort of democracy. I congratulate the Committee on making it very clear that answers are expected and that the appropriate officers are expected to be in attendance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has taken notice of both Senator Harradine's objection and the point made by Estimates Committee D. As has been indicated in the past to both the Committee and Senator Harradine, the officer involved in this issue was about to leave Australia and in fact left the next day. However, an undertaking has been given that all steps will be taken to ensure that the relevant person will be present when the Committee next meets in order to address the problems that Senator Harradine has raised.

—I have a further question in respect of community services. I still think of community services and health as two separate areas. Nursing homes throughout Australia have the resident classification pro forma of March 1988. They have been asked to check off the responses to 11 factors by each of the residents in their nursing homes. The Department of Community Services and Health will possibly know what I am referring to. I ask: Who on earth put the score beside these various 11 factors, and what qualifications have they for putting them?
—I am advised that the scores were evolved after consultation with something like 1,200 directors of nursing homes all over Australia who were involved in the process.

—The Minister tells me that this score was evolved after consultation with 1,200 nursing homes all over Australia. That does not necessarily mean that the nursing homes approved of this. I have not found one nursing home that thinks the scoresheet makes any sense. Could the Minister say whether the 1,200 nursing homes were in full agreement with the score set-up?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I would just mention something in the report of Estimates Committee D. It is an interesting matter to raise and will give the Minister the opportunity to obtain some answers for Senator Walters. Senator Harradine mentioned that it was said in the report that the Committee was concerned that the level and extent of information available during the hearings sometimes did not meet the standard expected of departments appearing before Estimates committees. Senator Harradine was referring then to a particular inquiry that he was pursuing. It was a course of inquiry that I found quite interesting because, until we had the Estimates committee hearings, I did not know that we had made the type of treaty that Senator Harradine was referring to.

SPEECH.PARA: Another part of the report deals with a similar matter. The Committee found it necessary to comment because it believed that the information that was not able to be supplied meant that the answers given by the officers present were severely lacking. More precisely, I suppose, because a certain officer was not present, the Committee was not able to obtain the information. This matter was raised by Senator Peter Baume and referred to an event which is rather topical at the moment and was even more topical then-the qualifications of Mr Robert Wood or, as we knew him then, Senator Robert Wood. The Minister probably has obtained his answers now so I might continue that story at a later date, if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for his assistance in answering this question. In response to Senator Walters's question, it should be placed on the record that, although I do not think anyone ever gets total agreement, there was overwhelming agreement that the program the Government has introduced is a vast improvement over the pre-existing one. In fact, it could be said with a fair amount of accuracy that it has a 94 per cent accuracy in predicting needs as opposed to something like 9 per cent with the pre-existing system. It can also be said that there is a great deal of support for the Government in that there will be a consultative and review process ongoing under the new scheme. I see Senator Walters shaking her head but if she keeps going any longer, the rest of us will be doing so as well.

—The Minister did not answer the question I asked. I asked: What was the qualification of the person who compiled the scoresheet? The Minister told me that the scoresheet was compiled after full consultation with 1,200 nursing homes. I said, `Could you tell me the name of any nursing home that was in agreement, because I have not found one?'. I thought the Minister might be able to tell me a nursing home that I could approach. Could he find out which nursing home agreed with the method of scoring? Would the Minister please tell me the qualification of the person who finally put that scoresheet together and put it to the Department for acceptance?

—The person involved was qualified in statistics and research. It should also be said that the statistics and the scoresheet were finally evolved after consultation, as I said earlier, with 1,200 directors of nursing homes. As to the other part of Senator Walters's question, even for her to ask that we go through a list of 1,200 nursing homes--
—I did not say that. Give me one name of a nursing home that is satisfied with the scoresheet.
—It might be a bit much at this stage to ask an officer of the Department to be dragged in to find that information for the honourable senator but I am sure we will try to find the information.

—The Minister might be able to find one but I would be very grateful to have the name of that one nursing home when he finds it. Could he come back to me with the name of one nursing home that is satisfied with the scoresheet? I am staggered, but not surprised, that the qualifications of the person who put forward this scoresheet are those of statistician and researcher. I happen to be a nursing sister and I can assure the Minister that it is very difficult to nurse a pat- ient-and I will wait for the Minister to listen so he can understand what I am saying.
—He is rude, isn't he?
—No, he is finding out some information. That is all right.
—I should say--
—Is the Minister correcting the previous question?
—No, I am answering your subsequent question.
—I had not finished but I will sit down.

—In response to the question by Senator Walters, it should be stated that the scoresheet was formulated by this consultative process with the directors of the nursing homes. Three trials were involved. I do not think that Senator Walters should single out one person who, at the end of the day, may have compiled what was put together by these 1,200 directors in this consultative process.
—I gather that the Minister will come back to me with the name of one nursing home that is happy about this matter.
—I would love to.

—That is good. As a trained sister, I can assure the Minister that it is very difficult to nurse a patient who is incontinent. With incontinence occurring more than once a day, this means that the patient is fully nursed more than once a day-bed fully changed, the whole bit. That patient gets a score of one. That patient would need to have pressure areas seen to at the same time. I am not suggesting for one moment that that patient would have just a score of one--
—I wonder whether at this stage I could provide the information you sought earlier?

—Does the Minister want me to finish my question? This is the second time he has interrupted. A patient who is incontinent more than once daily has a score of one. That same patient would need care for the prevention of pressure areas on every occasion that the bed is changed. So there would be, let us say, attention one to three times a day. That gives that patient a score for that of 2.63. So if we add that score of one to the 2.63 we get a total score for that patient of 3.63. That is a patient who takes considerable nursing care. But a patient who is not incontinent but just needs full assistance to be transferred from the bed to sitting beside the bed, gets a score for that alone of 4.37. So a patient who is not incontinent and who only needs two people to help him out of bed and make him comfortable in a chair beside the bed has a score of 4.37 while a patient who is bedridden and incontinent more than once daily and needs a full bed change-full bed linen and the lot-who has pressure areas being cared for at least one to three times a day gets only a final score of 3.63. That does not make sense from the point of view of the nursing staff.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
