DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Purchase of Residential Property by Non-Australians-Australian Capital Territory Schools-Arms Race at Sea-Automotive Industry Authority Report

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m, under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday I asked a question in relation to the purchase by non-Australians of residential property. My question read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It refers to an article in the Brisbane Sun newspaper on 5 May 1988 which indicated that a group of Japanese performers in Brisbane for World Expo 88 bought a house for $350,000. Do Treasury guidelines prevent the purchase of residential property by non-Australians except in special circumstances, and, if so, what are those circumstances? Have the details of this particular purchase been investigated and will it be allowed to proceed? If the sale is contrary to Government guidelines, will any action be taken against the real estate agent who arranged the sale?

It is fairly common in the Senate that if a senator wants a considered reply on a specific matter he or she provides detail of a possible question to the Minister or to the Minister's staff. I left the question with the Minister's office on 10 May, seven days before I asked the question. I expected that I would receive a comprehensive answer. I did not. The last two parts of the question were not answered at all. The answer that was provided is as follows:

Last September the foreign investment guidelines for the purchase of residential property by foreigners were changed. There are three special categories of exemption from that restriction. The first is for Australian citizens resident abroad, the second is for intending migrants who have received approval to take up permanent residence in Australia and the third category is for foreign companies seeking accommodation for their senior executives while they are resident in Australia.

I had indicated in my question that there was a report that a group of Japanese performers in Brisbane for World Expo 88 had bought a house for $350,000. Let us consider the Treasury guidelines as to exemption from the restrictions that residential property cannot be bought by people from foreign countries. The first is for Australian citizens resident abroad. Obviously, these Japanese performers do not fit into that category. The second category of exemption is for intending migrants who have received approval to take up permanent residence in Australia. Again, that category does not fit these Japanese performers at World Expo 88. The third category is for foreign companies seeking accommodation for their senior executives while they are resident in Australia. I hold that that category does not fit these people who are reported to have bought the house. The article says that this group of Japanese performers bought the house themselves. That would hardly fit the category of foreign companies seeking accommodation for their senior executives while they are resident in Australia. The answer to my question continued as follows:
I have seen the article to which Senator Colston refers and it seems to me that the particular purchase fits into the last of those three categories.

I maintain that, on the evidence that is available so far, that is not correct, that it does not fit into that category of foreign companies seeking accommodation for their senior executives. The article seemed to indicate that these people banded together, pooled their money, and bought the house themselves. The answer continued:
I will refer the article to the Treasurer's office for confirmation that this is indeed the case and for any other comments that the Treasurer wishes to make about Senator Colston's question.

If one presents a possible question to a Minister's office seven days in advance of asking the question in the Senate, I think that the relevant office-in this case it was the Treasurer's office-should be contacted in that time. If it were perhaps one or two days one might say that there was not enough time, but in relation to my question there was a whole week. I think the answer that was provided was totally unsatisfactory, given that a whole week's notice was provided. I ask the Minister on duty tonight-the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus)-whether he will use his good offices to obtain a comprehensive answer to my question. I would expect that it should not be beyond the resources of the Government to provide an answer by the time we first meet next week. The matter that I have raised is an important one. Many Queensland residents believe the Japanese in Australia are taking us for a bunch of suckers and are thumbing their nose at the Australian Government's foreign investment guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by drawing the attention of the Senate to a letter published in the Canberra Times of Thursday, 19 May-that is, today-which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned, parents of Page Primary School children and concerned citizens of Page, wish to notify the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that Eric Willmot has been targeted for closure as Chief Education Officer.

Being fair, we give him two weeks to respond to the criteria for closure, but having learned our procedures from the Authority itself, we will most probably change the criteria once they have been addressed.

This letter was signed by a group of Page parents, and, commented the Canberra Times, `many other letters from parents, students and citizens of Page have expressed similar sentiments'. In due course, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) will have self-government, and parents and concerned citizens will-if a democratic and representative form of government is in place-be able to make their views known to their own duly elected members of an ACT assembly. The present situation is quite other: when concerned parents at an ACT school have no recourse, and as a last hope have to depend on writing letters to the paper and appealing to a senator from Western Australia then that is a very sad state of affairs.

The education system in Canberra was, not long ago, the admiration of educationists around Australia. Twenty years ago educationists and the ACT community together created an education system which allowed the democratic participation of parents and teachers at all levels, and ultimate authority was vested not in a Minister but in an authority comprising parents, educators, and ministerial nominees, with an independent chair. In 1978, Professor Grant Harman wrote:

. . . the experiment has been an unqualified success. The essential goals of the community and teacher groups have been largely achieved, and the new ACT School Authority clearly provides public services at least equal to, and in my judgment better than, those previously supplied in Canberra by the New South Wales Department of Education, and that enjoyed by comparable urban communities throughout Australia.

That was Professor Grant Harman; many other parents and academics are on record as being equally impressed by the lively, multifarious and academically respectable record of the ACT Schools Authority. Last year, then Minister John Brown abolished the Authority; that is, he abolished the Council and transferred all authority into the hands of one appointed man. This man, the Chief Education Officer, is head of the Department which he administers, and is himself answerable to the Minister-whoever that may be. Of course in the States which have this sort of traditional bureaucratic system, the Minister is at least elected from that State. Not so, in Canberra. Not, at least, until the ACT has self-government.

I started by quoting a letter from the people of Page. As described by Senator Reid earlier today, one of the first acts of the Minister, through his one-man schools authority, was to announce the closure of a number of Canberra primary schools. But, one of the strengths of the development of junior education in the ACT was the emphasis on community schools, combined with a lack of compulsion; this meant that there was great diversity amongst the schools-which tended to specialise-and a genuine freedom of choice for parents.

The Minister's decision caused dismay throughout the school communities. Eight schools were originally targeted for closure. Eight communities were given the chance to prepare a submission as to why their school should be allowed to survive. The response was impressive, with thousands of questionnaires distributed, petitions signed, letters written and meetings convened. Unhappily this also had the effect of setting community against community and school against school.

Democracy depends on information; bureaucracy often depends on obfuscation. It was characteristic of a bureaucratic decision that the final report, Community Schools for Canberra, was issued at 5.30 p.m. on 6 May, and was embargoed for the media until 6.30 that evening. Honourable senators are unlikely to have forgotten that this was the weekend-it was a long weekend-of the opening by Her Majesty of the new Parliament House, so it is hardly surprising that the news of the closure of one small school in South Belconnen did not get banner headlines.

The fact is that of the eight schools condemned to be closed, five were reprieved; three were to be closed as planned; and one new one, without any prior warning, had been added to the list. The people of Page are shocked. Page is an area of South Belconnen, which has a largely working-class population. House prices are relatively low and the residents tend to be lower income families, with many single-parent families. This is a scenario for trauma, hardship, and misery: many young children; few, if any, second cars; young mothers attempting to cope with public transport. Yet the local school is to be closed. It is clearly absurd that a senator from Western Australia is the one to be making a plea for people from a suburb of Canberra-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid did a good job today, so it is not only you, Senator.

—I agree-but this is a consequence of the absurd system which dominates the ACT today. Self-government will bring its own problems, no doubt. But it is inconceivable that a democratically elected assembly, elected by, from and for the ACT, would deal as insensitively with its own constituents, as has been the case under the present one-man-band administration.
—Arrogant.

—Indeed. The people of Page rallied quickly after hearing the news of the threat to their school. Almost 80 per cent of the families who have children at the school attended a public meeting on 11 May. The feeling of the meeting was unanimous-that Page school must remain open.

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore ask the Government to defer the implementation of the Community Schools for Canberra final report, with respect to all schools in the ACT, until the administration of Canberra and the ACT is in the hands of the ACT, that is, until after self-government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic about which I wish to speak this evening is the very necessary campaign to disarm the seas. While I rejoiced with the peace movement at the signing of the intermediate-range nuclear force (INF) agreement last December and I welcome the prospect of talks on removing land based long range missiles or intercontinental ballistic missiles, I also feel that Australia needs to pay far more attention to the arms race at sea. I am particularly concerned at the increasing momentum of the naval arms race in the Pacific. Coming from Western Australia, I have noted the increase in the number of visits by United States of America nuclear warships since 1980, since my State gets about two-thirds of these ship visits to Australia. However, the number of visits has declined in the past few years. What we are now getting represents largely the spin-off from the United States presence in the Persian Gulf which, in itself, is rather worrying because the actions in which the United States Navy engaged there are sometimes seen as provocative.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now obvious that these port calls are really for rest and recreation of the crews involved and nothing to do with strategic importance, which is the argument the New Zealanders have always used in working towards a ban on nuclear warships visits. The world is no worse off because United States nuclear warships cannot visit New Zealand. Indeed New Zealand's move has given inspiration to many others around the world who believe that we can move beyond block thinking and that we do not have to choose between alliance partners in either Washington or Moscow.

This is precisely what concerns the United States. It is concerned about the spread of what it has dubbed the kiwi disease. We now have the ironic spectacle of warheads being removed from Cruise missiles in Western Europe once the treaty is ratified and then put on sea launch cruise missiles that ultimately end in Australian ports. On 8 March an article on the front page of the Australian suggested that Australia could take the nuclear warheads being disposed of as a result of the INF agreement and bury them here. In that way, we could have a new multi-billion dollar industry and contribute towards disarmament at the same time, or so the proponents said. Fortunately this ludicrous proposition was immediately dismissed by various authorities, including the Australian Government, but it showed the ignorance of so many people that they did not realise that only the missiles are being dismantled-not the nuclear warheads.

There were supposed to be 560 ground launch cruise missiles deployed in Western Europe, but the United States plans to deploy about 4,000 at sea made by the same company-General Dynamics-that made the Trident submarine. Of these, 758 will be the nuclear armed Tomahawk land attack missiles deployed on ships and submarines around the world.

While the Europeans protested at the deployment of Cruise missiles in five countries there was a great silence here, as if we did not know that Cruise missiles were on board ships and submarines visiting our ports and harbours. They were on board the battleship USS Missouri which came to Fremantle and Sydney in 1986 and again in 1987. All we heard about was its role in September 1945-and it did have an important historic role-and all the girls entertaining the sailors in Kings Cross over Christmas. These Tomahawks are being deployed on other warships coming to Australia in the years ahead, unless we follow the brave example of the Labor Government across the Tasman and say that we will not entertain such warships visits any more. In other words, the warheads are coming to Australia, not to be buried but just to be redeployed in a very much alive, active, ready-to-go form. Of course, while the Government does not mind criticising the nuclear waste disposal proposal, it goes along with the ludicrous `neither confirm nor deny' policy of the United States Government. The Soviets obviously knows what is on board these ships and submarines. Indeed, people can find out for themselves just by going to the Parliamentary Library or any public library and looking it up in Janes Fighting Ships. But the public is not officially told that nuclear weapons are on board these warships.

The whole relationship with the United States is characterised on our part by even declining to ask the questions in the first place. We thoroughly deserve our reputation of subservience. This point can best be illustrated by the reporter from the Sun-Herald who, when he rang up the Central Intelligence Agency in 1985 to ask why Pine Gap was code-named Merino, was told it was `because we built Pine Gap in a land of sheep'.

I would, however, like to praise this Government for beginning to stir on the subject of security and arms control talks in the North Pacific, even if no interest has been shown by our great and powerful friend, the United States. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, made an important contribution at the Australian National University in Canberra on 12 August last year when he gave the opening address at the Conference on Security and Arms Control in the North Pacific organised by the Peace Research Centre, the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre and the International Relations Department. Mr Richard Woolcott, our Ambassador to the United Nations, followed this up for the Minister by reading his speech to the United Nations General Assembly on 8 October last year. He again referred to Australia's suggestion that there would be an advantage in the United States and the Soviet Union initiating a dialogue on their respective security perceptions and concerns in this area of the North Pacific.

Although a great deal of work went into these speeches, I now note that there has been a general reshuffle in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. There seems some uncertainty on the level of expertise in the area of security and arms control. As this has come along at about the same time as the downgrading of the position of Ambassador for Disarmament, it leads me to question this Government's priorities after such a promising start. I speculate that there are elements in the Australian Labor Party that are really not the slightest bit supportive of the Minister's concern and would really feel far more at home with the Cold War warriors in the Opposition. Certainly, they would have felt more comfortable with Mr Howard's cold war speech on international affairs in Hobart on 2 March this year than with Mr Hayden's contribution at the Australian National University (ANU) or in New York. As for the lame excuse that the section is being run down after the International Year of Peace (IYP), that hardly makes sense in the light of the stated commitment to verification procedures, arms control in the North Pacific, disarmament and development and the United Nations special session on disarmament which starts on 31 May. IYP should have heralded a greater ongoing commitment in this area, not a smaller one. Considering that the Department of Defence is the largest department in Canberra, it does no speak much for our sense of priorities if we run down our tiny peace, arms control and disarmament section in Foreign Affairs in this way.

What is the situation at sea around Australia? Through most of this century the Pacific has been what the United States of America's Seventh Fleet likes to refer to as `the American lake'. Around 1960 the Soviet Union decided to try to match the blue water navy of the United States and under Admiral Gorshkov, who finally retired in 1985 after 29 years, the Soviets built up a very large naval fleet in the Pacific. Indeed, the Red Banner Fleet is the largest of all the Soviet fleets, although the other three are part of the Atlantic fleet. Their rationale was partly to make sure that they were never humiliated again as they were during the Cuban crisis in 1962, partly because of the deteriorating relationship with China in the 1960s culminating in armed clashes in 1968-69, and partly because the United States decided in 1960 to deploy Polaris submarines in the North Pacific.

Australia played its role in that decision when the North West Cape communications station was negotiated in 1963, one year before the Polaris submarine came on line. While it is perfectly true that the Soviet navy in the Pacific is far larger than the United States navy-and bean counting is a good way to distort strategic realities-the United States still has the upper hand. Basically, this is because the United States has around 350 bases and facilities in and around the Pacific away from its own west coast. The Soviet Union, on the other hand, is penned up in the inhospitable north-west corner of the ocean where much of the coast is icebound for the most part of the year and where the Red Banner Fleet can be bottled up in the Sea of Japan by the United States Navy and the Japanese Maritime Self-Defence Force. This is because the United States and Japan control the choke points out of the sea leading to the ocean. From Alaska and the Aleutian Islands the United States comes very close to the Soviet coast and is able to monitor submarine movements and air force flights, much as it did on the night that the Soviet Air Force shot down the unfortunate Korean airliner, flight KAL-007.

Having all these bases and facilities around the Pacific, the United States is able to keep 55 per cent of its ships and submarines at sea on a constant round of port calls and exercises, along with its many allies in the region. The Soviet Union has a sea-to-port ratio of about 15 per cent, and the only forward base between Vladivostok and Socotra in the north-west corner of the Indian Ocean has been at Cam Ranh Bay since 1979. However, there is no doubt that the Soviet Navy in the Pacific is excessively large and that it worries its neighbours, who are not inclined to view it as purely defensive. The Soviet Union would like the countries in the region to remain neutral in the event of a global conflict when the main battlefield might be in Europe, so it is hardly likely to block the sea lines of communication in an area where all the regional powers depend on trade for their survival. Nor has the Soviet Union the right to have any bases in Vietnam, such as Cam Ranh Bay, or those in the Indian Ocean at Aden and in the Red Sea. Even more ridiculous is the Soviet assertion that Cam Ranh Bay is not a base but a transit facility or marina. That ranks with the assertion that Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape are joint facilities in Australia because none of them would have been established by the host country. They are there simply to serve the global interests of the superpowers and the sooner they all go, the better.

More recently the Soviet Union has deployed new Delta class submarines in the Sea of Okhotsk, which acts as a kind of strategic sanctuary for its submarines where they can avoid the anti-submarine warfare activities of the United States and Japan. Besides deploying the SSN-18 on Delta class submarines since 1979, the Soviets have started testing a new sea-launched ballistic missile, the SSNX-23. So far none of their new giant Typhoon submarines have appeared in the Pacific as they have all gone to the northern fleet. New attack submarines in the Pacific have included the Akula class and the diesel-electric Kilo class, while it is possible that one of the new Oscar class may join the Pacific fleet before long. Besides the two carriers-or more strictly, the tactical aircraft carrying cruisers-three new recent surface combatants to join the Pacific fleet in late 1985 were the nuclear powered guided missile cruiser Frunze, the Sovremenny class guided missile destroyer Osmotritel'nyu and the Kashin class destroyer Strogii. Three more guided missile destroyers of the Sovremenny and Udaloy class joined the Pacific fleet in December 1987 in addition to the two already stationed in Vladivostok. The SSNX-21 is also being tested as a more accurate sea-launched cruise missile along with the SSMX-24.

The United States Trident submarine program was initiated way back in the early 1970s and the deployment began in the Pacific in 1982 with the USS Ohio. The United States Navy likes to boast that the Trident is the most expensive and destructive weapon ever made and we are meant to feel privileged that the first eight have now been fully deployed in the Pacific Ocean-or peaceful ocean, as it should be. After 1992 these submarines will be fitted with the Trident 2 or D5 missile system, giving them a first strike capability and raising further doubt about the status of the North West Cape communications base. The Los Angeles class attack submarine has been deployed since 1976 and after the mid-1990s the Seawolf class will replace it. The Reagan Administration, under former Navy Secretary John Lehman, set about acquiring a 600-ship navy by 1990, although that goal may be deferred with the recent defence cutbacks in Washington. Many of these new ships were deployed in the Pacific, including two of the revamped battleships armed with Tomahawk sea-launched cruise missiles.

Pursuing the cult of the offensive, the United States Navy came up with the maritime strategy in the early years of the Reagan Administration, an offensive and destabilising approach which made nonsense of claims that sea power was the most effective form of deterrent. Provocative exercises, designated the `Fleetex' series, were held off the Soviet coast each year, along with old favourites like `Rimpac' and `Team Spirit', getting bigger each time they were held. Sea-launched cruise missiles are regarded as particularly destabilising because they are impossible to verify and there is no way of telling the difference between conventionally armed and nuclear armed versions. Of course, once they are on their way, the proof would be at the point of impact and it is a bit late by then.

Faced with this escalation of the arms race at sea, it is easy to see why an agreement in the Asia-Pacific region will be much harder to achieve than the agreement in Europe on intermediate-range nuclear force missile systems. In the Pacific an obvious asymmetry occurs where a land power faces a maritime power. In Europe there are two clear blocs, while in the North Pacific there are several regional powers as well as the superpowers. The United States does not want an agreement in the Pacific, where it is clearly dominant, and Japan has shown no interest either.
Nonetheless, if we are to pursue regional security there must be talks and Mr Hayden has outlined areas where agreement could be reached. In his ANU speech he suggested:

They could aspire, for example, to put a ceiling on, reduce or eliminate strategic nuclear weapons from the region or substrategic nuclear weapons. Naval forces could be limited by numbers or tonnage either in the aggregate or by selected types of warship. Various naval disengagement arrangements can be imagined, again in aggregate, or confined to particular types of vessels such as submarines or aircraft carriers. One variant of naval disengagement that has endured in the literature and surfaced periodically in official proposals, is the idea of anti-submarine warfare sanctuaries for strategic ballistic missile submarines. The concept of a nuclear-free zone could be looked into. There are a variety of confidence building measures such as transparency, notification of manoeuvres and exercises and limits on their scale and/or location. Finally, one could list a straightforward dialogue on security perceptions and concerns, either as a step towards an agreed negotiating objective or simply in the hope of teasing out possible steps of benefit to all concerned.
The Minister also noted:
It is clear that the Soviet Union wants to address security concerns in the Asia-Pacific region.

It is also clear that most of the security problems in the region cannot be constructively addressed without the positive involvement of the Soviet Union. It is in the interests of all of us to provide the room for these sentiments to be translated into concrete actions in a measured step-by-step fashion.

The high seas are indeed a dangerous potential battleground. Many strategic analysts regard the possibility of nuclear war at sea as extremely grave, for several good reasons: First, the rapid build-up of nuclear weapons on board warships and submarines, to which I have already referred; secondly, the frequency of naval exercises involving the super-powers and their allies in dangerously close contact with their opponents; and, thirdly, the lack of visibility of nuclear weapons at sea, making public protest much less likely than against nuclear missile silos and stations on land. Fourthly, the mobility of nuclear weapons at sea gives the superpowers' naval planners a feeling of invulnerability, or a false sense of security. Fifthly, the high mobility also increases the accident possibility. Sixthly, distance from chain of command and possible breaks in chain of command could result in commanders of vessels launching their nuclear payloads in time of high stress. Seventhly, the relatively underpopulated oceans may give naval planners an excuse to test out their naval strengths against their adversaries.

Non-government organisations have already taken up the challenge of addressing this enormous problem of the arms race at sea. I have mentioned the conference at the ANU last August and the follow-up work of the Peace Research Centre is planned for the rest of this year. In February this year there was another conference on the subject in Wellington, New Zealand, organised by the Pacific Institute of Resource Management and Greenpeace, and yet another in Japan. Greenpeace International has launched a nuclear free seas campaign and with the Institute of Policy Studies in the United States is preparing a series of 10 briefings to be known as the Neptune Papers. The first was published in October last year and was tabled in the Senate.

I hope that this Parliament will take an increasing interest in this issue in the months ahead and that, instead of stale old rhetoric about the Soviet threat, we shall hear constructive discussions about security and arms control in the Pacific. Australia is a minor player and we need to work together with other middle-ranking powers in the region, encouraging countries like Japan and South Korea to join in and perhaps working more closely with countries similar to our own, such as Canada and New Zealand. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has indicated some initial steps forward, but his Government needs to back up those proposals by boosting its expertise in the disarmament section of his Department, not running it down. Finally, for those interested and in order for honourable senators to get a broader picture of the problems and prospects that lie ahead, I recommend a set of conference papers from the ANU conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to direct some remarks to the Report on the State of the Automotive Industry 1987, which was tabled earlier today but on which I was precluded from making remarks by the expiration of the time allowed for the discussion of Government papers. The tabling today of this report demonstrates the contempt which the Hawke Labor Government has for both Parliament and for the law. The fact is that, in tabling this report, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is in breach of the law. More particularly, he is in breach of section 8 of the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984. Section 8 (1) of that Act requires that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority shall, not later than 31 March in each year after 1985, prepare and give to the Minister a report on the state of the automotive industry during the period of 12 months that ended on the preceding 31 December and on the prospects for the automotive industry during the year in which the report is furnished and during future years.

It appears from the tabling of this report that the Authority has complied with this section of the legislation. That is evident from the letter which is incorporated on the first page of the report. It is addressed to Senator Button in the following terms:
Dear Minister,
In accordance with section 8 (1) of the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984, we have pleasure in submitting to you the report on the State of the Automotive Industry for the year 1987.

The letter is signed by members of the Authority, Mr Hunter as Chairman, Messrs Conron and Gietzelt and Mr Scales, Chief Executive and Associate member. That letter is dated 31 March 1988. However, clause 8 (3) of the legislation reads:

The Minister shall cause a copy of the report given under sub-section (1) to be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which the Minister received the Report.

Quite clearly, the Minister has not complied with this requirement of the legislation, because the report tabled today is not that which was presented to him on 31 March. Instead, it is the supplementary report of the Authority which was presented to the Minister on 13 April. That is referred to on the following page of the report in a letter from the Automotive Industry Authority dated 13 April 1988. This letter, as with the previous letter, is again addressed to the Minister, in the following terms:
Dear Minister,
In accordance with section 8 (1) of the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984, we submitted to you the report on the State of the Automotive Industry for the year 1987 on 31 March 1988-
as I previously mentioned that they had done. The letter continues:

We now submit to you a supplementary report on the state of the Automotive Industry for 1987, in light of the Government's decision to revise the assistance arrangements under the Passenger Motor Vehicle Manufacturing Plan.

That letter is again signed by the same four members of the Authority. Therefore, the Minister is not only failing to comply with the legislation by today tabling this report which was given to him on 13 April rather than the report of 31 March, but is misleading Parliament because he purports that this report of 13 April is that of 31 March. There can be no doubt that this report tabled today is the supplementary report and not the report of 31 March, as is required to be tabled under the Act. A perusal of the report demonstrates that quite clearly.

Page 45 of the report refers to the lowering of assistance levels announced by the Minister on 13 April-clearly a decision that was taken after 31 March and contained in a report that was obviously written after 31 March. On page 51 the report again refers to the changes announced on 13 April. Between pages 53 and 54 the report discusses in detail the changes announced on 13 April. Between pages 157 and 166, in appendix 5 to the report, the complete ministerial statement of 13 April is reproduced. What further evidence is required that this document which was tabled today is a supplementary report-the report of 13 April-and not the report of 31 March, which is the one required to be tabled under the Act?

Where is the report of 31 March referred to in the first letter attached to this report? Most importantly, this is the report that is required to be tabled under the Act. We may ask why the Minister has failed to table that report. Is it because what I raised as a possibility in a question to the Minister on 18 April-that the Government's decision in regard to the changes in protection for the automotive industry was not consistent with the recommendations of the Automotive Industry Authority report-is in fact the case? In answering that question the Minister said that the recommendations of the Authority with regard to assistance measures would probably be included in its report. He claimed that the Government decision was consistent with the recommendations in the report. In the light of the Government's failure to table the report of 31 March as required by the Act, suspicion must now be raised as to whether this is the case.

What is the Government trying to hide by refusing to table that report, by indeed refusing to comply with the law, and by misleading the Parliament by purporting that the report of 13 April is the 31 March report? Unless the Minister is now prepared to comply with the law, a law initiated by his own Government and passed though this Parliament, and to table the report of 31 March, I believe that his only option is to resign. I call on the Minister either to comply with the law or to resign his portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to the Senate that I will not respond to Senator Vallentine's habitual payment of her dues to her controller in the Soviet Embassy. She reads words and phrases, the meaning of which she had no comprehension. I was present in the chamber when the adjournment debate began and I was very interested in what Senator Colston had to say because he made a very real point. Senator Colston went as far as any loyal member of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) could go in pointing out the dimensions of this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take a few minutes to amplify this point and make clear what he was saying because the inflation of prices in domestic dwellings from overseas buying is a real problem in southern Queensland. The first point I make is that it is not only the Japanese buyers because others operating in this market include Hong Kong Chinese, Malays and members of other Asian countries who come to this country and buy residences not for their own purposes necessarily but for investment or rental purposes.

The second point I make relates to the total ineffectuality of the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) guidelines and controls on these purchases. Let us set aside for a moment whether or not it is wise to apply these controls. I simply do not know the answer to that, but the rules that were brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) earlier this year are totally ineffectual. One can drive a horse and cart through them. There is no way of enforcing them, let alone policing them. I believe that a real case can be made to throw them out or at least revise them and introduce something that works, if it is at all possible to control the situation. As I say, I think it is a very complex area and I am not sure in my own mind what the answer is. However, I am sure that, as a legislator, to have rules and laws that can be so flagrantly and easily broken is bad for society, and that is why I am speaking tonight.

My third point is that the influence of these overseas buyers is having an effect that runs through all residential accommodation in the region. It is true that they are operating in the upper end of the market and they are probably operating in an area where housing prices range from $350,000 up to $1m. It would be no exaggeration to say that in that bracket the presence of these overseas buyers is adding an extra third to the local value of these houses. People are still buying houses whether they are Australian citizens or residents of another country; so this is not operating as a barrier to people purchasing houses. However, the important point-and the point that I am sure Senator Colston is concerned about-is that there is a flow on from this right down to the lowest level of housing prices in the country and in this region.

I do not know what the median price of a house would be in the Brisbane area, but I guess it would be between $55,000 and $65,000. That price is being inflated quite considerably as a result of buying at the upper end of the market and, as a result, I think that there are social consequences. Housing prices are high enough already but interest rates, despite some easing in mortgage rates over the past 12 months, are also very high. It is very hard for young people just starting out to buy their first home. It is also very difficult for families with children because as a family grows it must move into a larger house with extra room and study areas for children as they go into high school. A very real social problem is developing as a consequence of this intrusion into the local market by overseas buyers.

I have no objection at all to the influx of overseas capital if it comes into this country to create jobs, to buy factories and generate an industrial base because the whole community will benefit, but I remain to be convinced that the purchase of residential accommodation by overseas buyers has any benefit at all for the Australian community. While I am on this theme I really wonder how advantageous it is for us to sell nearly all our tourist hotels and facilities to Japanese buyers. I am not sure that there is any long term benefit in that for the Australian community. However, I reinforce very much what Senator Colston has said. First, the foreign investment guidelines are absolutely unenforce- able and meaningless and as such must be changed if the Government is to preserve any respect for the law at all. Secondly, the Government must address the impact of overseas buying on the social life of the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly respond to some of the points raised in this debate tonight. I refer first to Senator Colston, whose comments were reinforced by Senator MacGibbon. Senator Colston asked that his contribution be made known to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and a reply obtained. I undertake to do that. Senator Jenkins repeated a point made earlier today by Senator Reid in relation to the Page Primary School. Much of her speech was on the theme of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and the need for the community to be able to direct its resources. In response to Senator Jenkins, as the respon- sible Australian Democrat in this area, it is interesting that she has yet to commit herself to the Government's self-government proposal, which may go some way to addressing the principal objections raised in her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine's contribution will be passed on to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I am sure that it will have a major impact and will influence his thinking as he works out the next phase of our foreign policy. Finally, Senator Chapman proved tonight that as a lawyer he would make a good senator and as a senator he should never try to be a lawyer. Section 8 (1) of the Automotive Industry Authority Act makes it quite clear that the responsibility is on the Authority. Even Senator Chapman acknowledged that pursuant to Section 8 (3) the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) had tabled the document within 15 days, so I do not think that one can maintain an allegation of a breach of law by the Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.17 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 2-Quarterly Survey of Balance Sheet Information.
No. 3-Survey of International Trade in Services.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Federal Government partly or wholly responsible for drawing up contingency plans in the event of a nuclear accident involving nuclear powered vessels in Queensland harbours.
(2) For which Queensland harbours do such contingency plans exist.
(3) Do such contingency plans exist for Royal Australian Navy ports, or commercial ports, or both.
(4) Do such plans deal only with accidents involving nuclear powered vessels, or do they also cover accidents involving nuclear armed vessels.
(5) Is the Minister aware that contingency plans involving nuclear accidents in the Western Australian ports of Fremantle and Cockburn Sound have been available to the public for about one year now.
(6) In view of this, will the Minister make any such contingency plans for Queensland ports publicly available; if so, when; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Because authority for controlling the resources of State Government emergency services organizations is vested in the State Governments, the Commonwealth relies on each of the States to implement emergency plans and to participate in their development. With respect to plans for accidents involving the reactors of nuclear powered warships in Queensland harbours, the Commonwealth assists in the provision of overall guidelines, technical expertise and specialised equipment and co-ordinates through the Natural Disasters Organisation any additional Commonwealth support necessary.

(2) and (3) There is a port safety plan for the Fisherman Island complex in Brisbane. It is the only berthing facility that would currently be used for nuclear powered warships in Queensland. It is a commercial port.
(4) Under existing arrangements, accidents involving vessels which may be carrying nuclear weapons would be handled in accordance with the general emergency plan of the relevant port.
(5) Yes.
(6) Any decision to make Queensland's port safety plans public is a matter for the Queensland Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday, 18 April 1988 (Hansard, page 1618), Senator Macklin asked me a question without notice concerning an efficiency scrutiny review of some CES services, which allegedly proposed, amongst other things, the introduction by the CES of a fee for service for client groups, including disadvantaged groups. The Minister for Employment and Education Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the efficiency scrutinies conducted by the Block review of the Australian Public Service, concerned CES involvement in temporary and professional placement services.
That particular review reached its conclusions some twelve months ago.

The findings of the review have not been presented to the Government for consideration. Initially the presentation of the review report was delayed because of last year's federal election. Subsequently the restructuring of Commonwealth Departments and changes to administrative arrangements, particularly the establishment of the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) further delayed the report.

More recently the Government has agreed to a broad based review of organisational arrangements within DEET, for the delivery of services to all clients of the Department. The report of the Block examination of temporary and professional services has now been subsumed by the wider review.
There are therefore no proposals before the Government concerning the introduction of fees for service by the CES, nor is the Government considering such a move.
It is also relevant that Australia is a signatory to an international agreement to provide a free public employment service. The Government intends to honour its commitments under the agreement.
